UPDATED: OCT 3, 2012 One of the best light, Belgian triple I¬íve had. Very interesting but yet subtle ale. More bittering hops than most, but they work well with the somewhat more complex maltiness that is found in this ale. The flavors work really well to together.

This is a very nice American interpretation of Belgian Tripel.  Given that this is among my favorite beer styles it was really easy to rate this one highly.  It was a smooth, creamy beer from a great Brewery.  I¬íve never been disappointed by anything from Allagash.

12oz bottle at Mussel Bar in Bethesda.  I¬ím sure I¬íve had this before but hadn¬ít rated it...so now will work.  Classic tripel golden in color with a large white head and substantial lacing.  Sweet and smooth with a lot of fruit but not an overly heavy body, which is great for this sort of beer.  Finish has just a little hops and I found it quite refreshing.

750mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours cloudy golden yellow with a big white head. Beautiful floral aroma with lots of champagne yeast, dry pear, and slight banana and honey qualities. Extremely complex flavour of honey, banana, quite yeasty, dry fruits (such as pear and green apple) - the honey and banana are at the beginning, with the yeast and dryness finishing. Very high carbonation, though does not detract from the complexity. Most wonderful tripel.
Bottle from Super Jr. San Diego.  Cloudy straw yellow color and minimal head with some lacing.  Meyer lemon and belg
Aroma of butter, passionfruit and wheat.  Pours yellow with a thick foam head.  Tastes of dough, papaya.  It¬ís good
Poured a hazy golden/yellow with a big, frothy head as a triple should. Nice spice, but there was a sour note that was unlike Belgian triples. A good beer.

Bottle at American Flatbread in Burlington, VT.  Finally got the chance to try this (we get the Dubbel here, but I¬íve never seen the Tripel).  Quite good, and pretty much what I was expecting from the style.  Spicy and peppery.  Very easy to drink; deceptively strong.
Bottle. Pours golden with a big foamy white head. Flavor is sugar sweetness with spice a decent hop profile. Not a typical tripel but still very good.

Big bottle (BATCH# 169) from Chips @ OBX.  Poured a hazy yellow.  Big foamy head.  The aroma has less sweetness in it than other trippels, I¬ím picking up more grains with some lemon zest, spice.  The taste though has the sweetness in it.  Med lite sweetness, more of a dry finish.  Ave carbonation, med body.  Has a nice, simle bitter kick at the end also.  Nicely done. Nice palate.

Batch 169 - Pours a cloudy yellow gold with an enormous head.  Aroma is of lemon and spice.  Taste is banana and mango sweet with a bit of exotic spice thrown in.  The finish is residual sweetness slightly offset by subtle spiciness.  The higher alcohol is masked almost entirely in this one.

Thanks Eric!
Aroma: minty, spicy
Taste: spicy, fruity, sweet
A very tasty Triple.

Tasted on 6/25/11 from a 750mL corked and caged bottle purchased at Binny¬ís South Loop, Batch #145.  Pours hazy orange-yellow with a thick, rocky off-white head that slowly recedes to rocky lace, leaving a bit of residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is fruity with ripe apricot and peach, along with spicy yeast , and some earthy, dusty basement aromas.  The flavor is lightly sweet with caramel malt up front, moving to the spicy, earthy yeast flavors and a hint of light bitterness.  The body is medium and oily with lively, stinging carbonation and a long spicy and caramel malt finish.
A lot of biscuity  yeast in the aroma, with some spice and a little banana.  Taste is sweet, with a hefty alcohol kick to finish.  A really nice sipper.

12oz bottle. Slightly hazy golden pour with a short head that leaves a little lace. Yeast and tropical fruit on the nose with a very light spicy/herbal note. I caught a whiff off buttered popcorn in there too. Fuller body than I¬íd expected with an almost sticky quality. That tropical fruit note carries through and there¬ís a honey sweetness to it. Finishes a little tart and leaves a weird feel in the mouth with too much alcohol.

Very pleasing somewhat sweet flavor. Well balanced. Slightly tart. There¬ís 1000 reviews of this already - my adjectives aren¬ít any better than everyone else¬ís. I like this - and I usually don¬ít like this kind of beer.
Pours a fading ring of off-white head with a deep golden body.  Aromas of fruit and yeast.  Flavors of yeast, passion fruit.  Finish is dry and slighty spicy.

I liked this beer, but was slightly underwhelmed. Nice alcohol forward aromas of buttery bread, maybe some, and a bit of a bitter finish. Finish does last long, for sure. 

But, I just didn¬ít find it as complex as other great in this category.

Hazy golden beer with a persistent white head.  Aroma is great but a little to lite, I would prefer it were stronger.  Honey and spices with a nice yeast undertone.  Flavor is like a tart honey with some banana flavor and other spices.  Beer finishes a little oddly and is a bit to light bodied.  Plenty of carbonation.  Could be a much better beer with a few tweaks.
12oz Bottle cellared for about a year.  Pours nice hazy gold.  Thin head that recedes quickly.  Fruit aroma.  Slightly spicy with great mouthfeel.

4oz tester at Montr√©al Mondial 2011.  I¬íll rate it again when I¬íll get a few bottles but this is probably the smoother and pleasantly fruitier tripel I ever had.  Lots of cereals, lemony, no alchool.  Top of the line Tripel, for sure, and probably my favorite.

On tap at Redlight. Deep gold color with a small head. Aroma of tart fruits, apples, apricot. Very complex flavors of banana, wheat, apple, yeast and light hops. This was one of the more enjoyable beers I have had yet.

750 ml. Batch#170 Aroma- Spicy up front, a little peppery, some fruit Appearance-Hazy, light gold, Big, dense, rocky white head. Taste- Slight sweetness, peppery, spicy, medium high bitterness that you can lick on your lips. Dries out in the finish. Plenty of belgian phenols but not overpowering. Palte-Medium light fouth feel, creamy, but prickly with carbonation. Alcohol is very subtle.
This tasted like the background beer that all the expensive bombers where make from. The uneditted allagash.

Tap at Redlight. Pours a hazy gold. Funky tart apple and pear aroma. Not sweet in any sense, but a light aromatic fruitiness. Taste is smooth crisp malt with hints of tart apple and a touch of sweetness on the back end. Awesome.

Hazy golden yellow color with a dense white head. Good retention and quite a bit of Belgian lace. Aroma has lots of fruit including banana, pear, and citrus. Also a distinct Belgian yeast aroma and a subtle spiciness and malt sweetness.Very flavorful with fruits, yeast, and a nice amount of hops with floral and citrus notes. Honey notes come out with the finish. Very well-balanced. A wonderful tripel.

Pours a nice murky orance with a medium white head. The nose has quite a bit of tartness to it. Apples, belgian yeast and brett. Apples or pears in the front. Very balanced. Overall a pretty good beer

(Courtoisie de JulienHuxley)  La couleur du liquide embrouill√© est jaun√¢tre.  La t√™te mousseuse est petite mais solide.  De petites pointes de dentelles sont observ√©es.  Au nez, les fruits tropicaux et les √©pices permettent √† des effluves de moutarde de s¬í√©chapper.  Les saveurs sont plus int√©ressantes, disons moins d√©routantes, port√©es sur la douceur avec un sucr√© bien dos√©, une levure √©pic√©e et des soubresauts correctement fruit√©s.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence plut√¥t mod√©r√©e et une texture cr√©meuse.  La finale se fait principalement sur des notes fruit√©es qui deviennent ti√®des.  Vivement une autre bouteille pour comparer.
Slight hop presence. Honey flavor., with bitter finish. Quite good, but a little disappointing. Batch 160

Bouteille de 355ml d√©gust√©e avec Patrick. Cette triple est de belle couleur bl√©, elle est claire et la mousse est blanche. Le nez est surprenant en sentant la moutarde jaune. Une touche de houblon r√©ussie tout de m√™me √† traverser ce mur de moutarde. La bouche est particuli√®rement mince, elle est agr√©able, d¬íune bonne amertume la finale est s√®che. Elle me semble quelque peu vieillotte et sera √† reboire.

Batch 168.  Poured a very hazy yellow color with a white stable foamy head.  Aroma has lots of banana and yeast notes.  Other fruits as well.  Taste is very flavorful with fruit, yeast, and a good amount of hops.  Some interesting floral notes.  Finish has a touch of honey with lots of banana.  Overall very well balanced and flavorful.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Perhaps the best tripel I¬íve had so far!  Very good!

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Forms a nice small head, and develops into sticky lacing. The color is foggy yellow, perhaps with a hint of green. The smell is fantastic, formidable as it reaches about 55 degrees. There is the sweet scent of grapefruit, while a strong whiff reveals fig and perhaps raisins. The carbonation was light and smooth, which carried the sweetness well. The sweetness wasn¬ít extreme, but was rather soft like a banana (as everyone says) with a very slight tart. Towards the end the carbonation leaves a bit of spiciness, but not hinting the 9% abv. This abbey tripel is very good, and strikingly similar to some golden ales I¬íve had.

Bottle (#36) shared by footbalm, thanks 
Appearance: Slightly hazy yellow with a nice sized white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Dried fruit, banana, citrus and spices 
Taste: Sweet malts, fruity, banana and citrus 
OK

bottle; hazy yellow with moderate white head; aroma-yeast, floral, banana, spice; taste-light sweetness, medium long lasting bitterness, high cabonation, strong alcohol. Good beer, much better than their dubbel
Pours a hazy orange amber.  Aroma of dried fruits, banana, and cloves.  Flavor of passion fruit, citrus, spices.  Mild alcohol, and mild bitterness in the finsh.

Fantastic brew. Deep orangish yellow with a tight off white head. Very complex and well balanced. American in character (bigger and sharper) , but very belgian in the aroma and spice roster. A great hommage.

From the corked 25 ouncer from Batch #164.  The pour is a cloudy pale-yellow with a little olive look to it.  There is a lot of head on the pour and busy carbonation.  Strong aromas of passion fruit, sweetness, yeast, and malts. The body is around medium.  The higher ABV is barely noticeable in the taste, which is otherwise sweet through and through.  I like this one.

750Ml bottle.  This beer pours a dull cloudy yellow with a medium white head leaving some good lacing down the sides.  The aromas are lemon zest, dough and musk.  The mouthfeel is slightly sticky and sweet with a dryness on the backend.  The body is medium.  This was a very nice beer!  Cheers!

Pours hazy golden with frothy head.  Lots of bubbles.  Smell has lots of lemon and orange with Belgian yeast and nice sweet malts.  Taste is coriander with strong yeast and candy sugar.  Slight notes of honey, lemon, apple, and berries.  Crisp and light/medium bodied mouthfeel.  Lots of carbonation.  A bit light for a tripel but this is a wonderful beer.  The only downside is that it goes down too quickly.

A - Pours a bright hazy golden-orange color with a thick two fingers of frothy white head. The head retention is excellent with some very nice lacing left behind on the glass.

S - Aroma is full of citrus fruits (lemon and orange). Also some light Belgian yeast and some spices (coriander). Some sweet malt also comes through a bit.

T - Starts off with some sweet malt and some nice citrus fruit and coriander. Some yeast in the background from the start. Through the middle the transition is smooth to some heavier citrus/tropical fruit with some more yeast flavor. The finish is a mix of some nice sweet malt, some yeast, and a touch of bread that lingers very nicely. Excellent balance.

M - Medium-light to medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. Really smooth and crisp. Finish is nice and light feeling, but has some really nice lingering taste.

D - Very drinkable. For 9% abv, super drinkable. Flavor is very well balanced and excellent. Also looks amazing in the glass. Super refreshing and crisp.

Bomber of batch 164 Pours a cloudy golden yellow. Medium white head. Very tangy, citrus aroma with banna clove, great smell. Reminds me of summer. Great smooth mouth feel. Orange peel on the tongue and a touch of honey. I get the slight alcohol taste at the back of the tongue which leaves my mouth dry. Very subtle but vibrant flavors. I would buy another tomorrow! Worth every penny!

Banana, peach, funk, and lemongrass nose. Cloudy yellow full of floaties, medium white head. Medium body, but very low viscosity. Fruity and bitter at the same time. Grass, peach, whole orange, and funk flavors. Bready peach in the end. Alcohol downplayed. Solid tripel, nothing too extravagant, but well made and classical.

It pours a dark clear gold with tons of carbonation, you see it just oozing from the bottom. The color is much darker than your typical tripel. The head is about 2 fingers of very puffy white head with decent retention. The lacing is very nice and chunky.

The aroma is nothing special of note, you have your normal floral hoppiness. The smell is on the lighter side of things. 

The taste is very light and uninspiring. There is not much flavor hit except some flowery malts. Mouthfeel is light but its very drinkable.

Bottle at Allagash tasting/front office. Pours out a straw topped with a small white head. Aroma was banana, belg yeast, spice, light pit fruit, and some clove. Taste was just as the aroma with the belg yeast and bananas leading the way.

Pours a golden color with thin white head. Aroma of malts, yeast, fruit, spices. Flavor was pale malts, spices, hints of sweet fruit, and some wonderful hops to create a dry and lasting finish. Well done Tripel that compares well to the gold standard -- Chimay.

Hazy pale gold body beneath a two-finger frothy white head that reduced to a solid film and left very nice lace. Aromas of bananas and other tropical fruit, clove and other spice, and earthy yeast. Taste is similar, enhanced by a more pronounced hops bitterness that appears once the spices and fruits have settled. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, slight warmth from the alcohol, and a well-balanced finish.Very very nice.

Pours copper-yellow with white head.  Typical banana-clove esters abound with some fresh baked bread.  Taste is more of same with some soft nuttiness.  Decent carbonation lasting yeasty sweetness.  Very good.

12 oz bottle.

Pours into my tulip a hazy gold with hues of orange. the head is rocky and white and recedes to nice Belgian-styled lacing.

The smell is authentic, yeasty ad fruity with a little bit of spice. Smells like a Tripel should, a feat that most American brewers fail at.

The taste is more of a letdown. It is herbal and sweet with some spice and bitterness but this is too sweet and clean for a tripel, it is sterile, like other American versions.

The mouthfeel is a tad watery, drinkability is decent theough the alcohol isn¬ít completely unmasked.

It is a decent attempt.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-27-2010 20:48:57

22 oz bomber shared with friends. Pours a golden blond and produces a 2 inch high head. Lots of lacing. Aromas of citrus oranges, bananas  and belgium yeasts.  Tastes slightly  sweet coming from the roasted malts mixed with some alcohol presence. A very nice representation of a tripel. I would highly recommend this one!

Pours beautiful golden blonde with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet oranges, yeast and a little citrus.  Taste is sweet, malty, with orange and corriander.  Finish is somewhat short, but plenty complex, with a semi sweet, boozy end.  A good tripel.

Hazy golden yellow in the glass with a thin white head.  Aroma of yeasty spice, malt, and fruit.  Nice malty notes on the palate blend with a balanced hop presence.  Fine carbonation.  Medium-heavy mouthfeel.  Really well done, could easily compete with some of Belgium¬ís best.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a britt citrus golden color win a nice white head and some good lacing. Aroma brings spices, orange peel, and some fruity esters. Taste brings citrus zest and some fruit with a bot of breadm. Feel is medium with good carbonation. Drinks quite well. A nice American version.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010
golden hue color, frothy head, complex flavor can notice the fruits a very nice tripel indeed

Spicy, fruity aroma, one inch off white head. Pale yellow in appearance, very cloudy. The same spice comes through in the flavor. The alcohol flavor isn¬ít masked as well as in other tripels I¬íve tried. Fizzy in the mouth, sharp aftertaste.
(Batch # 162)  The 1000th rating of this beer!  True Belgian style from Maine.  Thick frothy white head  Traditional flavors.  Mildly sweet and malty.  Easy to enjoy and delicious .

Pour is a golden yellow color with a white head. Nose is of light flavors, noticeably honey and hops. Taste is refreshing and has some complexity; starting with bananas and honey then into a nice bitter hoppy finish.

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours opaque, golden with a thick, lacy, white head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, bananas, caramel, honey, and light hops.  Flavor about the same, strong on the Belgian yeast.  A little alcohol on the finish.  An awesome tripel.

Hazy yellow pour with a small white head. Head sticks around for a while and laces nicely. Smell is of Belgian yeast, candied sugar, and bananas.  A bit of orange, really interesting smell. Taste is sweet up front, the fruits, banana and orange. A warming boozy feeling persists throughout the entire drink. Light and crisp, very refreshing, with a nice warning of the ABV by the warming alcohol taste. If only I had access to more of it!
Pours beautifully with a nice white, foamy head. Color is golden and crisp - very indicative of its taste. Aftertaste is slightly unpleasant.

Great cloudy golden body with a thin creamy head. This has an excellent aroma with hint of alcohol. Kind of sharp on the palate, but not overwhelming. I do notice the hints of banana and it taste great. Overall a great Belgian tripel.

(Sample Date: 11/2/2010   Source:Maniac)   Allagash Tripel Reserve Batch 88 Caramel with spicy yeast character and a faint sourness in the aroma. Cloudy orange golden with a fluffy fine off-white head that persists. Earthy caramel sweetness with lots of earthy honey character and a faint woody sourness. Light body and mouthfeel. Finish is dry with a light earthy bitterness.
Earthy, herbal aroma.  Taste is a delicious banana, wheat, honey and some spiciness.  The aroma/taste interplay is excellent!  I must get a bottle and age it for a year or two!

750 ml bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow/gold with rocky, foamy white head. Aroma is GREAT! Notes of citrus, farmhouse, musty. Flavor is very much the same but bland down a bit with notes if malt, herbal, spicy, citrus peel and dirty bitter at the end. Mouth feel is light body with soft, fizzy carbonation. Overall, a very well made brew!

Very pale, hazy yellow beer, big fluffy head but not much lacing. Aroma is very subtle yeast with a dusty quality to it. Flavor is generally sweet, lots of lighter fruits, pear, apple, some citrus and a very yeasty finish--perhaps a bit too yeasty for this beer, but a very drinkable tripel.

Appearance: Pale orange, quite hazy. Small amount of white head.
Aroma: Lots of fruit, some citrus.
Taste: More fruit and citrus. Slight bitterness.
Info: 355ml bottle, 21/11-2010
Pours a light orange on tap with a light white head.  Aroma of alcohol. Flavor with a hint of coriander.
Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with frothy white head. Nose and taste of banana, clove, citrus, Belgian yeast, herbs and lemongrass.

pours cloudy yellow with a nice sudsy head.  Aroma is subtle honey, sweet bread.  Taste is classic Belgian triple but better than usual... sweat malt and Belgian yeast.  Very nice palate and finish, excellent tripel.

Slightly hazy gold, thin white head, creamy full body, medium-high carbonation.

Aroma: wheat tartness, belgian yeast esters, candy sugar, and stale hops.

Taste: pale malt, wheat tartness, belgian yeast, candy sugar, and quite a bit of stale hops.

Balanced and restrained -all the typical tripel elements are here, but none of them trying to steal the show.

Bottle shared by OleR. Cheers! Slightly hazy straw yellow, not much of a head, just a light ring of foam. Aroma of honey, caramel, light fruity. Pretty weak aroma. Very sweet, but carbonation and some bitterness balances it out nicely. It¬ís a bit.. flaccid for a tripel. Would have liked more flavour, more fruit, spice, more punch.Fairly sparkly carbonation, medium bodied. A lot of alcohol sweetness. Decent drink, fails as a tripel.
One of the best tripels I¬íve ever had. Shocked that a New England brewery made such a great example of the style.

Bottle @ the mondial de la bi√®re. A yellow beer with medium head. Smell is fruity and yeast like. Aroma is very fruity with wheat malt notes, near to Belgian style but more syrupy and sweet. Good beer just too much agrumes for me.

0.75L corked bottle brought home from √òlkonsortiet, Aalborg.  Low blond top. Foggy, deep gold to pale amber colored body. Low aroma level. Vinous. Sappy. Notes of dust and earth. Solid malt body. Slightly sweet and rounded.
Notes of mellow, over-ripe fruits and mild spices. Light-bodied and soft in the mouth. Vinous ending. A decent Tripel, but suffers from a slight oxidation and lack some sharp- and freshness.

A-pours a pale golden yellow with lots of haze and a creamy white head with a nice lace left behind.

S-the nose is very sweet, light yeast notes with citrus and peach coming in behind.  hints of spicy phenol and light peppery alcohol.

T-the taste is much of the same, rather sweet golden fruits with light spice and yeast surrounding.  peaches and appricots with hints of alcohol and pepper.

M-medium syrupy body, smooth throughout, finish is crisp and lively with assertive carbonation.  very little driness in the finish.

D-decent beer, doesn¬ít have the things i like in a tripel.  little to no spice and light on the yeast.  finish isn¬ít as dry as i¬íd like to see.  tasty and sweet but not sugary at all.

650 ml bottle. Pours a hazy light golden yellow with a large fluffy white head. Aroma is very floral and malty, nice soft graininess with a touch of citric sharpness and some sweet honey and light fruitiness. Flavor is very well balanced, sweet yet softly tart, nice bready malt note with a touch of spiciness that round out the mouthfeel. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Really well rounded and refreshing beer.

750ml Bottle. Poured a cloudy straw / gold with a medium head. Aroma: yeast, fresh fruit, citrus zest, lots of spice, banana, passing notes of alcohol. Taste carries out the aroma: big but mellow. Medium body. Long finish. Overall: Excellent - great depth & balance.

Small offwhite head. Hazy deep yellow body. Milky papery alcoholic apple aroma, fairly light. Dry-sweet strawy oily toffee and earth taste with papery notes. Full-bodied. Sharpish mouthfeel. Dry toffeeish resiny fruity aftertaste with papery earthy notes. A bit dense and lifeless, but lots of flavour, and some freshness. (0.75l bottle shared by Ole_R.)

75cl bottle. Batch 95. Slightly hazy golden colour with s small white head. Oxidized with notes of apples, yeast. Sweet. Flavour is sweet and slightly bitter at the same time. Yeasty and malty. Notes of apples and bananas.¬†Medium long aftertaste.
Golden/light amber color, fine white head. Aroma is yeast, spices, banana. Flavor is the same, with notes of alcohol. Smooth and very nice.

750ml bottle. Thanks to Serg for the bottle... Pours a golden hazy yellowish hue with a thin to medium soapy white head... Yeasty right off of the bat with sweeter honey and a light spice. Really bready and sweet overall... Sweet honey center coinciding with bananas and some light spice and also some residual sweetness. Doughy. Well carbonated and accompanying body.

Pours a light hazy golden color with  a good size head that disappears slowly as you drink.  The aroma is not my favorite part of this beer, as this beer smells a bit like a wheat beer.  However, the flavor is slightly eggy with hints of citrus and has a bit of  a sweet taste.  The beer is light in the mouth with immediate tiny bubbles.  Overall, this is a very good beer with a nicely balances flavor and a good feel in the mouth.

Pours clear orange with lasting white head, aroma is floral, bread, biscuit, touch of honey.  Taste is better with some sweet biscuit, caramel, up front leading into honey, tropical fruit, some banana, and a hint of spice at then end with a dry finish.  Awesome taste for a tripel.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 This is quite nice but I can¬ít put my finger on what is a little strange about this.  I¬íll have to try again. Serving: Tap
Cloudy pale orange. Fat white, mostly-dissipating head. Faint aroma of spice. Flavor is missing something... a bit like a tripel meets macro-brew.
Pouirs a deep foggy and golden yellow, nose is peaches and fresh biscuit, taste is rich with candy sugars, floral hops, and an earthy finish.

Bomber of batch 155. Pours a cloudy golden yellow. Medium white head. Very tangy, citrus aroma with banna clove, great smell. Great smooth mouth feel. Definitely get passion fruit on the tongue, and a touch of honey. I get the slight alcohol taste at the back of the tongue. Very subtle but vibrant flavors. Every bit worth the $9.99 U.S I paid for it.

Brown bottle, 750 ml, batch 154, purchased at Bangor Wine and Cheese on August 17 2010, savoured on September 5 2010; eye: golden with a whitish hue, turbid, good effervescence, nice ring of white head, light lacing; nose: yeast, clove, coriander, alcohol, citrus; mouth: yeast, clove, coriander, alcohol, citrus, dry and rather short finale in alcohol with presence of citrus-spices, full body, rather carbonated, fizzy texture; overall: not for me

FRAN√áAIS

Bouteille brune, 750 ml, lot 154, achet√©e chez Bangor Wine and Cheese le 17 ao√ªt 2010, savour√©e le 5 septembre 2010; ¬úil : dor√©e avec une teinte blanch√¢tre, trouble, bonne effervescence, bon anneau de mousse blanche cr√©meuse, l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : levure, clou de girofle, coriandre, alcool, citron; bouche : levure, clou de girofle, coriandre, alcool, citron, finale s√®che et plut√¥t courte en alcool avec pr√©sence de citron-√©pices, cors√©, plut√¥t carbonat√©e, texture p√©tillante; en r√©sum√© : bien bon

Finally got around to ticking this ol¬í classic.  750ml bottle, corked n¬í caged, from Chip¬ís in Kill Devil Hills, NC.  Pours a beautiful clear golden - well hazy when you get to the bottom of the bottle - with a large lasting white head.  The aroma is nicely fruity with tropical notes, Belgian yeast, honey, and spice.  Very, very nice.  The flavor is also excellent, slightly Americanized but I think this actually helps it.  Sweet pale malts and honey, banana, spice, passion fruit, mango, Belgian yeast, and orangey hops.  Medium-full bodied with somewhat prickly carbonation and a great smoothness to it.  Really excellent example of the style.  Thoroughly enjoyable.  I killed most of the 750 myself.
Pale gold with big frothy head. Honey and fruit aromas. Sweet up front with a crisp dry finish. Nice american style tripel.

750ml bottle. golden pour. nice frothy head. herbal, sweet malts, notes of honey in the aroma. taste was similar to aroma, sweeter malts, honey sweetness, light herbal qualities. fuller mouthfeel. solid tripel
Bottle pours an unclear orange/yellow beer with a tiny white head. Scent is bread and coriander. Taste is sweet citrus, bread and coriander. Dry finish.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2010 Pours a fairly clear blonde with a big, foamy white head. Nose is fairly standard tripel, with sweet fruit, candied sugar, and a touch of spice and hops in the background. Flavor is very soft without a particularly specific-flavored sweet malt and a decent kick of bitter citrus and bittering hops that come out fast and linger the whole way. The finish is a bit on the spicy side too. This tripel has less "personality" than I ideally want but is definately a good brew.

Bomber of batch 151.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow.  Medium white head.  Very tangy, citrus aroma, great smell.  Great smooth feel.  Definitely get passion fruit on the tongue, and a touch of honey.  Very subtle but vibrant flavors.  Wonderful beer!

Had a bottle from Batch #158.  Medium carbonation.  golden yellow in color.  Lots of fruit on the nose.  Tastes of orange peel, apple, maybe some nuts.  Some alcohol in the finish, but disguised by some light hop flavor.  very well balanced!
Clear light hazy yellow pour with white.  Sweet clove and vanilla nose.  Flavor has a lightly bitter hop profile with more clove.  Not as good as I had hoped.  But not bad.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a large frothy white head.  Nose is sweet, spicy, and fruity with some banana and golden raisins, yeast, and just a hint of hops.  Starts fairly sweet up front.  Medium bodied, big hit of spice along with a light fruitiness.  Earthy yeast figures prominently.  The finish is dry with just a slight hoppy bitterness and lingering fruit and spice notes.  Very nice tripel.

Light golden and cloudy with small head.  Subtle aroma with spices.  Full body, alcohol is present but not prominent.  Some spices and tropical fruit and yeasty flavors, a little bit sweet but not too much.  Solid.

Pours a hazy golden color with a lasting, thick, white head leaving nice lacing.  Sweet, sour dough, some citrus, spice and raisins in the aroma. Nice creamy mouthfeel with good carbonation.  Taste is sweet, yeasty, and earthy.  Some alcohol at the finish. I really enjoyed this beer.
Bottle # 148 at Best Western city view NYC. Hazy piss yellow body with a medium white foamy head. Aroma is fruit, passion, pine. Nice tripel.

Bottle at Kevin¬ís Surprise Party. Pours a hazy, orange-gold with a huge, fluffy white head. Strong, phenolic aroma with enticing notes of banana, yeast and clove. Flavor is very sweet but not cloying, with more fruits, wheat and yeast. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a very smooth texture. Finishes bready and sweet with light bitterness. Delicious. This is a wonderful Tripel.

Poured into a pint glass.

A: Cloudy, yeasty golden. Rich head that falls to a quarter finger, but then remains. Very dense lacing.

S: Complex. Fruity (citric, plum) then herbal. Hints of spice. More sweet than hoppy.

T: This is one spicy beer. Spicy foremost, then citric and pine. Chewy yeast is very apparent. Next is a grassy, earthy undertone. Hops are not the focus of this beer. They instead play a support role to bring out the best in the malt mix.

M: Medium body with a good balance between creaminess and carbonation. Warming sensation at finish.

D: Good bee. A sipper that is not to be fooled around with.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-12-2008 21:23:31

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 Bottle pour to Trappist glass.  Medium amber clear with think white head that fades rapidly.  Aroma tart, light fruits, yeast.   Taste citrus, light fruits, a little sweetness, tartness.  Finish dry.  Palate medium, carbonated.

So many tripels out there.  To me this is just OK and I prefer a little sweeter and less dry.  Good tripel but really depends what you are looking for.

Yellow, effervescent, clear. Nice clean tripel smell. Crisp candy sugar, Belgian yeast... Not too overpowering, with a subtle hop presence
Flavours are quite sweet initially, then evening out at the end. A good amount of alcohol on the finish. I like this tripel, but not as much as others.

Pours golden, fizzy white head. Aroma ticks all the tripel boxes - candi sugar, cloves, herbaceous. Not particularly intense.
Rich, full body honeyish sweetness. Bitterness is upfront and fades into herbaceous clovey belgianness.
I like my tripels to be a bit dryer, but still very nice.
Batch # 136. Very beautiful golden beer with a thick head. Light yeasty aroma. A bit of grassy hops, quite bitter for a tripel, very clean. Aged ~1 year.

Sample from bottle. Hazy gold pour with thick pillowy white head. Aroma is bready, some yeast, lots of lemon zest and alcohol. Taste is sweet up front with the alcohol nicely cutting it off into a slightly bitter finish. Palate is very full and lively. Nothing original here, just a great example of the style (that some argue isn¬ít one).

Pours rich bright orange with a foamy beige head with good retention. Aroma of honey, brown sugar, bread, yeast sourness, lots of fruit and berries. Taste has lots of malt again with some citrus and lots of dark fruit and berries again. Very well balanced, very flavorful but not overly sweet. Smooth medium texture, soft carbonation.
On tap at Collins. Golden with off-white head and clings. Standard Belgian aromas of bubblegum, clove and yeast. Tastes of candy sugar, dough, mild spice, slight pepperyness.
Has a clear transparent yellow color to it with very little foam around the rim. The aroma and taste is spicy with a bitter after taste, but it¬ís awesome.
750 ml bottle. Batch 136. Light golden yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of lemon and yeast. Flavor is similar with a surprisingly nice honey sweetness.

Fat Cat, West Village pint on tap ($9): Pours a hazy lemon yellow with a nice frothy Belgian head (although my head was not quite as large as it could have been seeing as the bartender decided to up the quantity of beer and minimize the foam). Strong fruity aroma: banana, passionfruit, even some citrus in there. Spicy as well. A portent for the upcoming sweetness and complexity. Upon tasting it, the beer is ever so slightly sweet with some proper hop presence. High alcohol covered by the layers of fruity flavor. As the commercial description boasts, the finish is indeed very long. All in all, this is a very proper tripel. I could probably drink 3 or 4 of these without noticing... (except it would impact my wallet).

Had from bottle from BevMo.  Batch No. 144.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with large, thick head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy - fruity and yeasty with lots of herbs and spices.  Taste is overwhelmed by spices.  Also very sweet with sugar and herbs at the finish.  A dry, astringent aftertaste lingered.  I had higher hopes, but thought the spices completely took this beer over and were way too pronounced.

Pours an opaque golden hue with minimal white head.  Nose is banana and clove.  Flavor matches the nose, along with some belgian yeast and a bit of citrusy hops that give the impression of orange peel or lemon zest.  Very spicy, and the mouthfeel is fizzy and full.  One of the better triples I¬íve had.  Can¬ít decide whether I prefer it to La Fin Du Monde.

Pours a hazy yellow, good bit of dense white foam that sticks around a while. Aroma is yeasty, fruity (some banana in there), and spicy - cloves, maybe. Taste: very carbonated and fizzy, lots of fruit and citrus, lots of nice spices like cloves and nutmeg. This is the best tripel I¬íve ever had, including some Trappist ones too.

Bottle. Slightly hazy light orange pour with a very white head. Nose is yeast, fruit, and clove. Mouthfeel is slightly creamy, somewhat carbonated. Taste is Belgian yeast, fruity, and subtle banana. Very good tripel.
A drink this beer pretty often. A hint of creamy light vanilla flavor and a little hoppy.

Tripel Reserve Belgian Style Ale Batch # 65--2005 25.4 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV.  15 IBU¬ís?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--GoldenTripel.  2 @ $8.59 Each.  Lacy foamy white head.  Cloudy bright gold color.  Loose sediment.  Mellow Belgian wheat ester passion fruit front.  Cloying creamy crisp mild banana honey sweet complex rich smooth body.  Long-- Mildly spicy pepper hot refreshing rich smooth tasty end.  Sampled 1/10/2009.
Pours a nice cloudy golden color, with a medium head.  Tastes of some fruits and a bit of spice.  Very smooth and flavorful.  ABV was not dominant.

Golden honey colored cloudy pour white head aroma of herbs, belgian yeast and sweet fruits...... taste of honey, banana, sweet fruits and some spice .... has a light spicy finish .... a very easy drinking enjoyable tripel ... no trace of the abv at all and all the flavors are balanced none are overbearing
750ml - Bready yeast aroma with white pepper and tropical fruit.  Flavor of banana and mango, spicy yeast and a touch of citrus hops.  Palate is tangy and spicy.  Nice American tripel.

Pours a cloudy yellow-straw into the glass, with a large 4-finger head that reduces to a soapy cap that leaves chunky lace.  The nose is heavy of spices (pie predominant) and a hint of yeast strain.  The flavors come together integrated quite well, of fruit, yeast, pie spices (adding a nice contrasting dryness to the overall texture), and finishes with dry spicing and a hint of alcohol warmth (not in a fusel way).  The ABV is excellently integrated, however.  The mouthfeel is smooth, not quite creamy, with subtle carbonation and a round body.  A very nice tripel from Allagash, and a superb Belgian-style offering.

750(batch 149)->tulip: Pours a huge, white, frothy head that exhibits excellent lacing atop a murky light amber body.  Aroma of sweet malt and perhaps that of candy and ginger that is very pleasant.  Thin bodied, astringent in taste, with a long duration of flavor, ending sweetly on the palate.  A very light beer for its class and ABV.  This is the kind of beer that could get someone in trouble quickly, especially considering its light palate and high alcohol.  A beer to be enjoyed and respected.

I¬íve had this 12oz for almost a year, and I¬ím glad I let it age. It¬ís far more subtle and refined as an older beer than a young one. Big yeast in the nose, light honey and apricots in the taste, and a long dry abv finish. A fine example of an American interpretation of a Belgian tripel.

A- beautiful champagne body with thick foamy white head. Head fades to be smaller and plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- alcohol, yeast, and spices.

T- Taste has banana, Belgian sugar, yeast spices, and an overtone of alcohol. FInish is quite dry leaving a slight alcohol afterburn.

P- nice smooth body with medium carbonation.

O- the alcohol is very present in this brew. Not a bad thing but it decreases the drinkability of it. Its one that I will probably have again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 07-03-2007 04:21:16

Corked bomber. Appearance is a bright peach golden with foamy white head. Excellent lacing around the glass. Aroma is spicy yeast, apricot, cranberry and grapes. Taste begins with spicy dough and cloves followed by toasted malt and honey sweetness. There¬ís also some caramel, banana and burnt sugar flavors in the background. It finishes fruity and toasty with a warm alcohol finish. Mouthfeel is deceptively smooth and refreshing with a perfectly balanced level of carbonation. Excellent balance between the fruit, yeast and sugar flavors. More than holds its own against the Belgian Tripels I¬íve tried.

Light brown in color with no sediment, good carbonation, and a large foamy white head. The actual beer was also a lot more cloudy in appearance than some other Tripels I¬íve had. The smell is of pine, herbs, trees, bitterness, and flowers. Not as strong as an aroma but more complex than some others. Taste is of bitter hops that leads straight into a pine tree aftertaste, with little to no hint of alcohol at all. A bit watery, but not too bad. Kind of weak, but still good.

750ml bottle, Batch 139, from Central Market in Plano.  Pours a hazy, dirty blond body topped with a large, fluffy, off-white head that leaves some lacing.  Aromas of yeast, spicyness (almost peppery), and fruity esters.  Flavor is a very good balance of light candi sweetness, yeast, fruityness, spices and just a hint of floral hops in the finish.  Medium to full mouthfeel with lively carbonation.  Hard to believe I had passed this one up for so long.

Pours a hazy orange-gold color.  Thick white head with very nice retention and lacing.  Aroma is yeast, coriander and spice.  Flavor is very spicy, with hints of peppercorn and clove.  Some Belgian candi sugar and banana sweetness.  Medium finish with notable alcohol burn.  A little more spice bite than I like in the style (not right or wrong, just personal preference) but a very nice beer.

This is one of the best tripels that i have ever had. The aroma is very sweet and spicy. The beer pours cloudy yellow with a nice light head. The taste is super smooth and has a great mouthfeel. I wish all Tripels could be this good.

The beer pours a cloudy yellow-orange color with a white head. This is a really good looking beer. The aroma is Belgian yeast, citrus orange and lemon. The flavor is yeast, citrus fruits, light alcohol and peppery spices. The alcohol mixes well with the peppery spices. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pours golden with a big foamy white head. Flavor is sugar sweetness with spice a decent hop profile. Not a typical tripel but still very good.

Pours a pale yellow with a thick appearance. Head is thin, but persists as does the great carbonation and lacing. Aroma is doughy with a banana and cider undertone. Excellent hops and fine malts make this a wonderful Tripel. Not overly sweet, but delicately balanced.

750 ml bottle from Keller¬ís IGA, batch #136.  Pours a cloudy pale golden color with an inch-thick white head that leaves some soapy lacing behind.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, lemon citrus, honey, clove, bready malts, tropical fruits, and banana.  Flavor of Belgian yeast, lemon citrus, honey, bread, spices (mostly clove and pepper), straw, malt, and just a bit of alcohol.  Dry, peppery finish.  Medium-bodied, with above-average carbonation with a crisp mouthfeel.  Some lingering spice, yeast, and alcohol in the finish.  Really nice tripel.

Bottle.  Aroma of yeast and spice.  Golden body with foamy, lasting head.  Flavor is smooth with hints of honey, banana, citrus, spice and hops.  The alcohol content is very well hidden as this Tripel is light and refreshing.

[2633-20091205] Cask. Mild paint-thinner yeast aroma has notes of pencil lead. Slightly hazy, light orange brown body with a quick foamy white head. Heavy pencil lead yeast flavour. Medium-full body. Interesting.
(@ Coles, Buffalo, NY)
pours hazy and golden. nice aroma of fruit and spices.  taste some banana, not too sweet.  excellent finish, really lingers on the palate.

Amazing American beer that reminds my untrained taste to Chimay Blue.  High alcohol content provides some bite similar to an IPA.  I¬ím new to this ratings process--but I know Allagash is now one of my favorite beers.
Golden yellow pour from bottle.  Creamy, white head with fruits and spices on the nose.  Medium mouthfeel with a nice warmness to it.  Very well done.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a yellow gold cloud, with nice white head, good lacing, very nice pour, though head eventually fades to thin film.  Aroma of honey, banana, clove, other spices, white grape, fruit.  Taste is quite complex, with indeed a very long finish.  First a warm spicy fruitiness, with yeast detectable, tropical fruits to crisp yet soft spices, finish develops from fruit to dryness.  Very soft, nice mouthfeel, this one is just really nice.

On tap at Taco Mac.Yellow cloudy color.Nice sweet citrus aroma that leads to a creamy citrus mouth.Well rounded tripel that goes down esy and packs an admirable punch!I liked this beer and give kudos the the Allagash boys on this one.

Bottle.  Golden yellow pour with frothy head.  Dried fruit, citrus, nuts, spice, dark berry, banana bread and Belgium yeast on the nose.  Citrus, sweet fruit, spice, bread, and complex but balanced finish.

Pours golden yellow with a thick frothy white head and sparkles of carbonation. The nose is banana, clove, honey, bubble gum, Belgian yeast, and white grapes. The taste is similar with a murky yeast taste in the back. The lacing is minimal. Great tripel!

750ml bottle, batch #147, from grape & gourmet. pours a beautiful, bright, yellow gold with a thick, bubbly white head and a lasting ring of lace. aroma is excellent with bright, lemony citrus, banana bread, clove, nutmeg, and cinnamon spice notes, and light, toasty, belgian yeast with unique hints of cherry, cedar, and dark rum. flavor is delicious as well light, lemony citrus notes up front backed by sweeter notes of tropical fruit and melon, belgian spice, yeast, and dry, toasty malts leading to a dry, slightly herbal, finish. palate is medium bodied with bright, bubbly carbonation and not a hint of the 9%abv. overall, an excellent example of the tripel style that is quickly growing on me.

My wife made steamed mussels in white wine broth, so I decided to finally try this beer. Overall, a very tasty tripel. I¬íve been drinking a lot of trippels lately (Weyerbacher, Victory, Russian River), but this tasted more like St. Bernadus¬í Tripel than any of these. Nice foamy head and pale golden color. Had some nice fruity aromas. Paired very nicely with the seafood.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2012 Pours a beautiful cloudy golden yellow hue with a mountainous layer of head. As I excitedly lift the glass to my nose a fresh lemony zest is revealed followed by a spicy yeast aroma. Tripels are a delicate breed that when made right can taste magnificent. That¬ís just want this is. The palate is soft and light on the tongue, but bursting with flavors of peppery spice, bananna, pinaplle, and a complexity of yeast notes.

one of the best beers ive ever had, the first taste reminded me of their white beer, spices and all, with a little more abv kick to it. cloudy golden color, good fluffy white head, this brewery really knows how to make delicious versions of belgian beers. if  i put this next to chimay cinq cents, i would still have to chose this, excellent.

On draught at South Park Tavern.  Tulip glass.  Poured yellow/orange, depending on the lighting of the bar.  I could taste strong butter and floral flavors.  Not allot of alcohol flavor for the ABV %.  Decent beer.

( 750ml) Pours cloudy orange with nice head and lacing. Nose of cherries, bready yeast, rum raisins, and other fruits. Taste of spicy yeast,, bread, and a very well carbonated, dry creamy finish.

Honestly one of my favorite tripels and nearly as good as any true Belgian tripel.
Nice Blond Color.  The white head is thick and lasts for a long time.  Notes of banana bread, slight citrus, and maybe cloves.  High carbonation.  Had it on draft so it was very clean.

(12 oz. bottle into trappist)  Poured a light cloudy orange with a small head.  The initial nose was of a general sweetness with a little hint of pepper and citrus and as it sat, banana.  The flavor was at first heavily of the spice but the slight banana did develop in the mouth afterward.  The alcohol was well masked at first, but as the glass went on, you could feel it warming you up and the sharpness of the alcohol came forward strong to the front of the palate.  Would have been MUCH better had the alcohol stayed in the back longer, but this is not terrible either.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 Cool in a pint glass.  Pours a nice golden color with quite a bit of yeast cloudiness.  Leaves a thick white head that lasts quite some time for a high alcohol brew. There is a big yeast aroma and lots of baking bread and banana tones. The taste has a lot of yeast and banana with some citrus  in the background. The alcohol is masked well but you notice the warming some.  The mouth feel is better than I expected and leaves a nice lingering taste.  Once it warms some there is a slightly off taste that diminishes the overall package.  Its a good tripel  but slightly overrated, in my opinion.

A: Poured with an average-sized, white head that gradually diminished to 1/2-finger. Body is dark yellow and hazy.

S: Very nice aroma... strong with orange and other citrus smells, with some light yeast.

T: Lots of fruit in the flavor, and again the yeast is lurking, but not too prevalent. Finishes slightly bitter, almost an astringent taste to it.

M: Medium-bodied and creamy, with lively carbonation.

D: A solid tripel, which is no less than what I would expect from Allagash.
Also enjoyed on a lake with my friend from Troue du Diable, in the future I look forward to putting a couple of these down to cellar.

Beautiful golden/orange with creamy and rocky beige head which lasts and laces well. Aroma of pears, caramel, and oranges. Silky mouthfeel. Notes of oranges, peaches, and a herbal background note, with alcohol coming through, but in a warming way, not at all harsh. Delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2014 Refigerated big bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a little orange with some head that disapears fairly quickly.  Nice lacing.  The taste is citrus (tone is mostly orange and some passion fruit), floral, and some spice.  The best triple I have had.
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2010 Batch #135.  Had the great balance of a great belgium blonde.  Very clean finish, even with the high alcohol content.  Citrus notes, great on the palate.

750ml bottle batch #21 (cellared 6yrs).  Pours a great golden orange color with a huge creamy white head that leaves a great lace.   The nose is full of fruit and yeast at first, with notes of spiciness as the beer warms.  The taste was delightfully smooth beginning malty sweetness, fruity and yeasty in the middle and ending with a tart, citrus bitterness.  Alcohol makes its presence known in the finish, but is surprisingly subdued for the higher alcohol.  Full bodied with a full but crisp mouthfeel.  Delicious.

Brother Jeff brought this from CA to CO for our reunion. Felt is was just a good, traditional Belgium. Immediately good, some sour, some bitter, very bubbly put dissipates fast and with it the beer seems to lose something. Still nothing I would ever turn down.

Smooth eggshell colored foam sits on a dark golden yellow bottle.  After falling there is a full sheet of foam retained on the glass.  A fruity spicy aroma with just a bit of alcohol noticeable.  Bright fruits, pears and pineapple with lots of cloves mixed in.  Taste is more fruits, passion fruit, pineapple, pears, floral honey, lots of spicing, alcohol spicing, no heat though.

Bouteilles de 750 ml et 12 oz, au Bi√®res et Bouffe. Ar√¥mes de levure fruit√©e et √©pic√©e, notes de c√©r√©ales. Robe blonde p√¢le, l√©g√®rement trouble. La bi√®re provenant de la bouteille de 750 ml est nettement plus gaz√©ifi√©e et appara√Æt plus s√®che. Tr√®s bien √©quilibr√©e, la levure fruit√©e et √©pic√©e est accompagn√©e de belles notes de c√©r√©ales. Finale l√©g√®rement am√®re de houblon herbal. L¬íalcool est tr√®s bien dissimul√©.

750ml bottle at a tasting. POurs hazy yellow with medium fluffy head. Nose is fruity and a bit dusty. Very fruit. Taste is big yeast with some spices (cloves or cinnamon maybe). Overall very fruity and very nice.
29th August 2008. Cloudy amber beer. Smooth frothy creamy malt followed by peach and bananas. Dry creamy malt finish. Very smooth and superior tripel.

750ml Bottle from Champanes, sampled in a tulip glass, 

has a orange pour with some darker orange and yellow hues, there is a little haze from the fine particles in the brew, decent effervescence, produced a creamy white head that hangs around and leaves white bubbled lacing on the glass, 

aromas of fresh orange and pear fruit, orange skin, citrus, faint floral and spice notes, pale malt, faint light fruit and white sugar sweetness,

flavors of bright light fruit ¬ñ orange and lemon with flavor of pale malt, and has spice, tartness and pepper at the finish, and is dry at the  finish,

mouth feel is light, less than medium, creamy, a touch of alcohol warmth with each sip after the ale warmed up a bit,

this Tripel has a good presentation, nice nose and flavors, a very good beer.

~Spicy scent, clove, white pepper, orange, pear, and some bannana. 
~Pours a cloudy orange with creamy white head.
~Spicy peppery flavor with clove, honey and lemon.
~Medium bodied, sweet finish.
~Excellent trippel!
0.75l - Nice head, good cloudy gold color.  Yeast on nose, mainly mint on palate.  I liked it.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours hazy wheat-tinged golden, with a tall, solid, creamy white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, honey, barley, and hints of banana. Medium bodied, but very crisp and satisfying. Moderate finish. Decent tripel.Earlier Rating: 9/6/2009 Total Score: 3.7Bottle. Drank this one with Sean and Vin. Pours murky orange with a white, tall head. Aroma of spice and malts and yeast. Heavy body, with a strong finish. Great American tripel.
Bottled and available all over town. Might have had on tap at Uber as well. Lots of flavors here swirling around.

750ml bottle poured into a Sam Adams Sensory glass produced a thick, foamy, off-white head and light amber body.  Reminded me of Leffe.  Citrus and spice dominated the flavor with hints of grapes and honey.

Corked bottle from BevMo.  The hazy, orange-hued body of straw sparkles, topped with a huge head of eggshell that fades to a sheath and coats the glass.  Spicy aroma with clove, coriander, sugary malts, light fruits, a wisp of lemon, a perfrume-like fragrance of a floral base (like gardenia).  Mouthfeel is medium-full with gentle carbonation and a fairly dry finish.  Flavor is crisp with citrus, lemon, straw, coriander, and a long, balanced finish that dries the mouth.  Hints of wood, esters, white grape.

This bomber pours a cloudy golden yellow/orange with a thin white head.  Aroma of yeast and fruit.  Taste is of sweet bread, vanilla, honey and a subtle malt, followed by undertones of fruit, especially citrus and banana.  Started with pouring two-thirds of the botlle and finished with the last third to get the full effect of the yeast.  This is a very impressive Tripel and one I would like to locate again

Started out not so good, i think the bottom half is the best part. Thats the problem with large bottles. Hazy yellow color with orange hints. White head that disappears quickly. Aroma of coriander, banana, vanilla, and yeast. Spicy flavor with banana, bread, and vanilla dominant. Very nice beer!

750ml bottle. Slightly hazy gold/amber color with a decent head that dissipates relatively quickly. Typical abbey yeast smell and taste with an overall taste that isn¬ít overly sweet for a tripel and quite easy to drink for being 9% as well. A good tripel and representation of the style.

Pours hazy light gold with some white head.  Aroma was mostly yeast with a bit of sweet banana.  Nice carbonation and body.  Tastes sweet with honey and coriander. This is an excellent beer from a great brewing company.

12 oz bottle. Orange hue color, slightly cloudy, small head which faded quickly. The banana and yeast aromas follow on by a palate flavor to match the aroma. Mildly sweet and easily drinking beer for a 9% er. Glad to find this in 4 packs as the big 750ml bottles hardly fit in our fridge....

12 oz bottle thanks to my friend Leems. Poured out a yellow-orange with a fluffy white head and light lacing. Aroma was banana, pepper, coriander, yeast. Flavor was very fruity: banana, apple, kiwi and some yeast and spice. Very nicely done tripel which I would absolutely drink again.
Bottle from Sams in Chicago. Hazy orange pour with a very small head. Aroma of apples/bananas. Tastes of oranges, bananas, apples, citrus fruits. Champagne like. Quite a tasty tripel.

Poured from a bomber,  The head quickly dissipates leaving a llovely thin light tan foam.  The nose conjures up banana beard tinged with kiwi, sans the nuts.  The palate shows a nice balance of sweetness and bitterness (nice hops.)  One very lovely domestic tripel.
UPDATED: SEP 25, 2009 An unclear orange beer with no head. Aroma was nice fruity, & pepper. The taste is very smooth fruity with the alcohol hidden very well. A very nice tripel.
Hazy yellow color with orange hints.  White head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of coriander, banana, vanilla, and yeast.  Spicy flavor with banana, bread, and vanilla dominant.  Very nice beer!

Bottle.  Pours a large, pitted, creamy white head.  Clingy.  Hazy yellow body.  Lemon-citrus aroma with coriander, light vanilla and bread.  Crisp pale malt flavor, more Belgian spice, smooth wheat malt.  Moderate (too much for me) alcohol is distracting and detracting.  Light, crisp body.  Lots of alcohol that lingers.  Overall this beer has lots of potential, but the abundant alcohol distracts.

12 oz bottle.  Cloudy yellow-golden with a heavy lacing, meringue-sparkling white head.  Heavy coriander nose with light grain and lemon.  Taste is startingly boozy without the burn, heavy vanilla with some wheat and grain.  Dryish with heavy booze on the aftertaste, but again, it¬ís gentle and only warms the chest.  Might be better with food.  Burp revealed a nice rush of citrus (sort of kiwi-mango) that wasn¬ít previously present in the mouth.  Misses the mark, wide right.

Pours from the brown 22oz. "bomber" bottle marked batch #134 a stunningly beautiful golden hue, a cloudy, slightly orange color that is almost too pretty to drink. Of course, the standard large foamy Belgian head fills almost half the tulip glass, with a pillar of carbonation rising from the center of the glass where the stem meets the bowl. The aroma is of sweet citrus fruit, candy & sugar. 1st sip is of sweet candied citrus fruit (orange, lemon, tangerine) peel & honey, followed by a surprisingly dry, white wine-like finish. The citrus peel flavor reappears on the swallow & lingers tantalizingly afterwards. There is a champagne sparkle on the tongue. Drinkability is off the charts...it should almost be against the law for a 9% abv beer to go down this smoothly & easily. Overall...wow, Wow, WOW!!! This is about as good as it gets in the beer world!!!
Batch #133. The nose is really spicy with notes of clove, but light, and vanilla. Pours a hazy golden with white head. Flavor has notes of grapefruit, coriander and bananas. Has a bitter finish.

750mL courtesy of my main man and super Texan, Cavie!   Pours big hazy orange like a Belgian white.  The aroma is light but hints of esters, malt, and orange peel.  The flavor is much stronger and is big esters, tangy oranges, and spicy malt.  The mouthfeel is high carbonation and medium body. This baby is way too smooth for a tripel.

Source: Extra in trade from Ray

Appearance: Dark straw, golden, with 3 fingers white head.

Aroma: Bananas, apple, nice.

Flavor: Fruity, off-dry. Pretty nice.

Palate: Medium carbonation.

Overall: Tasty tripel. Like it a little drier but solid brew.

Great Pac NW Hwy 101 Family/Beer Trip 2009
Aroma: Nice Belgian yeast and malt aroma nice candy fruitiness.  
Appearance: Dark Golden yellow in color, Clear with a light head.  
Flavor: Nice Belgian triple lots of fruit flavors spices and wonderful yeast.   
Palate: Dry  Belgian Finish, with a Great Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Tasty triple this was a wonderful beer.

750ml bottle, batch 133, sparkling golden color, with a thick creamy white head, leaving a curtain of lacing, yeasty, fruity, spicy nose of ripe apples, pears, light candied lemon peels and coriander, with some honeyed pale, toasted malt notes, and a candy sugar, hint of honey sweetness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, fruity, stewed, ripe apple, pear, nice honeyed pale malt, doughy character, with some candied lemon peel, coriander spicy flavors, with a sweet candyish sugar note, and a hint of vanilla bean accent, leading towards a sweet malty, honeyish, candyish, lingering hop bitterness finish.
Batch #134, poured an amber color with a foamy white head, fruity/yeasty aroma with a decent bitter finish.

Tasted at brewery.  Hazy golden color, creamy head.  Aroma is intoxicating, I want to say I smell lemon hops (instead of lemongrass, get it?).  Malt/hops balance is slightly in favor of hops, like most of the Allagash beers.  Alcohol bursts on my throat with the first mouthful, really the only indicator of the beer¬ís strength.  Yay beer!
On draft at the Grey Lodge. Has a golden hue with a foamy white head. Flavour of passion fruit and herbal tea. Aroma has hints if banana and honey.

Gold, orange, and amber melt before my eyes while a fluffy cloud drifts and lingers atop a sunshine smile. White tufts fade lazily into a thick puddle centered in the middle of her glassy surface while an equally thick collar traces the edges of her confine. I tease her shimmering depths but receive no lace in thanks, just a thicker abundance of clumpy foam. What I do receive in spades though is a nose bursting with Belgian-style Tripel esters: yeast, spice, ripe fruits stewed and caramelized in a sweet mixture of honey, maple, brown sugar and cinnamon. Soft white bread offers gentle support while pungent cantaloupe, mango, star fruit, and kiwi teeter on the edge of over-ripeness. Flowers bloom and herbal essences drift by on a passing breeze while meringue toasts, piecrust is molded, and lemoncello cream fills someone¬ís aperitif glass. Abundantly aromatic and intense, all her esters and aromas mingle together in exquisite precision, drawing me into her beery embrace like a hapless seaman to the siren¬ís call. For such a rambunctious nose, her body and mouthfeel is super soft, so much so to make the finest cottons blush in envy. The freshest white breads still warm from the oven, steam rises from their brown skin. Starting off soft, she finishes with dry hops, dry lemon, orange, and mango skins replete with moisture-retardant lingering pith. A green, dry finish, her middle is also sweet, tropical, and grassy with damp dew, coconut, toasted flatbread, lemon zest, and floral essence. I find it intriguingly tasty how much her palate differs from her nose. The sweetness is subdued while my tongue tingles under a dry, toasty, green, dewy, tropical assault. I forgo the pen and paper for the rest of my bottle, choosing to just sit, sup, and savor.


Unique, but still a solid offering from Allagash. Their Tripel is not one of my more favored offerings in this particular style, but she is still a quality contribution none-the-less. I plan on quaffing future bottles of the Allagash Tripel in future dates, but not as frequently as their White.

Decent Tripel but not at the top of my list of styes. A bit of silt to watch out for, and the corresponding yeast flavor, but not over-powering or out-of-balance. Anyone who prefers Tripels will enjoy this beer a lot. Batch #137 at 55F from the 750ml bottle.

Beautiful pour into a bordeaux stem, great lace.  Restrained nose shows some honeyed grain, fresh pineapple (not sweetened from can) and nice hop spice that compliments the dryness well.  While the fruit continues on the palate, it never becomes cloying or tooti fruity. The esters never get to heady and balance is held to a level of seduction that many Belgians don¬ít achieve.  Yes I just said that.  A certain richness to the body does let the drinker know that this beer isn¬ít afraid to take the recliner in the living room without asking.  Well planned carbonation level gives this beer a spring in its step without jumping to a gallop. Honeyed malt and hop spice finish cleanly.  Very digestable.  Had this with a fresh baquette, butter, and some mixed atipasto.  Cheers to Mr. Tod. 94

Poured a golden color that had some has. Head is nice and tall and bright white as a tripel should be. Aroma is yeasty with hints of citrus and some mild spice. Taste is balanced and crisp with yeast and citrus over tones. A nice beer that can be picked up at the local grocery store.

750 ml bottle, from batch #134, served in a tulip glass.  Poured a hazy golden color with about 3 inches of thick, pillowed white head.  Nose is Belgian yeast, citrus rinds, and a light peppery spice.  Taste is yeast and citrus peels that finishes with a peppery citrus bitter.  A good beer and example of the style, but nothing that will make me remember this a few months down the road.
750 ml bottle, batch #134.  Pours clear orange.  Aroma of bready yeast.  Full bodied, orange peel with a mild herb background.  Decent bitter finish.  Nice example of the style.

Batch # 136. Picked up from Greens Ponce De Leon. The cork may be used as a deadly weapon. This thing exploded right out of the bottle. Holy crap. Anyways, Nice looking head. Nice slight orange haze color. The beer looks pretty friggin good. Head eventually fades away to leave a thin layer. Very fruity aroma. Yeast is noticeable as well. Very pugnent beer. Slight citrus aroma. This beer doesn¬ít have that cheap fruit aroma, but a very nuanced and complex one.  Very fruity and a nice yeast taste. The beer is too carbonated for me. It gets in the way of having the smooth flavors sit on your tongue. Nice banana/yeast and slight citrus. Nice candy sugar sweet flavor. This is a nice trippel. I just wish the carbonation would have been toned down.

Pours a four finger white head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Clear pale amber color. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied.   Oak and dark fruit nose. Flavor is sweet oak, bready and some orange peel at finish. Decent triple. $3.00 for a 12oz bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT.

Source:  750 mL bottle purchased in Georgia. Glass: Tulip. Appearance: Clear gold pour with a two finger white head.  Aroma:  Fruit and candi sugar, with a hint of alcohol. Flavor: Fruity, but very dry and bready finish. Palate:  Medium body with solid carbonation.Overall:  Not my favorite tripel.  Finish was too dry, and the fruit didn¬ít dominate the palate as much as I would have liked.

12 ounce bottle - $2.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a nearly clear, bright golden body with two fingers worth of white foam.

Smell: Spiced and sweetened sliced bananas greet the nose first, then enter some fruity notes of white peaches, Golden Delicious apples, pineapple, and maybe, just maybe even a bit of bitter orange. Background waft of whole, smile-inducing booze.

Taste: Pale malts, maybe some lightish wheat with a touch of overall breadiness. It starts candi sugar sweet but it instantly begins drying away. Richly fruity melange in the middle. Cracked cloves. A single, solitary drop of vanilla. Sharp floral touches alongside some hop bitterness. Peppery alcohol tries to hit you with a hammer, but the other various flavors try to keep it at bay. The other fruit flavors dim down, but the citrusy orange peel character remains. Dry, warming finish with a touch of dried herbs.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: Good! It embodies a fine line between full flavored and relatively easily drinkability despite the punchy 9% ABV.
Dark yellow, with a moderate white head. Fruit, spice, and a little yeast aroma. Very smooth, a little hops, fruit, and a hint of alcohol. Excellent stuff.

Bomber. Cloudy light orange colored, thick white head. Big nose of dough. Flavors of yeast, banana, a little lemon, and alcohol. Warming, but easy drinking and a nice finish of hops. Good straight ahead Tripel.

Yellow orange in color... Citrusy yeasty aroma... Flavor is crisp, citrusy with the yeasty finish you expect of a tripel... Very good representation of the style for an American brewery... Might be better than some of the Belgian tripels I¬íve had... Kind of a bitter finish... Good beer.

750 mL bottle from Total Wine (Batch 127, purchased January 2009).  Pale yellowish-orange pour with a white head.  Aroma of banana, clove, and a hint of honey.  Flavors of banana, peppery spice, yeast, sugar, and a bit of alcohol.  Very well balanced.  Because this beer seems to be just about everywhere I tend to take it for granted but it is an excellent beer that I should ask for more often.
Excellent triple. Highly carbonated with a head that stands up. Pleasant grainy aroma and flavor with a nice balance of hops.

Served in an 11 oz. trappist glass @ Taco Mac. Robust, golden color. Mellow aroma of banana, alcohol and fruits. First sip is complex. Honey, clove, lots of spice and tropical fruits. Full bodied and tasty. Reminds me of Victory Golden Monkey, but not quite as good as that godly brew.
Bottle. Aroma balanced between clove/pepper spiciness, Italian bread malt, and yellow-orange fruits. Flavor the same, well-rounded. Quite clean for a tripel. Tasty stuff.
Really enjoyable.  Sweet fruity aroma and crisp fruit flavor and finish.  really nice stuff

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of sweet fruits, yeast, sweet corn malt.  Flavor of sweet tropical fruits, grapefruit and citrus. light spices, yeast, and sweet malt.  Sweet but not overpowering.  Light and crisp palate.  This is super tasty!  Very nice tripel!
8/4/8/4/16 (4.0/5)

Pours a golden yellow with a fluffy white head.  Lots of little carbonation bubbles in there.  Aroma is fruit, spices, yeast, nice and sweet.  Taste is fruit tartness, spices, yeast.  There is some honey in there.  Good amount of carbonation.  Real nice stuff.
Good gracious, top 5 beer at beerfest this weekend.  This triple was an experience I won¬ít soon forget.

Batch number 109. Cloudy, golden-orange pour with fluffy white head. Earthy, fruity aroma with spices, yeast, some clove and banana. Flavor is fruity and estery, with lots of clove and banana. Nots of honey, yeast, and spice, with some earthiness. Full mouthfeel with light carbonation, with a nice earthy finish.  Pretty solid for a tripel.

Batch #131. Pours a cloudy amber color with a huge white head. Aroma is sweet and spicy - cloves, alcohol, and maybe a hint of cinnamon. Taste is more cloves, banana, spice, bread-like yeast, and some alcohol. Has a dull, earthy bitterness in the finish. Moderate carbonation, smooth mouth feel. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

From a 750 ml c&c bottle from BevMo in Sacramento this poured a orange to gold with a huge white head and great lacing. Nose of caramel malts and and ripe fruit. Nice creamy and smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is rich and well balanced with banana and clove showing. Nice clean dry finish. Excellent.

Bottle  Batch 133  Pours  a cloudy golden yellow  with a big white head.  The head lasts well and laces nicely.  Has a nice aroma of bubble gum, sweet malts, spices, and a touch of hoppiness.  Good carbination and a good mouthfeel.  Flavor is good with a good balance and a nice blending.  Has a medium body.  A good solid finish and a nice aftertaste.

Bottle, with Alaskanwarren. Thanks Brian! Pale orange/gold, lots of dense off-white head. Fresh green spring smell; sweet peas, black pepper, bubblegum, clove, citrus oil. Dense herbal hop flavor, lots of hop flavor but modest bitterness. Mint, menthol, lingering citrus oil. Cool tropical morning. Unobtrusive but somehow just right malt backbone, with a teeny warming quality, but as soon as it registers it is gone, and then just a sense of lightness of being. Finishes dry and delicate. An unusually nice American Belgian.

Pours nice cloudy golden color with just shy of a half inch head.  Lacing the glass extremely well.  Medium bodied on this one.  Malts, hops, sweet fruit on the palate.  Excellent tripel., especially when you consider that it comes from America.
Light, fragile head; strong fruity aroma; finish was a raw medicine like alcohol that outlasted the flavor
Good classic tripel aroma. Maintains head. Dry and mild but with reasonably flavorfull esters. A bit overly harsh bitterness on the finish with some lingering off flavors.

Bottle "Tripel Ale" from Brattleboro Food Co-op. Dark yellow body with thin, rocky head. Floral nose with banana and orange aroma. Nice and spicey. With fruit flavours, including banana and oranges. Sweet and spicy in the finish with ABV noticeable. Well done!
Aroma of yeast, some citrus hops, and sweet malt.  Appearance is cloudy, with a light orange head and lacing.  Flavor has light spices and coriander, citrus.

Bottle.  Orange tan, meidum small off white head.  Smells of bread, pear, clove.  A little sweet malt, then turns bready, finishes with some nice spice and a bit of bitterness.  A highly enjoyable triple.

Nice dark yellow orange color and great fluffy head. Nice aroma of spice and fruit. Some citrus, orange, and pinapple.  Taste is yeasty and crisp with a lot of spice. Nice sweetness and some hops too. A bit of alcohol and dry end.

750 mL into tulip. Pours a deep cloudy orange with a thick, IPA-like, beige head that sticks around and leaves some spotty lacing. Subdued aroma of dry hops, orange peel, yeast, and dough. Taste is- wow- much more alcoholic and warming than I expected. After the initial shock, there is fresh orange, pineapple, apricots, and other light fruits in the complex mix. Not too sweet though with good balancing spicy hops. Fruity, dry finish.

Maybe some oxygen got into this bottle, but it had a hoppy pilsner-like dry bitterness to it of which I was not a fan.  There was an awesome thick white head on top of a cloudy golden beer.  Excellent lacing as well.  Aroma was yeast and spices with some banana.  Flavor was very slight honey and banana sweetness followed by an ugly bitterness perhaps best enjoyed by hop heads.  Finish would be very enjoyable without the bitterness.

bottle - Pours cloudy gold with an ample head.  It smells of yeast with citrus and bready malt.  The flavor is sweet and citrus rich with very apparent yeast and a medium, bubbly body.  It¬ís quite good, but I¬ím not getting the complexity that others are finding to make it great.

Location: 750ml Bottle (A Gift Purchased at the Whole Foods in Union Sq NY, NY)


Aroma: Smell is a mix of lots of different fruits

Appearance: Golden color, very thick, milky white head

Flavor: Mostly taste the fruitiness, with hints of the alcohol.  Lots of complex fruit flavors that work well together.

Palate: Relatively full Body.  Smooth, enjoyable aftertaste.

Overall Impression: 
A very nice tripel, and a great representation of the style.  Drinks well from start to finish.

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle.  Initial appearance is a pale golden with a large white head.  Fresh, yet spicy on the nose; with a slight note of pepper.  Restrained and full on the palate, revealing wonderous complexity from the yeast.  A must for anyone claiming to enjoy belgian-style ales.

(Batch # 95) 75 cl bottle at Hopheads¬¥ tasting 30.01.09 (Trygve). Golden/light amber color, fine white head. Aroma is yeast, spices, banana. Flavor is the same, with notes of alcohol. Smooth and very nice.
Tap @ Monster B¬ís. Vanilla, clove, grass, honey and banana nose. The taste is much of the same with the alcohol flavor. A real heart warmer.

Pours a very nice honey orange with a thin white head.  The nose is very subtle and clean.  The flavor was also subtle, leaving something to be desired.  The finish is slightly acidic with a light smoky flavor lingering towards the end and a slightly sticky mouth feel.  I can¬ít say that I really enjoyed this beer all that much but it did do a good job of masking the 9.0% ABV.

Citrus, tangerine, floral, honey and a fair amount of alcohol on the nose.  Light orange, to dark yellow appearance, with a thin, half inch, quickly dissapating white head.  Flavor follows the aroma well, but the alcohol is noticeable.  Mouth feel is smooth, with small tight bubbles.  Overally, a nice tripel to sip on, but the alcohol flavor is a bit overpowering.  Should be better hidden in a tripel.

Tap @ OTH.
Pours cloudy orange.
Aroma is fruity, sugary yeasty.
Taste, nice orange/tangerine like fruits, sweet sugar, malty, light hops and esters.
Very nice mouthfeel, plenty of alcohol throughout.

Draught at the Big Hunt.   Hazy gold with a medium sized head.   I¬ím annoyed with the little 25cl Allagash stemware that they serve their stronger beers in.   So narrow, and so little head space.   Sweet honey, bread, yeast, and orange aroma.   Yeasty, spicy flavor with fruity pear notes.   The fruitiness in this reminds me a lot of the Black, but seems more appropriate here.   Definitely tastes like Allagash.   Good stuff.

Bottle, batch 104.  Pours a slightly hazy, yellow body with orange hues and a generous, fluffy, off-white head.  Aroma is belgian malts, spices, clove, with hints of apple, banana, and floral hops.  Flavor is sweeter than the aroma would suggest - belgian malts, citrus hops, orange, spices, and honey near the finish.  Soft, smooth mouthfeel; medium bodied.  Sweet malt and honey finish that is dry and slightly sticky.

Nearly every bit the equal to my favorite Tripel from Westmalle, Allagash Tripel is simply outstanding.  The yeast derived spice compliments the subtle fruity notes of the well attenuated malt and sugars.  This is   quite simply one of the best American made Belgian beers and I never intend to go without several bottles in my cellar.
Aroma of banana, cloves, yeast.  Taste is fruity, yeasty, full and deep, slightly spiced like cinnamon or cloves.  Body is frothy, carbonated.  Very crisp and refreshing.  Quite a tasty number.
Gold in color with a medium sized white head. Aroma is of citrus, honey, and clove. Taste is of fruits, spices and yeast.
A cloudy honey clored brew with a soft, thin white head, little bi tof fruit in the aroma, a very smooth, malty taste.  Very fine.

Bottle. Thanks to smokepot23 for the hookup. Hazy yellow highly carbonated pour. Flavor is honey and a bit herbal, some ripe fruits and banana notes. Hints of bread and yeasty esters. Medium bodied. Lingering smooth finish. Solid.

Pours a a hazy orange gold with creamy white head that dissipates to a thin later. Aroma is a citrus mango with coriander, bread and yeast. Flavor is banana, yeast, candy sugar. I definitely can find the honey notes in the sweetness. Body is creamy and a little thicker than expected with high carbonation.
Batch 91. An aroma of ginger and corriander. A golden pour with creamy white head and lace. Honey and clove with a bready aftertaste. A bit foamy but as expected. A very nice offering.

Was a dark copper/light orange color as poured from a 750 ml bottle. A nice white head. Smell is of spicy citrus, with some candi sugar and honey also detected. It is a malty and sugary beer with a big yeasty finish. Didn¬ít really taste all the spicy, which I expected from the aroma.

Bottle courtesy of superdave70 shared at hellbilly*s holiday tasting. Spicey yeast aroma. Golden body with white head. Flavor of fermented fruits and thought the last one had some spice this Allagash spiced up my life a little more. Wow odd stuff here for my palate I quess. Thanks Dave.

Nice looking brew. Cloudy orange color with a thick white bubbly head.  Aroma was a little lemony, but mostly yeast.  Flavor was like a typical tripel, but much weaker.  There was no sweetness and I didn‚Äôt notice any alcohol present.  The palate was really throwing me off.  The finish left a very metalic taste in my mouth.  I don‚Äôt really understand why people seem to like this so much.

Batch 102.  750 mL.  

Pours a super cloudy light yellow, with a nice frothy head.  Medium lace.  Aroma is honey and yeast.  Flavor is honey and raisin, some yeast with a touch of malt and holiday spice.  Palate is carbonated and fizzy, and the beer disappears in your mouth like pop rocks.  Overall this was a very tasty, complex beer.  Loved it.
