Sampled at the hellbilly holiday tasting.  Slightly hazy deep gold pour with a lasting foamy head.  Aroma of malt, yeast, light fruit and spice.  Sweet fruity flavor with a spicy , warming alcohol finish.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  Not bad at all.
has a slight banana aroma, taste is a bit of honey with some spicey malt mixed in, nice clove spice aftertaste, nice brew.
Draft at BT.  Pours an orange amber body with a white rocky head.  Banana, coriander, pine, and honey.  Sweet with a pepper spiced finish.  Good brew.

Bottle courtesy of superdave70 shared at hellbilly*s holiday tasting.  Pours a clear gold with a fluffy white head.  Nose is cloves, spice and malty yeast.  Taste is yeast, candied fruit and spice.  Medium mouth feel.  A bit too sweet for my tastes but a well put together brew. Thanks Dave!

750 ml bottle, batch 95. A cloudy dark golden beer with a small and fast disappearing white head. The aroma is excellent, balanced and yeasty with hoppy, floral, herbal and spicy notes. Almost no traces of alcohol in the nose. The flavour is balanced too,  with a medium sweetness and some acidity. It feels really Belgian in the mouth, well blended ingredients. Spicy, fruity and with a good hoppiness. Smooth mouthfeel, medium to full body, lively carbonation, dry long finish with medium bitterness, very lightly alcoholic. A fantastic beer, excellent aroma and really flavourful. One of the best tripels, comparable to the finest Belgians, if not better.

Bouteille de 330 ml. Nos yeux observent une bi√®re de couleur dor√©e et un beau col. Ar√¥mes tr√®s fruit√©s orange, mangue, ananas, de gomme baloune avec un peu de levure. Saveurs de mangue  de gomme baloune, de miel,

Batch 110.  Unremarkable.  Color is hazy and very cloudy orange yellow. The only way I can really describe the flavor and aroma is kinda sweet, then sort of murky and muddled.  One of the less impressive tripels I have had, to be downright honest.

Flaske. Flot orange √∏l, med et lille skumhoved, og klart mindre karbonering end belgiske trippels. Masser af frugt i duften. SMagen er mere humlet end ellers, med en fin bitterhed til at balancere s√∏dmen. En n√∏ddeagtig honningsmag kommer frem som √∏llen opvarmes. Alkoholen er komplet skjult kold, men kommer ogs√• frem med varmen og giver en god balance. Rigtig l√¶kker √∏l.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2013 10/18/2013. 12oz Bottle. Sticky banana and medicine aroma, phenol heavy and forward. Flavors smooth that out a tiny bit, adding honey, banana bread, and parsley. I¬ím not sure whether my palate has changed or I¬ím just realizing how harsh and messy American renditions of Belgian ferments can be, but this isn¬ít working for me. It¬ís got an acrid stickiness to the phenols that makes it hard to smell and take on the palate early. The finish is clean, minerally, and with some juicyfruit, but I¬ím not into the overall flavor profile. Alcohol fairly well integrated. 6/4/7/4/15


11/27/2008. 750mL Bottle. Aromas is a light kiss of cork, curt apple juice and a bit of bread yeast. Soft and quiet. Pours an opalescent, cloudy golden with a hint of amber, and a tall froth of clean white soap, lasting long. Flavor is fresh, bright and not overly complex. A solid tripel. Airy. A bit of creaminess, some calvados and a light tooth of malt sugar. Classic and bit more refined and deep than most versions. Finished extremely cleanly and with bits of almond candy. 7/4/8/4/17

Bottle.  Pours a light orange, almost yellow color with a nice frothy white head.  Aromas of bananas, fruit, wine, and a bit of pear.  Creamy start to a non-carbonated texture with an oily aftertaste.  Wonderful beer!

Batch 122- It‚Äôs scary how much this beer does actually taste like "fruit punch". Poured a golden color with a medium, white head. Alcohol is very well hidden. Sweet flavor, similar to "Hawaiian Punch".
Pours a vibrant gold color with a nice head.  Very smooth flavor for a beer with 9% ABV.  Great spicy flavor, very long finish.
Bottle. Pours gold with a white head. Sweet tropical fruity/fruity punch aroma with some spices. The flavor is less sweet than the aroma., with spicy and light notes of iced tea. Very good.
Getting my notebook online. Bottle, Batch 105. Pours a sparkling gold. Very yeasty in the nose. Honey, spice, and yeast flavors. Decent beer.

Bottle...  Poured orange with a white head.  Floral, tropical fruit with some esters on the nose.  Really smooth and delicate for 9%.  Had a great clove and ester presence in the flavors with some herbal fruit and hop notes.  Finished with plum and a honey sweetness.

Pours golden with a slight haze and bright white head.  Fruity nose, spice, and yeast.  Mouthfeel is creamy but not super thick.  Carbonation is medium.  Flavor is spicy as well as the finish.  Yeasty undertones throughout almost like it was brewed in Belgium
Pours slight hazy bright golden with a two finger off white head. Nice fruit and estery nose. The flavor goes very fruity, with apple and passionfruit influences.
Thanks to Pollo.  Pours a medium golden color with a white head.  Medium bodied, nice yeasty acidity, very spicy and a very long finish.  Excellent.
Thanks to rsamayoa: fruity, herbal, full bodied. very good. drank at an informal rateberian gathering.

Cerveza estilo belga - de las que les gustan al gordo solo que no tan peluda
No es mi estilo pero esta bien

Great beer.  Pours a hazy amber with a head that lasts throughout the drinking time.  Smells of honey and yeast, very nice.  Extremely balanced and mellow taste, has a certain sweetness to it.  Also has hints of spice and malt.  Medium mouthfeel, just about right for a tripel.  Very good beer, about the best American tripel I have had.

Brewfest NY 08. Man i wish i was able to write down notes at the fest, but it was pouring rain and I had an umbrella in one hand, and my drinking glass in the other. I remember this being pretty decent though. Obviously need to try it again.
Excellent beer. The flavors you¬íd expect from the style. Alcohol is not at all noticable which makes this a dangerous brew. The last sip makes you want another bottle.
22oz. Hazy gold amber. Light head low carbonation. The alcohol is apparent however the complex smokey wheat flavor is predominant. Sweet spicy esters. Pleasant balance and sweet dry finish.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Not impressed.  The flavor makes up for the aroma of something close to chlorine.  Not sure if it was offensive or good, which means even if it wasn‚Äôt offensive, it still wasn‚Äôt that good.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a fizzy/creamy head that leaves great lacing. Standard tripel nose consisting of yeast and spices and summery fruit. Taste is similar. I was somewhat disappointed with the finish, though. Somewhat of a lingering bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2010 750 ml bottle batch 115. Pours a rich thick creamy long lasting head, nice lacing (including the bottle), pleasant yellow gold color....nose of various spices including cardamom, some yeast, many phenols.... tastes initially slightly sweet, then various esters, including fruits and spices such as, banana, clove, followed by a more honey like sweetness and finally a somewhat bitter finish. Mouth feel was good throughout. It tastes very young to me and I plan to age a bottle or so.....................................It is now two years later, still batch 115. The original description is accurate, but the overall presentation is much rounder, less nuanced and softer. The more pronounced flavors are now subdued and less sharp. My rating would be 3.7-3.8. BJCP
7/3/15/4/8

750 ml bottle from daknole(thanks). Pours a slightly cloudy dark yellow, with a big white head that has good retention and leaves plenty of lacing. The aroma is moderate in strength with Belgian yeasts, spices, pears and something musty. The flavor is overtly sweet with a rock candy overture, followed by complex spicy fruits and concluded by candied almonds. The mouthfeel is full, smooth and malty. The finish is long and sweet. Overall:One of the best tripels that I‚Äôve had in a long time. Recommended.
Sampled at the NY Brewfest on 9/12.  Not able to give a very accurate rating due to the sheer number of brews sampled.  Remembered it being ok, but not sure it lives up to its rating here.

Poured from bomber, part of Belgian-style beer tasting.  Appearance is light yellow orange with a crisp white head.  Aroma is of spices, banana, yeast, and malt.  Flavor is initially semi-sweet, complemented by a smooth, lightly carbonated palate.  I tasted banana, yeast, fruit, and spice all in a phenomenally balanced recipe.  Overall, this is a great Tripel.  I‚Äôd say my favorite part of this is the smooth, balanced palate and the subtle finish with a hint of alcohol.  Can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve tried a better Tripel.
Hazy golden yellow, Citrus, yeasty, spicey, hops, little, banana, little caramel, slight honey little wood, dry finish.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2009 Batch 114. Pours with a large, off-white creamy head and a murky yellow body. Aroma of orange zest, honey, yeast and spice. Taste is sweet, spicy, and a bit of candied orange peel. Sharp bubbles and a dryish mouthfeel.

Notes from Batch 46 (1998 Bottle consumed in Feb. 2009): Hazy golden color with a generous white head. Aroma is sweet and bready. Notes of raisins and sherry covering up light spice. Hint of cardboard oxidation. Smells like a sherry dosed plain original donut. Taste is bready, sweet with notes of sherry. Mouthfeel is starting to show a little bit of thinning, but it is still pleasant. Light carbonation.
750ml bottle. Cloudy amber with a thin head. Light belgian yeast nose. Some spices and fruity flavors combine nicely with a yeasty malty finish. Maybe not my favorite triple ever but a solid beer.

Poured from a 750ml caged and corked bottle and served in a tulip.  This beer poured a hazy, golden orange hue with a lasting head of creamy off-white foam.  A decent coat of lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of fresh orange peel, honey, pale malts, and lightly peppery yeast esthers.  The flavor included bananas, orange peel, light honey, and light caramel.  No trace of alcohol until a slight warmth at the finish.  The mouthfeel is round and full-bodied with a nice crisp feel from some assertive carbonation.  A really well crafted brew.  Tasty stuff!

[Bottle] Pours a hazy gold with a large rocky off white head and some floaties. Aroma is pretty slight, but lots of citrus notes, lemon, orange peel. Flavor matches. Extremely smooth and pretty light in the mouth. The alcohol is not terribly present. A very drinkable tripel.

8/2/08 from the bottle. Aroma is a blend of roast malt and pepper forward with a caramel finish. Appearance is hazy gold with a well maintained white head. Flavor is clove forward with a perfumy banana background. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a somewhat grainy carb texture blend. Overall, quite good and worth trying just for the complexity.

Batch 37 Slightly oxidized.The appearance was a large sized white head that consisted of fine-small sized bubbles.There was was carbonation observed with this beer along with a cloudy body.The hue was yellow and the nose consisted of malt, hops, fruit, and cloves.The flavor was sour, tart, and fruity.It had bubbly and smooth mouthfeel along with a medium body.There was virtually no lacing with this beer.

Well how on earth did I wait until this long to try this beer?  Bomber, shared for sure! Amber pour wtih a medium off white head.  Lacing is nice too.  Aroma is really nice, malty, fruity, sweet, woody.  Good shit folks.  Flavor is yeasty and rich.  Good mouthfeel.  WINNER!

Foul aroma right from the get-go which only smells like lead, mite dust, and iron. In contrast to that however, the flavor is excellent; Fruity sweet with cream character. Viscosity and carbonation are near perfect. Perhaps the smoothest Tripel I¬íve ever. An odd recommendation: Drink this one straight from the bottle for maximum enjoyment, do not pour; It¬ís better sans the disappointing aroma. You make look like a wino, but who cares? Honestly, its better right out of the bottle.

Bottle into chalice. Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a creamy 1-finger off-white head that lasts practically forever. Aroma is fruity and sweet - ripe golden (passion) fruit, spicy yeast, honey. Taste is banana and ripe golden fruit, honey sweet malt, and a crisp, dry, slightly bitter yeast spiciness. Finish is dry and yeasty with a bit of alcohol, and a faint, balancing bitterness from the yeast and alcohol, and maybe a slight herbal hop undertone. Carbonation is crisp, with a creamy, medium body. Really a fantastic tripel.

Purchased from Belmont Station in an adorable 12oz. bottle--Poured a hazy golden-orange hue with a ginormous white head. Phenolic banana-clove nose with prickly spiced notes and some bold booziness.  Crisp malt underpinning.  Alcohol well masked.  Funky yeasty wheaten complexity.  Great example of the style.  Yum!

Corked bottle from batch #108.  Pours a hazy orange colour with a firm white head.  Big aroma of banana, spice and a little alcohol.  Phenomenal flavour, well balanced with spice and sweet.  9% ABV very well hidden.  Outstanding Belgian style tripel made in the States.  Well done.

The big bottle poured hazy bright golden honey color with fluffy white head that settled nicely into a thin white sheet. The aroma is definitely sweet and yeasty, apricot, banana, burned sugars, coriander,  and alcohol. The flavor is very balanced with herbal bite alcohol and sweet finish. It¬ís a rather reserved tripel. It¬ís outstanding really. Balanced and subtle.

12 oz bottle-at beach in DE-haven‚Äôt seen in this size at State Line. Jumped on this one. Very drinkable, taste is supreme, deep, complex palate is an understatement. This is brewing at its finest-Can‚Äôt see why anyone wouldn‚Äôt like this--
Batch 81. Pours bright yellow with a nice chunky white head.  Nose of funkiness, wheat, yeast.  Taste is yeasty, funky, a bit alcoholy. Nice smooth body. A nice  tripple.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle.  Poured gold with thin fast dissipating white head. Aroma of fruit and malt.  Fruit, sweet malt, honey and tiny clove notes in flavour.  Caramel, fruit and sweetness in the balanced finish.  A worhty tripel
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Tasted this at Microfestivus.  It was light in color and had good head.  The beer was fruity with some spicy/sweet notes.  It was pretty good and would drink again.

Bottle sampled at NFB&WF ‚Äô08 at Martha Clara Vineyards.  One of the better offerings I sampled at the festival.  Pours a clear gold.  Pleasant aroma of yeast, some fruit, and a bit of alcohol.  The flavor is lovely with yeast and candi sugar along with some fruit.  A bit sticky in the mouthfeel, which I personally like.  Enjoyable.

Pours a beautiful gold with a thin white head. Nice carbonation. Requisite banana and other fruit ester notes are present, but this tripel is not as sweet as other tripels. Long pleasant finish.  Nothing to complain about here.
Bottle @ Brewery.  Golden pour with well formed fluffy white head. Belgian yeast and assoiciated clove and banana flavors.  Sweet but not voerbearing as with some fo thier fare.  Well rounded.

Hazy golden color with a white head.  Light spicy flavor mixed in with tropical fruit flavors.  Yeasty and sweet.  A hair thick for my preferences making it slightly sticky, but still a suburb brew.  It is thinner than the dubbel and four, however.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2011 Tap @ Taco mac Mall of Georgia.  Golden pour, white creamy head.  Aroma of apriums (hybrid apricot/plum), honey, clove, pinapple, and some other tropical fruits.  Flavor is quite spicey, smooth and perfect to this style.  Bread, yeast flavors, followed by sweet ripe bananas.  finishes with a pleasant hop bite tha is light enough to give a perfect balance.  Where¬ís the alcohol.  very smooth, very very enjoyable.  Batch 90.  750ml, caged and corked.  Had this bottle brought back from a Whole Foods in SF.  With some age, it has become very dry.  Creamy texture.  Lots of tropical fruit is still present, gentle soft bread.  Nice carbonation.  Some sugary sweetness. no hop is present.  I feel I have opened a perfectly aged bottle sent from Heaven.

Pours hazy apricot with modest white head. Aroma is peach, apricot, citrus, clove, and honey. Flavor is subtle but nice. Hop character and bitterness is noticable, though alcohol is not.  Lots of sweet light fruit with spicyness from both the yeast and hops. Palate is thick for such a light colored beer, but not viscous by any means. Flavors are unique and overall, the brew is well crafted.

(Bottle).  Citrusy aroma.  Hazy amber color.  Taste is cloyingly candy sweet, with notes of alcohol.  Not my style at all, as I find the sweetness overpowering and decidedly off-putting.   Not an experience I care to repeat.

Pours a murky amber. Thick foamy white head, good lacing. 
Aroma of pineapple, lemon peel, cranberry bread, some hops.
Flavor is mild, tilted to the bitter/hoppy side. Bread-y and citrus.
Good medium/heavy body, nice and thick for a tripel. 
Overall, it could use a bit more fruityness and some less bitterness.

pours a hazy orange with nice frothy white head, slow to dissipate. Holds orange peel, coriander, honey on the nose. Flavor is excellent- yeast, orange, honey, and spice. Palate is excellent, very smooth, delicious.
Golden Orange pour, frothy white head, good lacing.  Honey, Spicy citrus aroma, tangerine is present.  Zesty citrus, orange peels, honey, spicy aftertones.  Crisp and refreshing, Very Good Tripel.

bottle.  Pours a bright, hazy orange with a decent head that clears quick but leaves a solid ring.  Sweet and citric fruity aromas- tangerines, oranges, peaches.  Flavors flesh out more than the aroma- definitely some fruit in there (melons, lemons, apples) along with some heavy yeasty notes, a fair amount of booze, and a smooth candy sweet malt character.  Very well balanced on the flavors.  Palate is crisp and dry, clean finish.  Very good tripel.

(Sample from July 18, 2008 Beer Club Meeting: Batch 113) Large frothy white head.  Pale orange/yellow color.  Steady and slow carbonation.  Smells of serious fruit, bananas even?  Lovely and sweet, wildly fruity, syrupy.  Nice carbonation.  Thin, but hefty.  Not bad for an American Tripel, but I‚Äôve had better.
Hazy orange with a nice off-white head, syrupy body, pleasant yeasts and some candyish citrus. Huge body, hints of perfume, dry finish. Nicely done.
Exactly what you would expect from a tripel.  Orange/amber color with a thin white head.  Huge amounts of yeast, citrus, and apples.  Dry and bitter finish.  Great beer.

C&C 750, batch #72. It‚Äôs about time I rated this - it is one of my favorites. I hid this bottle from myself to try to age it, so I think it‚Äôs about 2 years old. The cork popped up about 12 feet when I opened it. Murky yellow gold with a big white head. Yeast and coriander begin the show, with a bevy of fruits backing them up - mango, cantaloupe, orange some pineapple, sweet caramel, wow, lots going on! Flavors are more of the same, adding a light peppery bite, some floral notes. Some banana pops up late, and everything dries out just a bit. Hell yeah... this brew rocks! Medium body, smooth and satiny. LOVE IT.
bottle, batch 102, golden yellow color, lots of alcohol and sugars on the nose, flavors are much the same with some fruit like apricots, not as finished as some others

A very admirable effort, a nicely done trippel.  Lots of fruit and spice in the nose, has that really sweet candied orange peel I have come to know and love from Allagash.  Alcohol is a little more present on the palate than in the nose.  Has a bit of dry gingerbread maltiness, a bit of honey, and spicy cloves.  Enjoyable.

Thanks to Naka for sharing. A rich, frothy white head sits above a cloudy orange body, and leaves wonderful lacing. The aroma is very spicy and fruit, with notes of orange, bread, sweet candy, and coriander. There¬ís a also a BIG alcohol presence in the nose. The taste is obviously very young and fresh with lots of alcohol heat, strong fruity esters, and a touch of sweetness. Hints of sweet orange peel, cloves, coriander, ginger, and bread, with a slight acidic burn. My only complaint, other than the heat, is that it¬ís a tad under-carbonated.

Pours a hazy golden brown color into the glass with a moderate white, foamy head.  Aroma is yeasty, with a little spice to it also.  Flavor is yeast, spice (coriander), a bit of lemon, and a wee bit of alcohol.  Batch # 102.

1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle.

Bottle. Hazy bright golden. Thick off-white head and lacing. Sweet estery aromas. Lots of banana. Too much. Also nutmeg, pie spice. Soft creamy but chewy mouthfeel. Alcohol and sweetness detectable. Banana cream pie with phyllo and hint of chili too. All that I and I don¬ít like the beer too much.

Pours a hazy orange gold color with a medium head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is very citrus, mostly oranges, along with some spices.  This was very smooth, almost creamy in the mouth.  Very crisp and easy drinking.  The alcohol can sneak up on you so be careful!!
Nice Tripel.  Cloudy golden pour with a frothy head.  Aroma is malt and citrus.  Taste is better defined with the citrus notes turning orange in nature.

This is one of my favorite beers.  Pouring at 9% ABV you can dink a 750 ml bottle by yourself at leisurely pace just about any evening.  It is golden yellow and slightly cloudy with a fine creamy white head that last and last. The aroma is spicy and fruity with just the faintest scent of alcohol at the end. when you take this beer in your mouth you feel a nice medium to better body that borders on creamy.  Sweet and spicy up front with a nice rounded maltiness and a hint of alcohol warming in the finish.  If you haven¬ít had this you should and if you have you should probably pick up another one  just to remind yourself how good it is.

75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a cloudy brownish-yellow with white one-finger head. Aroma is citrus and juniper predominately with notes of wheat, bread and yeast. Flavor is slightly bitter with hints of caramel and honey. Subtle sweetness here, but the finish is somewhat quick and bland. Not the best tripel we have experienced, but a worthy drinker.
Poured golden with a effervescent small head.  Fruity smell with a lish taste.  Flavour of honey and orange.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 12 oz bottle (which they just started offering, I think).  A bright, refreshing tripel.  Hazy golden pour with orange tint.  Disappointing head.  Nose of orange peel, bananas, apricots, honey and spices that go beyond simple clove or coriander.  A little veg/herb note to keep it interesting.  Slight floral notes when one coaxes a head.  Alcohol is dangerously hidden.  Longy tasty finish. I¬ím a little picky about tripels and don¬ít like them if they¬íre too sweet.  This one has a nice crispness, almost tart. This is quite good.

This poured a cloudy golden body with a big fluffy head. The head was chewy and thick with a tart berry flavor. Aromas of fermented fruit, as well as wheat and spice. Sticky lacing all the way down. Mouthfeel was very full and heavily carbonated. It had a rice crispy effect in your mouth. Taste of lime, orange peel and  maple syrup.
Bottle from Liqourama.  Nice golden color with no head.  Very yeasty and citrus.  I did like the sourness too  The alcohol was hard to detect.  This was my first triple and I really enjoyed it.

Pours a sparkling, hazy gold with very little white head that rings the glass. Belgian yeast, soured fruit, citrus, and bread in the aroma. Very smooth drink. An excellent blend of lightly sweet sugared lemon and peach at first with a nice dry hop soured finish that lingers very nicely. Not unpleasantly tart or sharp like a lot of Belgians. No hint of the 9% ABV. One of my favorite tripels for sure.
This is good beer.  One of the best parts is the underlying abv presence, as it is not to overpowering.  Quite a treat if you like tripels.
Opaque gold. Very drinkable but a little clean. More pepper than I recall in other tripels, but not as complex.

Pours a golden with nice sized off-white head.  Nice fruity nose.  Flavor is very well balanced of fruit, some grannysmith apples with a touch of sweetness.  Great texture, one of the better tripels that I¬íve had.
Purchased at Beverages for Less in Santee. Side by side with the dubbel. This one wins. Bread dough aroma, with some sweet banana. Excelent flavors of the yeasty malts. Very good.

Bottle @ Kolding Bryglaug Americans tasting.
[thank you, SecretSanta!]
[vintage 2006 - batch 95]
Pours clear golden with a big, frothy, white head. Fine lacing. Aroma is lightly tart, some apples, lots of yeast. Super creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has lots of yeast, super dryness, lots of hops, yeast, vinious. Great tripel - one of the sweet ones. Thankfully there is lots of hops in there.

Pours hazy dark golden color with white head. Aromas of bread dough, bananas, citrus. Sweet flavor with Belgian yeast, citrus fruit and spices. Medium body with llively carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. One of the better Belgian tripels.

Had on tap at Taco mac. Pours to a bright red-orange color with nice thick off-white head that lingers well and leaves okay lacing. Initial nose is a pleasant mix of malty fruit and spices, and as the beer warms, the 9% abv makes itself known as well. Mouthfeel is full and slightly tingly, and the taste follows the nose perfectly, again with the alcohol making a late appearance. This all leads to a nice, well rounded finish.

Good job by Alagash in re-creating a Belgian classic.

750 ml Bottle(Batch 36) Thanks to HOPSCOTCH for the bottle-Pours an orangish amber with a small white head. Aroma of sugar, belgian yeast, citrus, coriander, and butterscotch. Taste is of alcohol and more alcohol with some sugars and cough syrup. I think the aging brought out big the alcohol flavor. A little bit too overpowering. I would like to try a newer vintage.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2012 750 from Whole Foods, Raleigh. Gotta say that I still really enjoy this brew, maybe the best American example of a tricky style. Lots of folks lay it on too buttery, and others too boozy. But Allagash gets it just right. Luminous amber pour with a trace of cloudiness and a billowy head. Some yeast and pepper in the nose, with some malts that don¬ít get in the way. When it¬ís young, there¬ís more pepper and I¬ím digging that right now - almost a pumped up saison imperial or something. But no, it¬ís true to the style, with rich malts and spices blending well, with an admirable hop backing. Always a pleasure to have this one.

The beer pours a very hazy orange yellow with a soft white head. The nose is a rich blend of coriander, citrus and yeast. The taste is what you would expect from a beer of this type, the taste closely follows the nose. The flavor is a highly carbonated mix of spice and citrus. The beer is a good example of this beer type but it is a little sweet. A few years of age might help is mellow out.

On draft at Redlight Redlight.  This beer pours an orange/ amber color with lots of light fruit and honey in the aroma, with a note of white grape?.  Lots of the bright flavors I expect from a tripel.  Good stuff, but not the best in the category.

Surprised I haven¬ít put my official rating in as I¬íve had this numerous times.  It¬ís one of the few great domestic Belgian Tripels.  Flavors are incredible mix of fruits and herbs.  Pours golden brown with nice frothy head.  Really excellent.

draft @ Taco Mac.  nice golden color... wonderful aromas of banana, spices and citrus.  Very smooth and soft over the palate.  The finish is very enjoyable with the citrus and spice coming through strong with some bitterness as well.  An excellent Tripel... ranks up there with the best... Looking forward to buying a bottle and having more...

Had this on draft.Poured a nice golden color with a hugewhite head.Aromas were of citrus and light banana.The taste was great with some honey and citrus.I think that this is up there with some of the better tripels including Chimay.

Batch #104.  Pours a hazy gold with huge head.  Heavy lacing.  Aroma of citrus and spice.   It is smooth and well balanced.  This beer hides the 9% well, but doesn¬ít hit me as anything more than a well rounded easy drinking beer.  I would purchase again at the same price.
Allagash Tripel Reserve has a clody golden yellow color with a nice white head and really good lacing. Smells very sweet and malty. Also fruity. Has a very fruity/banana taste. Very good tripel

Aroma is a Belgian yeast scent with a little banana.  Color is a hazy orange yellow with low carbonation and a thin head.  Taste is fruity and bitter.  Starting with a medium body it goes down crisp.  Finish comes in with a faint fruit yeast taste with a little clove, then a bitterness stomps over it.  After taste has a slight banana taste and the alcohol shows a little.  Not the best Tirple I¬íve had, its more like a strong ( high alcohol ) Hefe then A Triple.

a decent example of the style a bit too sweet in my opinion for the style....pear estery nose a bit flabby of a malt sweetness flavor.....but drinkable....not something I would ever buy though......give me more triple karmillet...andyday.....
Orange soda body with a creamy white head. Nice spicy, yeasty and fruity belgian nose. Sweet yeast and banana flavor. Strong spice and alcohol as well.

Light golden with a tiny bit of cloudiness and an ample white head.  The aroma is malty, yeasty, a bit sour, fruity - complex.  The flavor was a good balance of sweet, a little sour and a little bitter.  Good palate and carbonation. A very drinkable 9% alcohol tripel.

Bottle via trade with unclemattie.  Thanks again!  The pour was only slightly cloudy and was deep golden in color.  The head was two fingers plus in height and provided nice lacing.  The aroma was mild belgian yeast and then some sweeter malt and fruits taking over.  The flavor leaned more towards the ripe fruits and honey and didn¬ít  balance out as well with the spice and yeast that is often found with this style.  Very nice mouthfeel with the 9% abv being all but unnoticed.  Nice but mild.

Batch 103 - Pours a nice cloudy amber with a big fluffy white head that settles down to a fluffy 1cm which leaves some decent lacing.  Subtle spice/alcohol/citrus scent. Taste is slightly bitter and spicy with a similar finish. A decent example of the style, but I still prefer the Chimay. I¬íd buy this again and recommend it, though.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Pour is a bright but cloudy yellow with a large white head.  Aroma is nice with yeast, vanilla and fresh fruit.  Flavor is decent as well with lots of yeast and cirtus fruit.  Aftertaste leaves a nice berry on the tounge.  Above par tripel as this is not overly sweet and the alcohol is no prob.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2009 old rating:
6/4/7/3/14 - 3.4

batch #37
pours a semi-cloudy yellow-orange with a medium size bubbly off-white head that dissipates quickly, some lacing.

smell of grain, a touch of citrus, some banana, yeast, spice, and pear.

taste of banana, apricot, pear, some spice, yeast, pineapple, dough, and malt, ends a little dry.
Bottle of batch #109. Pours a slightly hazy orange yellow with white head. Slightly spicy fruit floral aroma. Taste is spicy floral with a little hops. Medium body. Very good tripel.

Wow. Pours a beautiful hazy yellow/brown color, with a thick head that leaves a nice lacing down the sides. Aroma is very floral with some understated herb/spice accents. Taste is floral with some big hop finishes. Spices detected in aroma provided a very good balance. Probably one of the best beers out there, would defnitely recommend.

A light copper, with a nice white head that stays well. Big aromas of yeast, and light peppery spice, alcohol. Flavor is the same with banana, heavy grass, spicey hops. A little overly sweet but I think it turns out really good. I liked this beer. The high rating is well deserved.

750ml Bottle. Batch 69. Probably my favorite Tripel of all time. Poured a hazy golden color with subtle orange hues. Aroma of many spices including black pepper and coriander, also a little honey and citrus(grapefruit). The head was white and somewhat lacey but stuck with it throughout. Easy to drink (slowly)
Flavor was excellent with intermittent spice notes from all around the palate, some bread yeasty flavors are present. Everything in this brew was perfectly balanced. Just after I tasted it out of the bottle, I left to by a 5 gallon keg. The next night I tapped the keg and was having trouble with foaming issues, by the time they subsided I was done for, asleep on the couch leaning on the kegerator, feelin great, the party hadn¬ít even started. When I awoke 2 hours later the keg was kicked and so were 20 other party goers. It was a little too easy to drink for the Alcohol content. Enjoy!!!

750 ml bottle from batch 106 from a trade with thecheeseman. pours golden with a big white head. aromas are typical triple with yeast dominating but noticeable malt sweetness. flavours are extremely complex. wheat, yeast, belgian sweetness, caramel, chewy malts, banana, buttery breadiness, cloves, spice, hops. all that doesnt make for the most drinkable brew and every sip tasted kind of different. this probably should have been cellared for a year to let it mellow but hey what can ya do. good but not the best triple ive had.

750ml bottle from BevMo Mission Valley. Pours gold with big white head and lots of bubbles. The aroma is zest, clove, honey, banana, and a hint of pepper. The flavor is banana bread with lots of autumnal spices. Warm finish and aftertaste. I am very impressed with the smoothness and balance of this one.

750mL bottle, Batch 83.  Poured clear bright golden with a well-retained creamy white head and sticky lacing.  The aroma picked up black peppery spices with sweeter pale malts and lighter fruits.. sweeter undertones of honey and banana.. very well balanced.  The flavor found tart lighter fruit skins and peppery spices over lighter fruits, mild toffee and honey sweetness.. again very well balanced.. spicy, engaging finish.  Creamy on the palate with full carbonation.. great balance between the sweet notes and the spices.  Excellent!
Bottle.  Batch 81.  Golden color, hazy with a nice head.  Aromas of fruit like banana and some malts.  Good for style.  Taste is sweet, alcohol is noticable but not too much.  Good beer.
Great aroma - fruits, belgian yeast, honey.  Loved the great interplay of the spicy flavors with subdued and controlled malty sweetness. Good.

Very nice...  as noted by several raters, it¬ís not as sweet as you would expect from a tripel, but for me that¬ís a plus.  Pours a hazy orange with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is of tropical fruits with the typical yeasty bite.  Flavor is a dry chardonnay-like fruitiness.  This is complimented by the yeastiness...  great american version of a belgian style.

750 ml bottle. The aroma is light stone fruit accompanied by sour. Hazy golden color with a lacing off-white head. Full bodied with creamy/chewy carbonation. Flavors are multiple. Bready malt, citrus, coriander, banana, other kinds of fruits. It is not sweet. It seems dry. It seems bitter. It seems to be a really good drink. The finish is clean and refreshing - weird to say that about a tripel. My mouth is puckering. It is a really good drink. Not that standard off-sweet tripel. Repeat: Good.

On tap at Jerry¬ís. Pale yellow-orange with good, off-white head / Estery, sour malt nose / Light to medium, lush body with good malts and long, sweet, dry finish / Flavors of banana, passion fruit, and coriander, and honey / Delicious.
Bottle (Batch 42): Pours a hazy gold with a white head, nice lacing. Aroma, peppery, yeast, bready malts, and some other spices. Flavor, doughy, spices, yeast, some light fruits, and floral notes.

Pours a cloudy light gold color with a medium pearly white head.  Smells of banana, orange citrus, coriander and other spices.  Great nose.  The flavor has a great spice character to it, alot of orange citrus and coriander, maybe some clove.  Well balanced with nice masking of the alcohol.  One of the better tripels Ive ever had.  a nice rendition of a usually boring style.  Fantastic!
Big white head on a beautiful golden pour.  Bold, penetrant, taste, from this great triple.  Well balanced with subtle undertones.  One of the best tripels I¬íve had.

On tap -- Light golden body, slight haze, terrific lacing from top to bottom.

Somewhat unexciting aroma of spices, fruits, yeast. Nothing mindblowing.

Initial mouthfeel is moderately carbonated. Taste is heavy citrusy fruits (orange, lemon), spices, initially malty, but a dry hoppy finish. I¬ím not tasting much of the 9%, either. Very drinkable.

Pours a cloudy yellow-gold with a  large frothy head and nice lacing. Aroma was very pronounced passion fruit, citrus hops and spices. The flavor was more fruity than the aroma would suggest. Soft yeast mixed with citrus is also apparent. Medium body, creamy texure. Average carbonation, long dry finish.

On draft this one poured a golden orange color with a medium foamy white head. The aroma is of sweet citrus and passion fruit with some belgian yeast and malts in there as well. Smells almost like fresh oranges. The flavor follows suit with the sweet citrus fruit and oranges coming through and blended with some candy sugar, honey, and belgian yeast. This one has a very sweet flavor to it with not too much spices in there like other tripels. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and almost creamy with a sweet sugary finish. The alcohol is masked really well in this one. I love all the sweet flavors this one had as it is probably my favorite tripel that I have had. I need to try more of their beers.

Bottle, batch #83.  Clear yellow-gold pour; much like apple juice or urine.  Aroma is like a mix of green grapes and green apples, with sugar and yeast.  The flavor also has the green grape component, some other malty fruit, alcohol, and some spices in the finish.  Pretty good beer, but the spices took over after drinking half the glass.
yellow hazy color with good creamy head, nose is fruity ( apples maybe) clove , yeasty. Flavor is belgian yeast sweet pale malts spicy. nice triple
good triple, great aroma and really hits the palate well.  One of, if not my favorite, abbey tripple

lightly carbonated ,citrusy aroma and taste.
Reminded me of an Allagash white but more complex.Will drink again.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, coriander, and spices.  Poured gold in color with a large, foamy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Sparkling.  Very hazy.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor of spices, cloves, pepper, coriander, yeast, and honey.  Medium to full body.  Lightly sticky texture.  Lively carbonation.  Spice finish.

On tap numerous times.  Hazy golden yellow color, stark white foam, very nice retention and lacing.  Aroma is a nice mix of restrained fruity esters with some notes of almost green hops.  Flavor is nicely complex, some very nice candi sugar notes surrounded by ripe fruit with a hint of hops and a balanced rich finish.

Slightly hazy orange appearance with thin off white head.  Aroma of spices and yeast.  Taste of hot spices, yeast, and fruits.  Dry aftertaste.  Medium mouthfeel with carbonation on the back of the throat.

Not hazy but not that clear, golden body with a good sized white head. Good carbonation. Aroma is pleasant, some banana, a little yeast and some candi sugar. Smooth taste, there is little banana in there but not much, zesty, more noticeable is the alcohol, medium to full body and nice spices to boot.

Batch 103. Orange, unfiltered look. Nice white head with nice lacing. Aroma of yeast, spice, arpicot. Sharp carbonation on the tongue. Light yeasty flavor, heavily spiced. Not as fruity as i had remembered. Carbonation and spice a little overwhelming. Good beer though

75 cl. Bottle. Clear golden colour with a nice huge white head. Aroma of bubble gum, yeast, spices, bread-like and citrus notes. Great flavour of malt, yeast, spices, honey very fruity, a nice eksample of the original abbey triples.

Batch 80.  Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Slightly hazy, light pale orange.  Orange spicey aroma.  Flavor is also very strong orange with spice, yeast, light fruit and earthy.  Medium bodied and well carbonated.  Very much in style.

750 ml, batch #98. Orange-golden with a four-finger, creamy pillow head and nice lace. Spicy yeast, citrus, and Juicy Fruit gum aroma. Vinous, fruity, yeast and sweet malt flavors are well balanced by some toasted nut, caramel, peppery alcohol, and a hint of bitter herbs. Body is on the lighter side of light-medium, alcohol-tingly, and smooth but disconcertingly airy and effervescent at the same time. Crisp, dry, apple martini-and-herb finish gives good balance to the caramel malt and bubblegum ester flavors.

May 2006 - Batch 74.   Pour was pale yellow with nice, but quickly dissipating head, minimal lacing.  Aroma and flavor was spicey and wheaty.  Flavoe might have been a tad too sweet and very peppery.  Touches of banana and strong yeast presence as well.  Pretty darned good for an American attempt (better than Golden Monkey), but definitely isn¬ít top notch.

My first thought was "I am pouring silk into a glass!".  The head came out very silky.  Slightly amber/yellow.  Small uniform bubbles puff into a cloud like pillow of awesomeness.  After a minute or two the head quickly dissipates into a thin layer of bubbles that form a prairie on a far away fantastic planet.  What I mean is that it falls unevenly.  The color of the elixir is a light golden.  It is cloudy enough to be completely opaque.  Nothing can be seen through the glass with the exception of light.  Holding in front of a source of light makes the beer appear to generate its own happy glow.

The aroma is sweet and a touch heady.  It has that indefinable (until I review more beers:) scent that I correspond with Belgium beers.  Almost sickly sweet; as if a honeysuckle has been sitting in the sun for a few hours.  Nothing freshly plucked about it.  Although this beer (on the top of the smell stack) does have some fresh sweetness.  The smell overall is a touch too light - my nose is yearning for just a hair more.

The flavor hits me first with the sweetness then sharply drops off and my taste buds hit a near vertical wall of this sweet-dropping-off effect.  Then the taste takes a visual jump and comes back a little smoky.  From the third taste on this sharp drop and rise effect mellows out into a more smooth visualization.  The taste is a slow climb, then a slow decline of flavor.  Almost like a slight frown.  But there are no frowns about this brew - it¬ís frickin delicious.  It hits me as fruity - almost like a dried apricot that was rubbed with some raisins.  This beer is incredibly drinkable.  I¬ím glad the bottle is more than just one pour.  A quick swallow sometimes brings a bit of sharpness to the back of the throat.  So this is definitely a beer to drink slowly.

The palate is smooth with a touch of tickle from the carbonation.  It slides smoothly, yet it is still thin.  It says to me "I am very drinkable, but I have substance, so take heed and don¬ít drink me like water".  I feel like as I near the end of the glass the palate becomes more viscous, but still very slippery.

Overall I truly enjoy this beer.  I would drink it again.  The bottle is numbered by batch number.  I am partaking in batch #102.  One thing to note is that there is a slight sign of mold on the top of the cork (underneath the metal pull down).  It¬ís dry, but seems that it was wet at one point; maybe during transportation?  I have been storing the beer on its side.  The solids in the beer fell to the side and stuck to the bottle.  It doesn¬ít seem that any solids make it into the beer, but I¬ím a true believer in not trying to avoid the solids - I believe they are part of the experience of a particular beer.  On a side note - this beer goes very well with "Neutral Milk Hotel" on the speakers.  As I near the end of this fantastic experience I note that I can feel the alcohol.

Really really good. I didn¬ít know what to expect from this, but the subtle sweetness of this beer is delicately balanced and serves to cement this Maine beer¬ís place along side some of the great Belgian Tripels.

I really enjoyed this one.  The aroma slaps your senses when the bottle is opened.  Visually, it would be hard to find a prettier one.  The body of this beer has all shades of yellow, gold and orange...a sunset in a glass.  The head is a thick merrange and the taste is that of citrus, banana, and honey.  This beer is juicy...extremely tasty...get it if you can!!!

Pours a pale hazy yellow with a two finger creamy white head.  The aroma was soft, yeasty, some Belgian characterstic, spicy, . The flavor was very spicy, coriander and curacao, wheat, earthy, banana, and a little alcohol. Very nice tripel. Dry finish, bitter mouthfeel with a little bit of alcohol.

The color was a light hazy golden.  The head was creamy, thin, and white.  The aroma was yeast, spice, grass, and alcohol.  The flavor was strong, spicey, hoppy, and alcohol.  The palate was lively.  The finish was warm.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 Bottle. Pours a light golden with a nice frothy white head. The aroma is mostly malts, spice and banana. The taste is really smooth; some coriander, holiday spices, malts, a slight fruity aspect also. Really nice and easy to drink. A well made beer.

Pours golden with a nice frothy head of tiny white bubbles.  Aroma is a bit lacking, but has some of the usual spice and bread like aromas you¬íd expect in a triple.  The flavor is excellent with the perfect balance of sweet fruit, spice and a tiny touch of alcohol.  Extremely easy to drink this one.
A good triple and an excellent beer.

Hazy orange pour with a huge and lasting white head.  Aroma is of yeast, banana, melon, citrus and spice.  Creamy mouthfeel, full-bodied.  Lots of pepper up front, nice and spicy.  Middle tames a bit with more of the melon and some honey.  Banana towards the finish.  It¬ís all over the place really.  Lots to enjoy.  I didn¬ít detect any alcohol but for the slight warming finish. Too tasty and easy to drink, this one is dangerous.  But great!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 I was really surprised how much i enjoyed this one. Nicely sourish, lemony aroma, mixed with a touch of melon. Flavor is sweet at first, but overwhelming. nice flinty notes, then a bit of herbal bitterness. As it warms, notes of rye, perhaps even sage emerge. Very satisfying and tasty.

Fantastic
Little heavy on alcohol but good. good good
Need to have one in front of me to really rate it of course

Batch # 54. Cloudy lemon yellow hue with a 2 finger white head with tan colored specks suspended. Spicy, peppery smell with a whiff of alcohol. Medium bodied with a prickly, highly carbonated mouthfeel. 
Earthy, woody, spicy grain flavor here; pretty complex with a hint of black pepper, lemon and other fruits. Has a soft alcohol taste to finish. 
Not overly sweet like some triples, my favorite of all the domestic brands I¬íve tasted so far.2005
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Batch # 58 (Aged). Pours a barely translucent golden yellow with a great pure white head. Immediate explosion of spiced fruit esters fill the room. Tropical fruits, cherry, banana yeast, orange peel, clove, candied sugars and super sweet candy malt all hit the nose. First taste is super spiced and super sweet malt with tropical fruits lingering on the palate. Great yeast quality with some pineapple, green apple, clove, cherry, banana, more sweet malt, and alcohol warming. Smooth as can be and full bodied with a slight bitter edge on the finish. I now have a warm stomach and spicy breath, couldn¬ít have asked for better aging.

Batch #94.  Barely translucent carmel in color.  The nose shows off wonderful spices along with orange pulp, carmel, nuts and citrus.  These flavors continued into a smooth and balanced beer with a finish that lingers with some bitnerness.

Batch #84. Damn pleasant beer. I really can¬ít fault Rob on his brewing, and Allagash is starting to be my favorite American brewer. Beautiful color, pours with the perfect small bubbled head, 3-4 cm cream-white head. You can taste a sweet cherry-like yeast, and little pear on the nose. Apple/Pear on the tongue, just the right balance of sweet and fizz, and a little tang on the back of the throat. Easily one of the best American beers of the last 5 years. (Bottle Pour 1/2/2007)

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel".  Pours a clear yellow with a white head.  Citrus and grain nose.  Not very distinct.  Citrus, pear, really fruity.  Earthy, tangy, alcohol.  Hop presence.  Finishes dry with the alcohol and earthy notes.  Ok.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 Bottle. Pours cloudy straw colored w/ voluminous foamy head. Sour, yeasty aroma. Taste is very smooth and fruity, reminiscent of green apple.
a truly amazing tasting beer have no complaints other then pour it slowly theres alot of head that come with this beer.
murky golden pour with a white head that lasts a while.  lots of fruit on the nose.  a lot of carbonation and fruit with a very tart aftertaste.

Straw and wheat, slightly cloudy.  Fluffy white head.  Lots of fizzies.  Lacing.  Smells dry, like a wine.  The flavor is predominately bananas and esters, with a dry sweetness and hoppy/spicy finish.  Lovely.
Bottle from 5 Points pours straw colored w/ a extremely small head w/ good retention.  Standard tripel here.  Fruity, spicy, mildly nutty flavors.  Good, but nothing special.

sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours clear, pale gold with white head. nose of cloves, yeasty, citrus. flavor is citrusy, orange peel, alcoholy, toasted biscuit. lively carbonation, decent stuff.

draft @ redlight redlight. Candy sugar, sweet malts, and spicy hops in the aroma.  Pours yellow/orange blonde with a thin white head.  Sweet malts, cotton candy, sligtly sour, sweet and dry upfront, thing slightly sour, with a dry finish.  Malty, sweet, some hints at citrus, candy sugar, spicy hops, with a good dry finish.  great beer, SOLID!.

Draft at Rick¬ís in Murraysville, PA.  Pours a deep hazy golden color with a thick foamy head with nice lacing.  I didn¬ít get much of a nose from it... perhaps a little clove.  It was really sweet and had a strong cherry-medicinal taste.  A little bit of yeast and alcohol in the flavor too.  I¬íve liked everything else from Allagash, so this might have just been an older keg.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Batch 96-750ml bottle-  opens with a nice pop. nice cloudy golden pour with a quickly disappearing one finger  head. Noted a slight fruity aroma, nothing strong. Carbonation was present and a nice fruit flavor. No alcohol detected and this was very drinkable. I waited for this one and it was well worth it. Well done for my first Allagash brew.

Bottle. Poured hazy golden, with a moderate sized white head. Spicy, yeasty aroma, with coriander, flowers, and aome alcohol. Flavor is big on wheat, along with spice, tropical fruit, wheat, citrus, pepper, and alcohol. Really nice tripel.
Batch 79.  Very nice tripel that I will be be buying again.  Smooth flavors of banana and citrus that balance the alcohol well.  Very drinkable.
Batch 102. Subtle flavors. Unlike some American tripels, the tastes don¬ít come out strong. Otherwise, I get the typical banana and spice. Fruits. Nice. A little too much carbonation.

Bottle shared with Quevillon. The color is a hasy blond with an off white thick head. The taste is a mix of spicies, fruits and sweet fruits and also citrus fruits with that great taste of malt.The alcohol % is not that noticeable. This was one great beer.

750 ML Bottle-Batch #84-Yellow orange w/a moderate white head. Sweet Belgian Aroma. Flavor of candied sugar, yeast, spice, wheat & citrus. Has a fair amount of carbination. Easy to drink, alcohol is well hidden. Long sweet finish. Quite good.

Bomber bottle batch #103. I followed the label instructions and let this warm up to cellar temp before opening. Nice pop of the cork. It poured a cloudy golden amber color with a thin wispy head. The aroma was crisp and sweet with a fragrance of alcohol. The flavor was very nice. It started with a nice light bite and a sweetness that wasn¬ít overpowering. There was plenty of carbonation and a bit of a spicy taste. In all a nice combination of flavors that left you guessing at what the flavor you are tasting now was.

A 750 ml bomber with pouring instructions and a loud pop when uncorking went a long way towards reminding me of the sampling occasions of several wonderful original Tripels from Belgium.  The body was cloudy yellowish orange and a lot of foam formed atop it in the tulip.  The smell was a tropical forest full of flowering trees.  The flavor contained banana, oranges, white pepper, cookie dough, and lemon juice.  The clean and majestic taste avoided the one flaw I¬íve dreaded in American versions of the style, that of being too sweet.  The dusty, yeasty dryness was quite welcome and refreshing.  Soothingly rich in the mouth, and well carbonated, so resounding burps abounded.  The label says that this is well suited for cellaring, and it would definitely make an interesting experiment.

I had this on tap at my local, in proper glassware. It looked wonderful:  a cute, foamy head with creamy, paint- like lacing over a rich honey-gold body. The aroma was strong and rich also, almost too much so--very sweet and yeasty. The taste was very strong as well and in the same way, with lots of sweet fruitiness and yeast. Hops aren¬ít very evident at all, but the beer does get a little more bitter the further you go into it. The kick wasn¬ít obvious at first, but quite powerful by the time I was done. The palate was the biggest problem for me, and the main reason I can¬ít make this a 4. To tell the truth, I had the same problem with this that I have had with so many hefeweizens. The palate is just way too full and bloaty for me, with much more carbonation and more yeast than I can handle comfortably. In fact, the palate was so heavy that it was hard for me to finish the glass. Combine that with a very strong kick and a very strong flavor and you have a beer that is quite a handful for many drinkers. This is a good beer, no question, and many rate it higher, but I can¬ít in all honesty do the same. It¬ís very much worth a try, especially for lovers of Belgians, but give me something a bit less bloat-provoking, please.
From a bottle poured nice light amber flavor, with a lot of head.  Flavorwas light and refreshing, with a good strong finish.

750 ml, Duvel glass. Pours a delectable orange-gold with voluminous fluffy white head. Nice islands of lacing left on the glass. Nose is rather wheaty, strong lemon peel citrus, a bit of yeasty snap, grassy/hay hops, candi sugar.  Rather nice and full on the palate, fluffy, very smooth towards the finish, minty hop bitterness slowly creeps up and envelops the palate.  A rather nice American tripel.

750 ml bottle - Pours a hazy golden color with a 3/4 finger thick white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is yeast, esters, and bread.  Flavor is yeast and esters with a touch of spice.  A smooth, medium body beer.  Good stuff.

Unclear orange with a fine white lasting creamy head & lacings. Aroma is of yeast, fruits - peach & orange, alcohol & some spices. The alcohol bites the cheek a bit and the carbonation is quite high. Other than that its a full bodied well crafted tripel. Light sweet & sticky before a dry end!

batch #105.  cloudy dark gold pour with a small white head.  flavors of creamed corn, citrus hops and yeast.  aroma hops(grass) and yeast.  medium bodied.  not a bad beer, but i enjoyed some of their other offerings a lot more.

Bottle thanks to NachlamSie. Blind tripel tasting with Chimay CInq Cents, Westmalle Tripel, and Tripel Karmeliet with NachlamSie and Muenster. The pour is a cloudy golden with a pale white lasting head. The aroma is spicy with a caramel sweetness and pear citrus. As the brew hits the tongue, the citrusy pear and orange is slightly dominant over the spiciness, but not by much. As the brew progresses its decent down the tongue into the throat, the spiciness becomes more apparent, overpowering the citrus and sweetness. As it passes the tongue, hops qualities surprisingly arise along with a quick burst of spiciness. In the end, the hops, spice, citrus, and sweetness levels nearly evenly. It¬ís really nice and complex and is my favourite out of the four in the blind tasting.

Pours bright golden and mostly receding off-white head. Aroma of coriander, honey, pepper, and alcohol. Taste is sweet, citric, yeasty with notes of earthy malt, honey, flowery esters. Mouthfeel is full bodied, lightly sticky with lush carbonation. Very nice tripel.

10/6/07 bottle.  Foggy yellow color.  The smell isn¬ít entirely awful - it seems to be a mix of sour patch kids candy and feet.  Overly bubbly on the palate.  Taste is strange and just not very complex in my opinion.
Pours light orange with a nice big white head.  Aroma of honey, lemon, citris.  Taste is roughly the same.  Nice beer to go with food.
Pours orange with a rather large head. Aroma of fruit and honey. Very nice beer.

Poured a hazy light orange color with a giant creamy head. Sweet smell of citrus fruits. Taste was sweet honey, citrus and banana. Very good tripel and I enjoyed it much. Alcohol was very well hidden!

McChouffe trappist glass. Pours out a hazed orange with a thin, but dense head that fades to a sudsy film. There is some particulate matter sinking to the bottom even with trying to avoid this by pouring painfully slow. The aroma is vibrant, light (tropical) fruits, some floral notes, honey, corriander and a bit of that bubblegum goodness, along with suggestions of horseblanket. The flavour is as fruity as the nose implies but instead of honey I¬ím getting a caramel malt backbone. Slight bitterness arises from the yeasty complex and alcohol content, but not in a way that is offensive. There is warth throughout the taste but most notable in the finish. The finish is long and leaves behind herbal notes. The mouthfeel is tingly and medium bodied. Very easy to drink, but of course it is better to sip.

This beer pours a cloudy orange color with mild particulate matter that sincks right to the bottom. There was no head since it faded quickly but that could be due to the glass since i poured to glasses and one had a head and one did not. It has a nice clove and citrus smell to it. Initially there is a lot of carbonation with citrus flavors and is rather tangy. Over time as the beer itself warms up you can taste alot of honey on the sides of your mouth as well as the palate. I really enjoy the honey after taste since it is very sweet.
Aroma of white grapes and oranges.  Flavors of honey, coriander, heather.  Finish is dry and bready.

Bottle as shown. Batch #75. Pours a pale light yellow color with a medium frothy off white head. The aromas is very fruity and floral. Very good lacing on this one. The taste is very sweet and fruity with a dry finish. This is an excellent abbey tripel from Allagash.

bottle.  Golden, white head with attractive lacing.  Citrus, bubble gum, fruits, yeast, spice. Excellent balance.  A very good triple, maybe a little thin, but quite well done.  Allagash is one of the more impressive brewers in the US.

RB #1900. 75 cL bottle (batch 95). Pours hazy orange with a dense and a huge and light orange head. Aroma sweet malty with a decent level of belgian yeast note and some spices. Smooth mouthfeel, softly textured. Flavour starts sweet malty, nice and smooth caramel flavour. A classic yet nice yeast flavour takes over and goes into the finish with a slight herbal note and a distinct bite before the end. Lovely a great balance. Very well made.
Cloudy gold,huge white head.Nose of spicy yeast/banana. Malty,yeasty, alcoholic, hops are an afterthought here

Caged corked 750 ml. bottle, Batch #90, short blurb and serving suggestions along the left side of front label, sampled in a wide mouth wine glass.

Cloudy bottle conditioned appearance, lush golden orange color, frothy, dense white head, good retention, fair amount of laced sticking.

An appealing nose, tropical fruits, honey and subtle banana, medicinal herbs that mesh with the estery alcohol. Everything is pretty much as advertised. 

The airy carbonation helps lighten the feel of the medium body, making this a smooth pleasant sipper, well rounded in the palate. Begins with warm spicy alcohol mildly stinging the tongue, followed by honey grains and candied sugar. The alcohol keeps it¬ís warmth through out the taste. Tart tropical fruits in the middle, the yeast turns an earthy spice in the end. Finishes dry, pale grains and earthy, fruity yeast, along with a palate cleansing effect from the spicy alcohol.

This is a delightfully complex tripel from Allagash, I wish this was regularly available in my area.

I¬ím a big fan of Allagash.  I love what they do to push the boundaries of brewing.  This beer was nothing less than what I expected.  Pours a beautiful dark golden color with very little head.  Aroma was not strong and overpowering, but you definitely get some sweet floral/fruity notes.  Flavor is a beautiful sweet blend of fruits and honey.  Strong presence on your palate.  Excellent complex brew.
Pretty light head, dark orange-golden color.  Very slight aroma, complex but subtle.  Strong mouth, great finish. I strongly recommend it.

My immediate reaction is alcohol in the aroma.  Lots of yeast I can smell some banana.  Orangy gold, small white head.  Lots of bubbles. Wow, great beer. Lots of alcohol in the front, some hops.  Aftertaste of alcol, but tons of sweet cake in the finish.  Love it.  Full bubbly mouthfeel

bomber.  average white frothy head that left too soon.  cloudy orange body.  aromas of light honey, light citrus, sugared candy, bubble gum (yeast), and very light alcohol.  flavor is sweet with light bitterness that presents in the middle and intensifies in finish.  long finish duration.  one of the best tripels i have had the pleasure of rating.
Pours a golden-yellow color.  Has a fruity, yeasty smell with a similar taste.  The mouthfeel is very lively.  A good tripel, recommended.

Light bright orange pour with a bubbly quickly fading head.  Smell is like every fucking belgian i¬íve ever had.  That awful funky, rotten yeast smell that I abhor, only with a bit of rotten fruit and alcohol covering it up.  Taste is lightly fruity, dry bland sweetness.  Uninteresting, and a complete drainpour for me.  I¬íd rather drink any pale lager.
Not as great as I had hoped, I would much prefer Chimay (white), but like most Tripels, definately enjoyable.

batch #96. pours a cloudy dark yellow with a one finger fluffy white head. aroma is wheat, yeast, and banana with some lemon and a touch of hops. has a medium body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but stronger with some bread. not to bad kind of a weiss tripel combo. the hops come out a little more as it warms in the flavor. also the carbonation is lively on the tongue.

Pours a slightly hazy gold body. Aroma is candy sugar sweet, herby and a little earthy. Flavour is sweet and yeasty with s spicy tinge.  Turns to an earthy grassy hop bitterness as it finishes.  Well balanced brew.
Light grain and light yeast aroma. Nice balance. Cloudy pale orange color with a large white head. Light fruit malt taste. Not as grapish as other tripels. Good amount of carbonation.

Corked bottle, batch 102. Pale gold in color. Clover, a hint of citrus, and a touch of banana in the aroma. The taste is very clove, spice, corriander, and yeasty too. The finish is long and dry, but in a good way.
Draft at Capones. Looks like a tripel. Smells like a tripel. Soild beer nothing wrong, but again nothing special. A soild interpretation of the style.

Bottle. Fantastic balance in this aroma. Caramel malt, lemon hops, and a moldy basement for the yeast. I also noted an undescribable spice, and pumpkin. Head is very fizzy, white and thick which diminishes slightly and has excellent lacing. It poured crystal clear amber in the begining, then got hazier as I went deeper into the bottle. Taste starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then the long finish is lightly sweet and bitter and moderately acidic and just a touch sour. Palate is light to medium, between watery and oily and has a lively carbonation. It finishes slightly astringent. If Belgian tripels were my favorite style the overall score could¬íve easily been an 18 or 19.

Pours a hazy golden colour with a frothy rocky off white head. Aroma is clovey, ripe fruits, grassy, yeast and hints of spice. Initial taste is  sweet, apple & heavy clove. Finshing with a banana, yeast and bitter hops on the palate. Palate duration is good, nice lacing of the glass, and good head retention. Sticky mouthfeel.

Date: 02/08/2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Sunset, Boston

cloudy yellow, fine white head, lots of lace, sweet spicy aroma, thick body, sweet spick flavor, nice esters, light oaky character with a touch of vanilla, light bitter finish

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

750, corked and caged. Pours a cloudy and very dark straw color with a towering, foamy platinum blonde head. Rings of sedimentary lace. Soft, sugary nose: fruity, definite pitted tree fruit there of the red variety. Cotton candy as well. Smells suspiciouly like their Grand Cru, in fact. Medium body, soft carb, hides the alcohol well. Has a tart crispness that the Grand Cru gets by without; that would be the primary difference between the two. Not much finish. Not all that exciting a beer.
12 oz. bottle.  light golden pour.  minimal head.  sweet nose.  sweet warm swallow.
Pale yellow of color with a white head. An aorma of spice, sweetsand oak -as saison. A flavor with some sweets and spices.

Caged and corked, batch #97.  Poured a nice yellow-tinged orange with a thin but sustained head.  The aroma is lightly yeasty and moderately induced with citrus.  The drink is musty and earthy with a creamy tone.  Banana, yeast, corriander, maybe a hint of ginger, grass, grape cider.  Very nice.  (#3058, 8/17/2007)
sampled at brookline liquor mart, alchol too strong and overpowed  taste and smell, hard to pick up grain notes over fruity tone.

Batch 97 from a 750 ml bottle.  pale golden beer, crystal clear with a pillowy white head.  Aroma is spicy with a soft apricot fruity sweetness.  Slightly earthy on the nose as well with a soft bready maltiness that is quite unusual in this style.  Very fruity, especially as it warms, giving off apple, pear, peach, apricot and a hint of banana with a soft wheaty background.  There is a soft caramelly sweetness in back along with the bready character.  Fruits seems overly ripe and the beer starts to get cloying.  This bottle probably could have used another six months on it.

Golden with nice, white persistent head, good lacing; pretty to look at.  Wheaty, yeasty aromas with fruity, citrus spice scents as well.  Flavors of wheat, banana, and fruit; with lingering spice and lengthy dry finish.  Alcohol is well disguised considering the high abv.  Very nice tripel

Golden pour, extremely frothy.  Aroma of honey, grass, yeast and alcohol.  Kind of like an overweight pils.  Hint of Christmas spice and gingerbread.  Strong and sweet on the tongue.  A messy, hot green apple mash  with bananas long since browned.  Sugary and a little sulphuric.  Wet hay sitting in the sun, and iron.  Palate is slightly abrasive especially as it warms quite quickly.  Smacks a a bit sour.  This one really never came together.  Thanks Andrew!

(Bottle) Pours amber. Incense, clove, and cardamom in aroma with some more subtle notes of spices, herbs and yeast. Flowery and light grassy hops. Also notes of bananas and some even more exotic fruits. Rather creamy nose. Creamy malt and yeast in flavour some spices and fruits to back it up. Light dry and medium bodied. One of the best US triples out there.
Unclear yellow with a small white head. Strong spicy aroma with alcohol and fruit, peach in particular. Big flavour, dry and fruity, and wonderfully easy to drink.

750ml Batch 98. Yellowish golden ale w/ large white head, a bit of cloudiness.  Nose of sweet goodness (yeast, hops & alcohol). Taste is a battle between yeast & spices, both heavy-weight contenders... some might have called it a draw but I give it to the spices.  Pepper, clove, honey, and anise(?). Really comes across Belgian. Impressive & truly a champ.

Tastes like honey and yeast and malt. Pours a nice saturated yellow color with a decent sized soapy head. Tastes like honey and malt. Pretty good but I was surprised to see it was considered one of the best.

Bready,doughy yeast aroma,quicly mixed with and then dominated by apple-peach fruit. Taste is that doughy yeast with touchs of honey,vanilla,banana, and soon alcohol,has a little grainey hop harshness in finish. Well done for style,just something I would not reorder because of yeast domination

bottle.  golden/orange pour.  carbonated to frothy white head.  big yeast, malt and spice.  corriander, peach and appricot.   I couldn¬ít put my finger on it until reading description but honey as well.  full malty body. yeast and fruity.  pepper bitter finish.  slight alcohol warming.  well done.

Pours a hazy yellow with a lacy white head.  Aroma is largely citrus and slight banana.  Taste is the same, with spice, clove, and some slight honey included as well.  Mouthfeel is incredible, definitely at least one of the best examples of a tripel I¬íve ever tasted.

Bu en √©chantillon, √† la brasserie (bouteille de 355 ml.). Blonde dor√©e riche et brumeuse, moyen collet vanille. Arome de malte √©pic√© et de sucre et fruit l√©g√© et d√©licat. Go√ªt de malte de fruits √©pic√©, des note de cr√®me sucr√©. R√©chauffant et doux.

Bottled. 
Yellow colour, good head. Good malty vanilla aroma without the expected, sometime yuky sweetness in tripels. Great pale malty mouthfeel with no obvious flavour profile, this is fruity and floral and just balanced.

Bottled.
Deep golden with a large head.
Malty and rather vinous aroma; yeasty.
Fruity and spicy flavour; apricots, raisins, coriander, pepper.
Hazxy yellow color. Yeasty, fruity aroma with a malt profile. Yeasty, malty flavor, some fruity notes. Good, but a bit onedimensional.

Bottle thanks Marsiblursi. Hazy deep golden with a large fluffy white head. Earthy malt aroma with clear notes of cauliflower, and some woody and yeasty notes as well. Medium bodied and smooth. Good balance, dry finish.

Bottle(Tax to Marsiblursi)
Red clear colour nice creamy head.
Aroma of yeast,hops,hay,gras vegetable,fruits.Flavor is citric-flowers,nice balanced hops,fruity. Medium body, and a nice fruity medium long finish,. Werry nice!

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 Bottle from MCAS Miramar Marine Mart:  
Hazy rich golden color with a medium, but fading white head. Aroma is spicy and tropical fruit sweet. Flavor starts fruity sweet (peach/apricot) with spice followed by a light citrus bitterness and a lightly dry orangy finish. Medium bodied and creamy with moderate carbonation. Alcohol well hidden, but makes its presence known.

Hazy golden pour with soft orange glints at the perimeter. Visible yeast in suspension, a cloud of life in the center of the glass. The head is tall, rocky, compacted, well retained and leaves awesome lacing in its wake. The aroma is lovely and is immediately recognizable as a top notch tripel with an unmistakably Belgian influence. In other words, this smells like the real deal. Notes of candy sugar, ample yeast, tart and sweet tropical fruits, dusty pepper, honey, appleskins, touches of cloves and well integrated alcohol. Lovely. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, quite yeasty, with fruit notes even further accentuated by a simple, forthright alcohol component. wheated malt is plentiful in character, though I get the feeling this is an illusion of sorts. The finish is smooth, sweet at first, then very dry and lightly sticky. Mouthfeel is mildly sticky, medium to medium-full bodied, moderately to highly carbonated and very luxurious, without any flavor clumping together or seeming muddled by excessive sugary sweetness. An excellent example of the style, easily one of the best produced in the United States. I¬íd expect nothing less from this brilliant brewery.

Bottle, batch #83.  Slightly cloudy gold in color.  Medium head.  Apple aroma.  Persistent finish a nice surprise to the relatively light body.  Agree with the alcohol comments below.  Like a yeastier better-balanced Tripel, myself.

[bottle, batch # 95] Pale orange/brown, hazy colour.  Moderate head. Fruity citrus aroma. Dry, spicy (aniseed) flavour with the alcohol being way too dominant. A beer for the cellar, pity I don¬ít have a cellar :o(
xxx Batch 74, great beer, definitely happy with this one.  A nice 750ml bottle that did me well.
Bottle at K√∏benhavnske √∏ldage 07. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheat, fruit, banana. Flavour is sweet, banana, wheat, fruit, alcohol, spices. Nice beer.
bottle shared with brie.  The flavors are bitter and spicy.  It tastes like grassy bananas and alcohol.  The 9% tastes great with the spice.  Good american triple.

Bottled at K√∏benhavnske √òldage. Clear, golden beer with a white head. Wheat, fruit, banana, spices and hops in the aroma. Wheat, alcohol, banana and spices in the flavor. Nice flavor, but there¬ís more to it in the nose. Full, sweetish mouthfeel, and a long, hopped and spiced finish. Quite nice it is!   (070511)

Blonde-amber. Nose is alcohol and grain. Pours barely any head with yeasty white swirls among the definition. Very crispy taste, almost typical Belgian characters of wheat, roasted grain, finishing out with Brazil nuts and banana. Slightly metallic aftertaste. Refreshing.

Clear medium gold with a decent white head. Big Belgian nose: fruity and yeasty. Flavor is rich and smooth:pums, raisins, toffee, and a vinous note or two. Notable alcohol presence. Lightly astringent on the palate, but mildly silky for all that. Very nice.
On tap at Capone¬ís. Cloudy amber/orange. Banana type yeast, with apricot and spices. Lite brown sugar sweetness. Citrusy finish. A bit warm. Very good.

#94 fluffy lingering head. aromas of honey, malt and yeast with a big face full of alcohol. flavor is yeasty with light lemon and mango. soap/ coriander and white pepper are in there as well. honey like sweetness is in the mix but not over   powering. lots of alcohol lacing through.
Sampled at Capones on Allagash night with Stegosaurus. Hazy Golden Pour With honey and fruit aroma. Alcohol was very noticeable in taste along with a mild bread feel. Pretty good.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours a clear, warm, golden with a creamy, off-white head leaving a broad curtain of lacework. Complex, fruity aroma with a whiff of yeast. Rich and full body with lots of fruit - some pineapple and perhaps a touch of coconut. Some yestiness and a distinct, warming alcohol in the finish. 180607

I actually really enjoyed this beer, it is one of the better allagash¬ís i have had.  I didnt find it very bitter compared to some of the reviews i have read, it left a sweet spicy taste in my mouth.  Poured nicely, golden orange with a white head and a strongy banana aroma to it.   Maybe a little over rated for the money, but a good beer all and all.

NorCal tasting June ¬í07 - While most of the time, I really enjoy Allagash beer, this was a bit of a let down. Tripel¬ís are also not on the top of my favorite style list, so that could also have something to do with my poor reception of this beer. Aroma was doughy, mashed banannas with an old yeasty smell. Appearance was brilliant with a medium golden color and a brilliant white head. Mouthfeel was a bit minerally for me, verging on almost being too harsh. Flavor was more of the mashed banannas with a bit of clove and sour apples. Not really my thing.
Fully golden colour with a white head. Malty, sweet fruity aroma with hoppy and spicy notes. Malty and quite spicy flavor with fruity and floral notes. Light dry and sweet finish.

Murky golden pour at the SD County fair from the bottle. Nice sweet aroma of pear and peach. Rich flavors of fruit and some yeast without alcohol strongly noted. Smooth on the palate with a lovely finish. Quite nice for a tripel.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden/orange colour. The aroma is sweet with spices, caramel and has a bready maltiness. The flavour is sweet, with a good toasty maltiness, yeast, spices, caramel, fruits and hops. The finish is spiced and malty. Great brew!

K√∏benhavnske √òldage 07. Golden with a nice aroma with notes of yeast, coriander and biscuits. The flavour has sweetness, notes of caramel, coriander, fruit and citrus. It has a nice balance, but IMO it¬ís a bit too sweet. 2121

Batch 97.  Pours a hazy, orangey-golden color with an average, white, frothy head; a small amount sticks around persistantly with tight lacing.  Nose is lovely with yeast and bananas over the top with nice cloves and cinnamony pie crust below.  Light notes of ripe peaches and herbally spices.  Flavor is nice but without the pie crust notes and more spiciness and bitterness than expected.  Yeast is still dominant with fruits of banana and light ripe peach.  Other notes of faint honey and spices of cloves, pepper, and herbs; moderate bitterness matches the spiciness.  Soothing is a good way to describe the palate, as the description goes, with it being medium bodied, soft feeling, creamy, and moderate carbonation.  Finishes quite long with herbs, pepper, yeast, and a faint remainining cinnamon.  One of the best tripels I¬íve had to date with such a good balance between spicing, bitterness, fruits, and yeast.  Herbal characteristics make for an interesting twist on a fairly straight forward style.

Bottle.70cl. Batch 95. My first Trippel from the land of  faith, hope and charity, and im filled with blind faith, and hope that they will take my hand and walk me in too a new view of the trippel.......... but no.......Sorry. the taste of yeast is a bit out of controle and not in the in the Belgian way, it is the taste of slurry, and not propertyes of the belgiean yeast.
Bottle, 9% at K√ò07. Asparagus aroma. Cloudy golden colour. The flavour has a little asparagus, too, but it is still nice. Quite peppery and spicy. Not bad.

Batch # 68 found at the Liquor Depot in CO Springs, CO. and stashed in my cellar for a year or two.  Cloudy gold color with massive head.  Malt nose with a hint of sweetness and spice and a similar body.

Poured a hazy golden with a billowing white head in a wide-mouthed Trappist glass.  Nose was spicy and alive with some doughy malt notes.  Palate was absolutely smooth and silk-like.  Flavor was many of the best in the tripel style:  nice spicy herbal quality, cinnamon, pear, and many more.  This brew was so good that it reminded me of the excellence of Allagash.  It also reminded me to rate beers that are well made, something I hadn¬ít done in months.  It¬ís wonderful how eye-opening a solid brew can be.
