UPDATED: JUN 23, 2005 pale gold color, big creamy white head, almost smells like a pilsner, head fades away and coats the sides of the glass, the aroma has elements of grass and citrus. flavor is spicy and sweet grassy hops, elements of banana as well.  the aftertaste is the downfall of this brew, as it is metallic and bitter.  lots of tingle in the mouthfeel from a load of carbonation.RERATE: after having a batch 37 bottle courtesy of egajdzis, i found the flavors to be much smoother and evenly balanced.  also the bitter aftertaste had faded away and was no longer present.

Golden with a white head. Aroma is banana, cloves, spices, honey, and yeast. Some weak banana is present in the flavor, as well as slight honey character. Spices dominate the flavor fo sho. Light mouthfeel that tingles the tongue with lively carbonation.

Thanks Damion. Batch 56- Pours a hazy bright golden color, nice white frothy head, lots of lacing aparent. Aroma of sharp spices, cloves lemon zest, corriander. Flavor is acidic, and sweet, lemon oranges, honey, bananas and more spice. Interesting.
Now this is a great beer! It is a must try. A very balanced flavor and long finish.

A bitter disappointment.  Maybe the bottle was skunked by mishandling (I bought it in a Harris Teeter in Washington), but what I tasted was severely off in every respect of the word.  The only resemblance to a Belgian tripel was in the strength, but the flavors were gamy, rancid, ruined and off.  At the very least Allagash needs to get a handle on its distribution!

Couleur blonde miel, presque opaque.  Grosse mousse hyper persistante, √©paisse et cr√©meuse issue d¬íun d√©gagement gazeux tr√®s actif.  Ar√¥mes timides de poires, de houblon rappelant la menthe et de r√©sine de pin.  La forte pr√©sence de levure est honn√™tement juxtapos√©e √† la coriandre et √† une fra√Æcheur typique de la feuille de menthe.  D¬íune douceur remarquable, sa pr√©sence en bouche est cr√©meuse et d¬íune sensation in√©gal√©e.

Pours a gorgeous hazy yellow color with a thin to medium white head that leaves nice lacing on the glass, the head remained for the duration of the sampling. Mild aroma of yeast and citrus. Excellent flavor of yeast, spices and citrus. The best quality of this beer is it mouthfeel which is so smooth, heavenly, it feels like having a cloud within my mouth. The body is medium and carbonation is moderate. Excellent beer, definitely a world class tripel.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2005 Batch #60.  My first Tripel, and I was kind of surprised.  This is actually very similar to the white ale allagash makes when you get it on tap, but this is in a bottle.  I was impressed with the mouthfeel and flavors present mostly.  It¬ís also very well balanced so that no one flavor sticks out too much.

Batch #43

Pours bright and brassy, sparkling with a big white head. Lots of lace. Nice looking beer. Smells fruity and spicy with caramel aromas.

Smooth and malty up front with caramel undertones. Slight bitter alcohol finish, warms on the way down. Very smooth for such a strong beer and very well balanced. Nice fullbodied feel.

Not an everyday beer but hey, it¬ís not trying to be. Good brew to stick in the cellar to let it mellow. A nice source of warmth for winter.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2005 July 8th 2004: First of a long series of sampling.  Shining golden hue, honest rocky white head becomes a never disappearing 1cm foam. Superb noble hops in the aroma. It feels very natural, grassy and extremely floral. I smell a spice blend, but I can‚Äôt put any names. It smells very airy.. In mouth, once again this charming floral profile comes out very dry, champaigny almost. Spices flavor from the fermentation get a bit more defined (pepper, sage, cloves) while the malt base appear honeyish and fruity (but once again hard to put any names). Very bitter spicy and grassy finish. Pillow-soft mouthfeel, fluffy, creamy, round. Incredibly balanced and holding much more class than I can handle. I didn‚Äôt expect that much, this is a gem. Thanks Stephen! 

Everytime I try this again I‚Äôm blown away. Vastly superior in terms of expanding creamy tiny bubbled velvety mouthfeel. If the nose was more expressive, this would be very close to perfection. It builds a superb foam that lasts as long as you‚Äôre willing to sit on it. The sides of the glass stay white all along while the core at the middle digs a crater. Is that rockiness or what? And the taste... woah, succulent honeysuckle, very spicy, complex and champaigny. Only a 10 renders justice. Too elegant, shining and well-edged to be true with just a hint of alcohol to remind you it‚Äôs a tripel. Classy and effortlessly among the best.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2007 Batch #60:  A creamy white head with massive bubbles interlaced forms quickly atop the cloudy yellow body in the pour.  A bit of spritzy carbonation is noted as well, but not overly prickly.  The aroma is deep and sweet, with notes of honey, floral, dough, banana and spice.  This beer really expands on the tongue, giving a real ¬ífull,¬í chewy mouthfeel.  Finishes long and dry, with a nice warming sensation at the end.  Damn near great IMO!
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2005 750ml bottle,out of Batch #59, had along with an Ommegang Abbey Ale.  Allagash was a smoother, creamier drink.  Good flavor, nice head that held.

Low rating for aroma ¬ícause it¬ís hardly there.  What little I detect seems to be yeast and grapefruit.  Pours beautiful, full of life but with little carbonation.  The cloudiness does not distract; rather, it adds intrigue to the imminent intake of this beverage.   Palate is thin, taste is doughy and full of yeast, with a slight bit of coriander to finish it off.  This beer reminds me of pumpkin pie.  Interesting concoction; I would love to have this again, especially around Thanksgiving.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Great beer.  Floral aroma.  Great pour.  Perfect head.  Remings me of Duvel, with a hint of honey.  Batch 63

An awesome brew by Allagash! This one is almost as good as Allagash FOUR but at half the cost. Pours a nice looking golden color with big fat yeasties floating around, I love it! Nice rocky Belgian style head and good lacing rings wrap around the glass nicely. I was suprised at the amount of complexity this brew offers. There is the fruity Belgian notes that you would expect, but there is also this honey herbal tea flavor that I really enjoyed. This brew is full of body, it was better then I thought it would be!
Bottle courtesy of BuckNaked in our first trade. Pours deep golden yellow with a big white head. Strong fruity citrus aroma with lots of yeast. Flavor has lots of bitter orange. Unique tripel.

Bottle: Poured a light golden color beer with great carbonation and good head retention. Aroma is quite sweet with a nice floral background. Taste is sweeter then expected but well balance by some spices and wheat. Would have been better with a bit more kick (spices, it seems a bit light compared to Westmalle or De Dolle Tuve. Still very enjoyable but it seems a bit overrated compared to some other abbey tripel beer out there.

Batch 54.  Opened this one as a nice complement for Easter dinner.  Popped the cork, and got a quick aroma of citrus and banana.  Poured slightly hazy golden with a good head that lasted and left a good lace.  Good aroma with the aforementioned citrus and banana, along with peppery spices, some vanilla and some floral hops.  First sip was dry with a substantial bite.  Very floral flavor with some citrus (mostly grapefruit), some vanilla and quite a yeasty bite.  It finished dry, astringent and a little bitter.  Not too bad.  As it warmed (or as my tastebuds started to numb from the 9%), it became sweet and dry.  Honey, banana and vanilla flavors took over.  When warmer, it finished very smooth.  As far as tripels go, this is one of the better ones.

hazy gold pour, a good amt. of white frothy head. aroma is spice, alcohol, yeast. taste is very yeasty, sweet, a nice amount of spice, and detectable alcohol, but not to a fault. smooth mouthfeel. quite good!

batch 53, thanks to footbalm.  very yeasty and green grape-like, the aroma is like a half-fermented white wine.  quite sweet despite all the alcohol, and it eventually picks up a hint of bitterness, with a tiny olive-like flavor deep in the finish.  very good beer, the best tripel i¬íve had.
A cloudy golden colored beer.  It was nicely hopped and yet sweet.  This combination partnered with the spicy hints made this a very plesant beer to drink.

750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy yellow, a pinky fingered head that recedes quickly into thin fizzy film. Smells of sour apples, raisins. Complex taste, initially yeasty with gentle hops, settles into a sweeter notes of vanilla, honey, grapefruity citrus. Swishes creamy, mmm, and finishes crisp and dry. Tastes of apple linger. My friend says it is what you would get if you were eating apple pie and drinking beer at the same time. Lively small bubbles dissipate in the glass but are reborn on your tongue. Medium bodied, very drinkable.

Tasted in Los Angeles.  Obtained from  either Plumpjack in Noe/San Fran or Berkeley.  Appearance is straw / light yellow colour.  Highly carbonated with a sustained white fluffy yet dense head.  Aroma has citrus notes, with a spicyness remiscent of corriander with a slightly sweet nose.  Flavour is sweet, slightly burning sensation from the alcohol.  There is a very warm after taste present as a result of the alcohol flavour.

Poured a cloudy light golden color with a big lasting head. Aroma of fruits and yeast.  Spicy flavor with frutiness and sweetness and a yeasty finish.  Nice medium mouthfeel with a little alcohol burn.
Nice color, hazy. Too simple aroma. Well hopped, balanced sweet/bitter body.

Corked bottle, Batch #46Hazy, pale blond color. Good Tripel, strong spicy character and quite dry in the beginning, a bit alcoholic, with a light corky character and a very light fruitness, good but not so extraordinary.
clear blond colour, fine head, yeasty and spicy, slightly perfumy, sweet and full-bodied, low carbonation, dry and slightly bitter, long yeasty and alcohol finish - thanks to fiulijn for sharing it
Very yeasty in the nose but the malts really come through in the flavour Sweet with spicy herbal notes. Far superior to the Dubbel.

I¬íve been holding on to this since I started drinking world class beer.  Batch #35.  Pours a clear golden with a large frothy white head, much like Orval or Duvel.  Huge clouds of bubbles are swirling up to the top of my glass.  How am I supposed to take a sip from a beer who¬ís froth is taller than that of a cappucino?  The aroma is a very nice combination of honey, grapes, and a touch of banana.  Taste is dry white wine with some spice, not too sweet at all.  This could substitute a fine champagne (and would be a hell of a lot cheaper).  Finish is dry and refreshing.  Excellent beer.  In my humble opinion, I think Allagash has it over Unibroue when it comes to western Belgian-style brewers.
Had this one with la fin du monde. Batch 40: Golden, hazy color huge lasting frothy white head, very carbonated. Lots of yeast aromas. Flavor is yeasty with a sour kick. Complex. Nice.

Bottle:  Nice citrus aromas with lots of orange peel.  Banana in there too.  Pours a hazy orangish-yellow with a big white head with very good retention.  Lots of citrus with banana in the background.  A little sweetness in the finish.  Leaves an orange peel aftertaste.  Another courtesy of Styles.

Now here ya go. This is much better belgian drink that I actually enjoy. It still has that belgain buisness to it that makes me want to stop drinking but the malts are so much more sweet and enjoyable. This thing is actually drinkable. What else can I say.

Medium amber color with thin white head.  Spicy, perfumy aroma.  Yeast.  Coriander.  Fruit.  Moderate carbonation.  Medium body.  Flavor was passable but not exceptional.  Typical, in my book, of a Belgian tripel.  Bittersweet.  Spices.  Not my style.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Swet. spicy, caramelly.  Thin white head that dissipated quickly over a golden body.  Round  Belgian flavor. Extremely spicy finish with a strong alcohol note.  Soft and bubbly with a strong carbonation.  Alcohol leaves it feeling clean.  Delicous Belgian.

50F.
Smells like pulpy orange juice with a twidge of lemon, and a little rust.
Cool. Kinda spicy - coriander, cumin, cardamon, white pepper. Good little sour yawn. Bosc pear. Then the alcohol dries it out; distills these flavors to their bitter essence.
This is a good beer, but it still doesnt blow me away.  I think I find American made tripels lacking, kind of like when Hollywood remakes a great foreign film, just not the same.

Batch #51.  Pours gold with a large, lasting head and great legs.  Aroma is of honey, spice, and malt.  A sweet smell with a sweet taste, bananas and honey in the taste.  Some oragne and perhaps pepper in the taste.  A smooth, warming mouthfeel as the alcohol dissipates pff the tongue.  Honey, too.
Just like any other good tripel, only less so. Unremarkable aroma and taste.  Slightly sweet, slightly spicy and finishes without fanfare
Golden color with white head.  The aroma is sweet but, I couldn¬ít pick anything special out.  Just nothing special going on here.

Batch #41: Hazy golden color with a thick white head that has good retention. Thin and silky lacing. The aroma consists of yeast, fruit and spices. Medium-bodied with sugary sweet qualities. Lightly fruity with some yeast and spice flavors, but none in any abundance. As a matter of fact this was not quite as flavorful as expected. Still it is a good beer with nice balance. The finish is mildly sweet with fruit, yeast and a bit of pepper. So far Allagash has been consistently solid for me.

Batch #41. Very cloudy, yellowish-golden body with a fluffy white head. Aroma is oranges, bananas, sugar, and alcohol. Flavor mirrors the aroma. Very good up to the point of the rather abrasive alcohol burn while this goes down.
Batch #56. Cloudy golden with a very large white head. Aromas of sweet alcohol and banana. Very nice flavor: mainly banana, with some other fruitiness. Finishes with a tinge of alcohol. Nice!

Batch 51 for those who give a damn. Now for the more important aspects: this beer was delicious. After struggling with the cork, the extra effort was well worth it. Poured a pale yellow/gold, somewhat cloudy, with a nice initial head that deflated semi-quickly after pouring. Smelled wonderful - honey, vanilla, banana and pepper. This was one of those beers that you think "hell yeah!" as soon as you taste the beer. Yeasty and wheaty, with a nice trifecter of citrus-sweet-and-smooth. Finish was a tiny bit spicy with some of the alcohol coming through. Aftertaste lingered for a while, but I didn¬ít mind it - it reminded me of a job well done in drinking this fine beer.

Batch 54: Poured hazy yellowish orange with a nice fluffy white head...smell is sweet with lots of tropical scents and then strong spice with anise, pepper, and coriander coming through...the taste was very fizzy with a nice sweet malt flavor up front, giving way to a growing vegetable bitterness in the back...like an orange rind...finish is very dry...a great beer, but if it was a touch sweeter it would be rated much higher...

Batch #32, for those of you keeping score at home.
Appearance: slightly hazed, pure golden hue, some bubbling carbonation, with a large and lovely, fluffy cloud of foam on top, obviously home to a myriad of tiny angels awaiting their chance to entrance the senses.
And it is good work that they do!
Aroma: intoxicating! Senses-filling, flooding, uplifting! Rich, delicious, heady, spicy, sweet, fruity (lemon, orange, pineapple, peach), complex, and invigorating. Bewitching, beguiling, bewildering! And pretty good, too!
Taste: huge, yet soft, and sensual attack of hops, that just as soon turns to an orgy on the tongue, nothing but goodness and delight coming from it, a paroxysm of pleasure occurs, sending jolt after jolt of joy down through the nervous system and every sense receptor.
These flavors, these temptations, sweet succor to any thirst or any lack of happy feeling, they continue again and again every time lip meets cup, and ale meets tongue, again and again, without pause. Mmmmm, is all my mind can conjure to relate the exact consequences of consumption, and maybe it¬ís that 9% ABV of this 750ml bottle (1/2 to go, and the night is still young, where to go from such bliss?) of perfectly brewed tripel?
Everything¬ís in it¬ís heaven in this brew, the malt, the hops, the booze, sugar, yeast, every little imp that does it¬ís special magic has earned it¬ís fairy dust in the production of this very fine golden ale!
Allagash, I¬íd tip my hat to you, but I haven¬ít got a hat!

750ML Batch #55.  Hazy golden orange colour. White head. Well fitzy on the tounge. Had a nice well balanced fruit/spice taste. Was smooth and didnt rack my brain as much. Some natural sugar taste. Enjoyed it very much.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 750ml bottle, batch #51.  I have had this in my fridge for a couple of months waiting for the right occasion, and chose it for my birthday brew.  Allowed to warm for about 30 min before opening, and served in a nice Christmas tulip glass.  Hazy golden in color with a small white head that disappears, leaving the beer still quite lively with carbonation and tingly on the tongue. Pleasant yeasty fruity aroma.  Very deep and complex flavors, almost burgundy in character, though remaining light in the mouth and easy drinking. Hoppy and some bitterness nicely matching the honey sweetness, very clean finish.  A delicious and drinkable ale, with the high alcohol masked fairly well, and a wonderful buzz at the end. The spiciness came out more toward the end of the bottle.  An excellent choice for my birthday, I loved it! A couple more like this and I might be a Belgiephile instead of a Stoutie!
Typical tripel. Pours hazy yellow with a fluffy white head. Spicy fuit taste. Slighty weaker in comparison to la fin du monde.
Bottle, Batch #35, Golden orange in color, nice off white head, nice lacing, smells of fruit, spice, and honey great fruity taste that leaves a sweet aftertaste.  very nice.

Bottle ala qdog.  Hazy light amber to orangish color.  Scant white head.  Good lacing.  Strange dark colored floaties.  Nice sweet aroma, yeasty and fruity.  Very smooth.  Less carbonation than some triples.  Nice complex taste profile. Sweet but not overdone.  Perhaps some Hefe. characteristics.  Just enough bitterness in the finish to get the job done.  Pretty damn good
Honey and buttery w/ fruit notes.  Light yellow color w/ great head and no lacing.  Good effervesence and medium body.
Poursa golden hue with a halo of a head.  Aromas of spice, honey, and cinnamon.  Medium bodied with a spicy finish with flavors of nutmeg and bananas.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2005    Re-rate.  Time to give this the credit it deserves.  Pours golden with a nice white head.  The head actually gets thicker instead of thiner which is unusal.  Smell had banana, honey, white wine, gin and tonic, lemon, vanilla, orange peel and grape.  Taste was pretty smooth but bitter at times.  Powerful alcohol presense in the flavor.  Smooth palate which was similar to the Westmalle but not as good.  Nice tripel.
batch number 53:cloudy yellow body with not much head for a tripel.very nice well balanced aroma of citurs,cream,and yeast.very nice flavors of hops,citurs,yeast,and cloves.good tripel.
Batch #50. Vanilla aroma with a hint of citrus. Hoppy, somewhat creamy flavor, just a bit flowery. Hoppy aftertaste, somewhat alcoholic. Nice and easy going tripel.
The aroma is quite promising but it¬ís actually just a nice tripel. A bit on the sweet side maybe. Not complex, not exceptional.

(Dutch ratebeermeeting) Balanced aroma of fruit, grain and spices. Hazy, yellow coloured with a lasting, white head. Taste is sweet with fruit and spices. More bitterness in the finish. Sticky. Decent balance. Decent brew. Typical triple.
Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Cloudy yellow coloured, white head. IMHO nothing special going on in aroma and flavour, just an average tripel. And i¬ím not that big of a fan of the style.
Slightly hazy yellow color, big white head. Spicy and grainy aroma, some wheat. Quite sweet taste, bit sticky palate. Nothing special, but therefore quite good.

Batch No. 37...Cloudy orange-gold with a huge frothy white head.  Yeast and malt aromas with a fruit and spicy wheat nose.  Sweet yeasty flavor with citrus, butter, and honey notes.  Warm and creamy palate, refreshing.
First try, batch 53 750ml bottle. A little too harsh alcohol bite, not well hidden at all. Complex, sweet flavor, honey-hoppish. Would try again.
does the united states make better triples than belgium?  perhaps...this one was great.  nice golden color.  tasted the traditional banana and clove.  this masked the 9% extrordinarily well.

This was Tripel number 2 of three for last night. Definitely the best looking of the three with a nice yellow/orangey color, cloudy with tasty yeasties. In the nose, there was a lot of sweetness, pear, apples, a light hop aroma, and the smell of champagne. After the silky smoothness crossed my tongue, I was hit with the sweetness, a taste similar to honey. As it warmed, more banana and cloves were presiding. I had to double check the alcohol on this, as I didn¬ít think it could possibly be as high as 9%. I was quite pleased in this selection, though not my favorite.

Pours a cloudy amber colour with lots of head. The Head just lingers and is frothy with nice lacing. Has a nice hoppy Aroma. The flavour is refreshingly Belgium Big and Sweet and has a bit of a bitter finish. This beer is very refreshing and very tasty. I love this beer and I know you will also. CHEERS!

Pours a hazy dirty orange with a nice spumous Belgian style head. An absolutely magnificent color on this one. A great sticky lace as well left on the glass. Nice head retention and a feast for the eyes. 

Light fruits rise in the nose. Lots of banana, clove, grapes, lemon, some spicy fruits like pineapple. Smells yeasty as well with the faintest hint of alcohol. Nice nose on this one! 

Nice flavor. I¬ím beginning to love the style. BIG flavor but very mellow and smooth. Starts out sweet and then shifts to in onslaught of juicy hops that was almost overbearing but ended up being very pleasing. Lots of light fruits similar to the aroma. Starts out with the light fruits and then leads to the sour ones on the finish. Nice brew!

Batch #51 bottled on 3-03-04. Cork popped with a loud bang. If I hadn¬ít such a good grip it would have put a dent i the ceiling. Served at 50-55 F. Color was a sickly pale gold not unlike many macro brews. Thick puffy head. Slightly strange aroma of yeast,citrus and hints of dish soap(not from me). It was semi yeasty,fruity(citrus,possibly passionfruit), no banana or honey but it was sweet,crisp and slightly dry. Alcohol presence was not mask very well as this was quite warming going down. UUUURPP,fizzy too. Not bad but IMO needs to sit another year. Can¬ít see why this avgs. a 4 rating. Goes well with cheesey cubes and ritz tho.
 The St. Bernardus I had yesterday was a whole lot better and the same price for 2 330 ml bottles.

Bottle: Batch 53
Dense white head that sticks to the sides of the glass.  Looks cloudy and intense, even a little threatening.  Very sharp with the bitterness, but so many yummy and spicy flavors.  I¬ím a new fan of this

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2005 Bottle:  Batch 54.  Pours cloudy, light, golden yellow in color with a large, creamy white head.  Aroma:  Light honey, banana, pear, yeast, and the slightest of alcohol vapors.  Taste:  Initially the champagne-like carbonation and some bitterness hit your tongue.  It was a bit more bitter than I expected at first, but that only served to prepare my palate for the change to sweet towards the middle, then to dry & bitter, spicy aftertaste.  There¬ís bitter banana, yeast, white pepper, pineapple, honey, caramel, malt, bread, citrus, and even red clover in this taste.  The alcohol is hidden very well until it gives the finishing spice just a bit of a kick.  This beer seems to get better and better with each sip.  It is a bit more bitter than most Tripels I¬íve had, which makes it very easy to drink.....you¬íve been warned.
Goldern color with medium head.  Aroma is fruity, yeasty, and a little spicy.  Sweet flavors of fruit and sugar.  Spice on the finish. Medium body.

I love it when my parents travel because they bring me stuff like this. The bottle poured a deep golden colour. I smelled a bit of honey and a strong fruitiness. This beer got better on each sip with lots of tropical fruit flavours and a complementary yeastiness. mmmmm good.

golden yellow in color and lots of microbubble carbonation.  very creamy/rocky tall white head, fairly lasting and good lacing arcs.  pretty clear color on first pour, more cloudy at second pour.  yeast & malty nose, super-faint honey nose but I couldn¬ít smell any fruit - maybe faint lemon rind.  very faint candi sugar nose too.  sweet malty honeyish start.  little bit of the bready/doughy mouthfeel, then very balanced alcohol/hop burn.  spicy white pepper afertaste.  enjoyable summer evening belgian tripel style.

750ml bottle. Batch #42
Pours a cloudy golden color with a fine white head, silky lace and nice pearling. The head diminished rather quickly ? leaving a fine film. The clouding reduced some, but never completely cleared. Aroma of fruit and very yeasty?not very complex or aromatic, but still pleasant. The taste was tart with some sweetness and a dry biting finish. The mouthfeel was rather flat ? not a lot of body and quite one-dimensional.
IMHO: Not a lot of character or body. Numerous qualities that can work in a well balanced beer were either under or over represented. It looks as if there have been other batches of this beer that have been much better.

Chose this beer as I try and find an outstanding tripel.  Bottle says "Batch #50", if that makes sense to someone.  After removing the cork, there is nothing written on the cork except maybe a sideways, and somewhat deformed, number 6 or 9.  The beer pours (in Westmalle glass) a cloudy, light orange-yellow golden colored liquid with a small amount of white head that dissipates quickly, but leaves a thin film.  Aroma is of citrus, banana, fruits, sweet.  Flavor is citrus sweet, fruity and somewhat hoppy.  Good mouthfeel.  Not my kind of beer, but a good tripel as rated by others, I guess.  Sampled at refrigerator temp and as it warms.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2008 Gold color with a large white head. Spicy aroma and flavor, with orange peel and cloves in the latter. Full-bodied and incredibly smooth for the abv. An excellent beer.

UPDATE: My god, this is an incredible beer. If you leave it in your mouth long enough, the spices mix with the alcohol and burn your tongue a bit, like biting into a pepper. I like it a lot.

Had a four year old sample tonight. Still kicking, but there‚Äôs a light oxidized note that some people may find off-putting. I thought it added a great sherry-ish nuttiness. Spice has calmed down, and the finish is all yeast and light sherry.
Pours golden, with a nice white head. Aromas of yeast, hops, spice, and some malt. Flavor is spicey, with hints of orange, yeast, and malt. Body is just right.

Hazy gold w/a  lasting white head.  Bubble gum and light clove aroma with some grainy sweetness; hints of perfumey floral and herbal hop; hints of alcohol and light plum fruitiness as it warms, also some green apple.  Well balanced but to lightly bitter, which becomes more bitter toward the finish and into the aftertaste.  The more I drink, the more bitter it becomes...Very distracting!  There seems to be a little bit of cardboardy, bland malt flavor, also a little grainy. A light hop flavor, some sugary flavor, low fruity banana esters. Finish is dry and peppery yeast, clove into the aftertaste.  Highly carbonated, dry m/f, light warming alcohol w/ a lighter body.  I¬ím not very impressed.  Too bitter for my taste for a tripel and does not have very good depth of flavor IMHO.  Most typical flavors are there, but they are all very light.  Aroma promises a lot, but flavor delivers very little.

Pours a cloudy light golden hue with great head and silky lacing.  Great complex nose:  Bread, yeast orange and  honey.   Nice spiciness with a hop bite and a good malty background.  Nice creamy texture and a spicy hop finish.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2004 This is the ultimate summer beer. Golden and wet. Frothy and cloudlike. Nose of honey, honeysuckle, hops, saaz hops and lots of them almost like a good czech pils. Flavors match these with even more hoppy goodness. Excellent brew.
G-rat
Hazy, orange. Fruity and alcoholic. A bit more sweet and strong than most other Abbey triples. I would store this one for several years, than I could imagine it would get sublime.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2005 Caged and corked bottle. Nose is bready and yeasty. The flavor has notes of citrus, banana, anise, bread dough, berry, alcohol, and malt. Finish is super clean. Mouthfeel is nice and light. This is good stuff.

Bottle.  nice earthy aroma with a sweet hint. pours a hazy yellow with a thick fluffy head. . fruity sweet taste, i guess is from the passion fruit. i don¬ít know what passion fruit tastes like, so that could be the taste that i can¬ít identify. peppery malt flavor. very nice this makes me smile when i drink it, and i don¬ít smile much.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2004 I rated this once about two weeks ago but I lost the sheet of paper I wrote it on. This turned out to be something of a blessing as it gave me an excuse to buy this wonder of a beer again. This is a very pale triple--I¬íll call it golden rather than yellow because it tastes good. The first pour is crystal clear but there¬ís a touch of sediment in later glasses. The head is nice and fluffy, creamy with tiny, tiny bubbles and it lasts long enough to leave thousands of of drippy little spots of lace on the side of my chalice. The nose is somewhat surprising--a bit more hops than I expected, almost-hints of citrus along with actual hints of bread and honey but not much if any of that banana they talk about in the description. The palate is nice and thick, some slight stickiness is made more pronounced by the bitterness in the finish. This is really an excellent beer. I enjoy the extra bit of hops Allagash has added. It gives the beer an American spin without becoming some ham-fisted monster and still staying relatively true to the style.

Whata ya know? I found my old rating of this. It was much higher (4.5). I thought the beer tasted a lot thinner the second go round..... Cloudy golden, gorgeous creamy white head that lasts forever and leaves huge sheets of lace. Nose is mild, slightly bready with a hint of sweet spice and some floral notes. Creamy, thick mouthfeel with a velveteen cusion of carbonation. This a truly complex and delicious, easily on par with the best of the Trappists.

An unclear orange beer with a fine white head. The aroma is of yeast and coriander. The flavor is sweet with notes of oranges, yeast, and coriander. A nice American produced Belgian beer, though a little on the sweet side.
Poured a hazy golden color with a small head. Aromas and tastes of fruits (bananas), spices (cloves?), and yeast. Bitter in a good way. Very good Tripel that I will definitely drink again.
Cloudy golden coloured. Aroma of yeast, fruits and spices. Sweet and fruity flavour with a yeasty finish.

Good hazy golden hue with a tiny bit of head on it.  Aroma is a rather spicy malt and yeast smell, a little spicier than usual for a Belgian strong.  Mouthfeel is a thicker than expected for this brew.  Crisp flavor with a small carbonation and hop crispness to the end.

750 bottle.  Pours clear and golden with a creamy white head - if I didn¬ít know better I might mistake this for a lager - but I know better!  Aroma is malty and yeasty with mild spicyness noticble.  Flavor is rich and sweet, peppery bite along with bready flavors, cardamom and and hoppy, tingly finish.  Full bodied and creamy carbonation make this one a really nice Belgian tripel style and a pleasure to drink!

Bottle. Batch 49. Another Allagash beer that doesn¬ít live up to it¬ís reputation. Light golden colored with a decent white head. Bubblegum and yeast aroma. Big carbinations. Decent malt flavor with some light fruit - banana and green apple... I don¬ít see any passion fruit - and some spice. Just not enough complexity. It¬ís catering to the style without showing anything.
Golden with thick white head. Apricot, peach and spice nose.  Creamy palate with mid sweetness, rich and yeasy with a drying finish.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2005 Thanks goes to civforprez for sharing this one. From batch #51. Pours with a large white head. Has a very cloudy straw color. The aroma is interesting with banana, ginger, black pepper and lemon zest. The taste is bananas, ginger and cinnamon toast. This is fairly spicy. Has active carbonation in the mouthfeel. Very nice for a tripel. Just a bit too spicy. Sampled again courtesy of Secret Santa. Excellent tripel.

Hazy blonde/light amber color with white head & light lacing. The aroma is harmonious with hops & alcohol, very true to stye. The flavor is well balanced between sweet & dry, neutral, spicy yeast with herbs on the side. Very true to style for a triple.

Dark cloudy gold. Creamy head and spotty lacing. Biscuits in the nose with some yeast. Apricots and pears. Some citrus hops, more floral though. Some spices along with hints of bananas. Flavor contains bananas, yeast, apricot, some spices, citrus hops, some lemon. Light acidity. Fuzzy palate with a medium body and finishes malty.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2005 Grapefruit, pine, floral hop nose with notes of oranges, almonds, lightly spicy yeast and a good supporting malt base. Opaque golden orange with fizzy white head that recedes to ring. Marzipan, sweet malt - incredibly bitter for the style but that¬ís just an afterthought. The sweet, fruity, malty flavours dominate. Excellent body is medium-full. Strong carbonation that still manages to remain unobtrusive. Bottle. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere.  Rerated with largely the same comments and scored 7-4-9-4-16=4.0 on 15-May-05 with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Olivier_MTL, Rastacouere and Yowie.  Original rating (7/10/2004) 9-4-9-5-18=4.5.
Its a good beer on my personal taps. this will be featured next week. this beer is always out when i have friends over.
Cloudy yellow. Big head. Attractive aroma. Very good flavour. Spice pepper. Moderate honey. Very smooth.

Aroma of citrus fruits including orange, sweet. Pours a cloudy yellow, nice head and lacing. Flavour is mostly sweet with that baking soda note and an alcohol finish. Fairly dry and quite smooth. A solid tripel.
Hazy golden light brown. Spicey lemon aroma. Taste is spicey, fruity, zesty, lemons, and light hops. Alcohol also comes out some. This is a very good beer. But, I liked Allagash Four better.

Batch 44.  Pale yellow with a large open white head and very rapid carbonation.  Becomes cloudy as the yeast from the bottom enters the glass.  The aroma is sweet, wheaty, yeasty, and spicy.  Spice seems to be from hops and other spiced items.  It¬ís very smooth and balanced.  The taste is a mixture of alcohol, honey and spices along with some orange peaking through.  The spiced finish rests very nicely in the mouth.  Very nice beer.
Poured slightly cloudy with a wonderful head- fluffy and snow white. Nice spicy aroma. Beautiful roundness on the tongue. A very fine example of this style.

Pours sunshine gold with some haziness. Fluffy white head which dissapates, but decent lacing. Mouth-watering aromas of lemongrass, honey, yeast rolls and oranges. Pleasant spritzy carbonation which quickly settles into just a silky smooth honey-drippin¬í  texture. Flavors of lemon, spices, banana and doughy bread abound. Overall a sweet profile maskng the 9% alcohol completely. Great complexity and a beautiful sweet, but slightly tart finish. Good stuff and a great deal.

Bottle.  Medium dark golden color with some cloudiness.  Aroma is a bit spicy with malt and flowery notes.  Taste is excellent.  Dry and yeasty with subtle spice.  This is my stand-by for triples because it¬ís quality and cheep.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2008 mmmm well, im glad i bought another one of these to cellar, because i dont think its near ready to drink.  banana is noticiable in the taste, not in the smell.  pours golden in color.  citrus flavored taste, pretty complex- but i cant say that it has really blown me away.  this brewery must use something in their beer that just doesnt impress me very much.  the aftertaste is the best part with a nice lingering sweetness.  Original score: 8 / 3 / 7 / 4 / 15

Cellar pick - 2003 bottle.  Batch #50.  Sampled: 50 degrees.  After reading my initial review of this beer some 4 years ago, I have now come to terms with what that taste actually is: the yeast.  And now that my palate has changed over the course of 6 years, it is obvious to me that the yeast Allagash uses is actually my favorite part of their beers.   Pulled the cork out of this one and thought it might have been dead, but after pouring it, it is clear that the carbonation was just hiding!  Straw yellow color with a big white head on it.  The smells of bananas and sweet fruits are still there perhaps a bit less pronounced.  Tasting this beer is fabulous.  Sweet, easy to drink, very little alcohol burn (which is usually present in a fresher bottle).  Damn this is good.  Very dry and leaves you wanting more.  The 9% is no where to be found in this beer.  I am not even a fan of tripels, but I feel I must bump my score after trying this one!  This is the reason Rob Todd is a premier brewer in this country.

Batch #33
I took TAR¬ís advice and aged this bottle for over a year. A few months ago, BeanDip shared a newer vintage with me, it was rather tasty 3.7, so I am excited to find out if the cellar has done it¬ís job. 

 Pours with a beautiful and vibrant golden body, hues of orange, it looks like a jar honey, but with a colossal mountain of snow encrusted atop. The aroma is citric and sweet, orange blossoms and honeysuckle accompany notes of clove and black peppercorns; all can be found along side a freshly cut tangerine, a ripened plum, a doughy yeastiness, and a modest amount of musty barnyard hay! 
Geez, the flavor is alive with sweet notes of honey, banana and mango nectar, and some biscuity likeness. This is profoundly full of tropical fruits and Western spice¬Ö The palate is sticky yet buttery slick. Thick sheets of lace cloak the glass with each sip¬Ö. A Marvelous Triple! The past 12 months have brought this beer into Greatness!

Art of Beer Festival 2004:  Has a golden color with a lot of carbonation and a medium white head.  Smell citrusy/yeasty.  Taste is fruity/malty/spicey and finishes with a slightly woody/alcohol flavor.  Overall a very good beer and I think my first Tripel...

On tap at Eulogy in Philly.
Wow, what a beer!  I thought the aroma and appearance were fantastic.  The bubbles were mesmerizing alone.

The taste matched the aroma and appearance.  Yeasty, a little banana and pear or apple.
A bit warming, but nothing to distract from the complexity of a pretty young brew.
Find some, open one, cellar the rest.  
Best of allagash to date.

Batch #41 Magnificent ultra clear gold nice head & lace, good bead but not fizzy.  Malticious citrus flower aroma, perfumey hops or yeast?  faintly musty(cork??) bit o¬í alcohol.  Big malt, spicy hops, citrus, little lingering lusciousness mixed with alcohol.  Very nice beer. I could be fooled into thinking it was from Belgium.  Alcohol does come through a bit, but its not dominating or hot.  Somehow, I¬íd just like this beer to be bigger.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2006 Golden-orange body with significant carbonation and a tight sudsy white head. Orange citrus, bananas, and biscuits in the aroma. Great sweet-sour-bitter balance in the flavor make this a very nicely rounded tripel. Includes some spice, phenols, and earthy muskiness. A prototype tripel, this beer typifies the style in my experience.
Nice aroma, nice yeasty peachy banana taste that faded very very quickly with almost nothing at the end. Well masked of alcahol. Something for the ladies.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Very creamy pour, with cream on the tongue, the glass. Fruity apricot and bannana and orange and apricot, and spices, the latter penetrating the nose. Coriander. A long and dry bitter tart aftertaste yet satisfying.

This beer poured a slightly hazy yellow gold color and formed a huge foamy white head that left laticed lace as it slowly supsided. A medium amount of carbonation is present and maybe a few particles of sediment. An aroma of hops, malt, coriander and other spices with a touch of yeast. A taste of malt, coriander and grain/yeast. It has a medium body to it with a touch of the alcohol present.
Light golden, lovely creamy head. Aroma of pineapple, mostly sweet but also fresh. Bit fruity, pineapple and banana flavour wit some cellary notes and noticable alcohol.

batch:45. Nice yeasty aroma with hoppy citrus notes. It pulled a rather small head but a firm one. Taste was a bit of a let down, very fresh subtle taste with a fruity undertone of bananas, peaches and oranges, nicely blended with hops and malt. This brew is very nice, but I wanted a bit more out of it

Exceptional tripel, semi-cloudy & hazy golden color, thick fluffly white head, fruity & yeasty nose, flavors have notes of yeast, honey, banana & other spices, very smooth & drinkable, nice warming effect from the alcohol, dry & semi-bitter finish with some spiciness

Hazy blonde beer, with a spicy aroma, lots of coriander, with yeasts and alcohol and mixed fruits. The alochol warmth hits you first followed by spices and orange peels, and bananas. Wonderfulley rich and warm body.

Pale yellow slight haze in the beer. Med white head that held up for an average amt of time. Good rich malty candy sugar aromas with some spiceyness. Complex flavors, phenoilc with sweetness followed with some spice and alcohol. A good overall belgian trippel.

Killer beer! I had it on tap (Reserve- 9.8%) from a batch that was aged in bourbon casks (Jim Beam). Strong bourbon notes all over the place. Combine with an awesome triple and I didn't know where to go. Nice suble vanilla and banana notes and all that great yeast. I cannot say enough positive things about this beer.

On Tap-Blind Tiger NYC-Nice clarity, but no head-might be something about the way it was poured.  Good solid malt presence and alchohol apparent as well.  Would love to have a few more of these on a cool winter afternoon. Nice belgian from a great brewery.

Couldy golden straw colored body, tight bubbled white head, laceing seems to stick around for awhile.  Aroma is spicey/ malty with a fruity back bone and some mild phenolic yeastiness.  Spicey yeasty flavors dominate a citrusy fruit body (grapefruit, grape, mild lemon).  A slight malt sweetness comes through near the end.  Palate is dry with a lingering after taste.  Tripels are not my favotite but good none the less.
Big bottle, hand marked batch 49.  These Americans have put together a Tripel that can compete with the best:  fin du Monde, Maredsous, and Karmelit.  Solid all around performance.

Competently constructed American version of a Belgian tripel; Sweet, spicy (cloves!), slightly bitter, balanced and completely in character for a Belgian tripel, and on par with the typical tripel from Belgium; The spiciness comes out mostly in the finish; The mild nose is lightly sweet with some spicy notes; Carbonated mouthfeel and fairly sticky; Golden yellow in color, too light to be a shade of golden, and definitely a little hazy; White head is composed of tiny bubbles and has solid retention, but lacing slides down the glass

Pours a hazy yellow with a thick white head. Nice lacing down the glass. Fruit and yeast on the nose. Tingly mouthfeel. Citrus fruits ands spices on the tongue. Bold and crisp flavors. Nice smooth finish, with a lingering aftertaste. A great beer at a great price!

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2006 Bursting with the smell of fresh sweetbread.  The use of the fenallic yeast kind of give it a minty aroma and flavor.  Not too much mintiness to ruin the beer but borderline drinking too quick after brushing your teeth.

Bomber, batch #49.  Aroma is yeasty with banana and clove.  Color is a hazy blonde with a moderate off-white head.  Start is kind of metallic.  some cirtus lemon notes in the middle.  Malty finish.  *shrugs*

If Allagash can make a Belgian this well, and sell it for less than five bucks a bottle, who needs Belgium?

This is an exceptional beer and an even more exceptional value for the buck.

Bottle, "Batch #47" (3.21.04)  Pours a very pale but brilliant yellow, completely clouded with yeast; medium to smallish white head with excellent longevity; fair, visible carbonation that presents itself as a light fizz on the palate.  Aromas are subtle but complex: honey, ginger, tropical fruit salad and cream.  The flavors are much of the same up front, plus a nice depth of spices - coriander, allspice - and fantastic yeast and salt notes at the end.  Absolutely amazing beer.  I wish there was more of an alcohol presence, but otherwise perfect and so so so quaffable.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 Nice pour, very dry yellow, cloudy, with a huge head.  Head leaves nice lacing.  Very complex- yeasty, hay, leather, herbal, and estery aroma.  I also noticed that this is one of the most highly hopped tripels out there.  Lots of earthy and spicy hop aromas.  Flavor is of sweet fruits and nicely balanced by malts.  Very nice mouthfeel, and finishes quite smooth.  Awesome tripel.  One of the best out there.

This beer has a dry, grassy, yeasty, musty, bready aroma.  The aroma is quite complex and perfect for a Tripel.  The beer is brilliantly clear, a bright gold color, with a dense meringue like white head that is held up by a prodigious carbonation.  The taste is sharp, astringent, lightly sweet, a bit of grain, herbal, and finishes with a bit of alcohol.  This is a great interpretation by Allagash, this beer has lots of flavor, unlike the breweries Dubbel.  This beer is so effervescent that it has quite a drying effect.  This beer has completely restored my faith in Allagash, they can make some tasty brew.

Tap. Had this one after a fairly fruity beer and I'm not sure if that contributed to my not noticing the fruit this one is supposed to offer up or not. I got some spiciness and cloves and alcohol though from this almost brown hazy gold beer. Very smooth and easy drinking and then the fruit came out on the palate, although mildly. Quite enjoyable.

batch #36 750ml bottle.  Very nice golden color, crystal clear with a typical head.  Aroma is very pleasant, citrus and spice. Taste is citrus and other fruits, banana, pineapple maybe.  Possibly hint of wheat. Moutfeel is smooth with a tiny bit of heat from the 9% abv.  Not at all overly citrus.  A good brew from the nice people in Maine!
cloudy yellow with a skunky smell.  i didn't detect too much flavor in it.  from all i'd heard, i was expecting more.  i was a little disappointed.

Batch # 41... Poured a hazy dark golden color with a large fluffy white head, beautiful lacing and bubbles that never stop!  Spicy aroma of yeast, citrus, and banana.  Sweet taste of citrus fruit, some funky yeast, hops and a light citrus alcoholic finish.  A great Belgian style beer made on the left side of the Atlantic.

Batch #40.  Poured a cloudy yellow-orange with a medium-thick white head.  Vinous, pineapple juice aroma led to a nicely balanced flavor of white grape, apple peel (a touch), pineapple juice and spice leading to bready yeast characteristics and a medium dry finish of crackers and a touch of alcohol.  Tripels seem to very between very sweet, fruity examples and dry, yeasty examples.  This version strikes a keen balance between the two extremes.  Smooth palate.  Very nice.
Batch #48 @ the SE Gathering. Pours a cloudy yellow with a wonderful aroma of banana and spices. Banana, cloves and spices dominate the flavor. Very smooth and warming. Thanks Scoobyluv!
Spicy, lemony and citrus flavors are predominant in this one.  Not too complex, just an average trippel.  Light fruits and corriander spiciness and not much else.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2004 Re-rate: Batch 37.  Noticed honey profile and a nice dry finish.  Batch 48 at the Southeastern Gathering (thanks scoobyluv).
This cloudy yellow fizzer started well, but didn't finish like I wanted. Too much citrus.  The claim in the description includes "honey surfacing from its deep and complex palate" - this was the missing piece to me.  If the honey were present, the sweetness and fullness would've helped perfect this otherwise excellent Trippel.

Sample glass, RateBeer Southeastern Gathering.  Very lemony-citric, over-the-top even.  Hazy, yellow and fizzy body.  Lots of lemons in the flavor.  Medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation.  The bottom line is: to many lemons, just didn¬ít click with me.
Aroma is lemony fresh. Apperance is murky yellow. The flavor is slightly sour with some sour lemons, dough, oranges, and bananas. A spicy and tart finish. Pretty good beer.
Very nice tripel and thanks to scoobyluv for bringing this one to the tasting in Atlanta.  NIce tripel with some good spice character.  Long finish...Good

Batch #42 Beautiful golden orange color with a very frothy white head.  Spicy nutmeg, clove and corriander aroma. Very sweet apple, orange, clove, nutmeg and corriander flavors. Surprisingly dry, bitter finish. Well carbonated. Very tingly.

Batch #41. Uncorks with a huge pop, pours hazy straw colored. The snow white head towers above the rim of my half-filled tulip glass, just like the pictures you see of tripels but almost never duplicate in real life. Massive lacing. Spicy musk in the nose, floral, pencil shavings, apples with brie, lavender soap, hot summer hayfield. Flavors of clovey spice, 7-up, juniper or quinine, cantaloupe, herbs-de-provence, barnyard and white pepper properties, and a chemical-like bitterness (did you ever taste residual hairspray in the air?) Dilute honey sweetness, yet finishes almost bone dry. Leaves a limestone wellwater feel on the tongue. Bizarre aftertaste of bitter salad greens, kiwi, and cigar ash. Well made but strange beer- a cacophony of tastes- I can't decide if I like it or not.

very gold and surprisingly clear for a tripel.  The yeast seemed to aggregate a bit more, actually a lot seemed to have dried out in the top of the neck.  Very foamy head, soft mouthfeel.  Fig, raisen sweetness upfront.  The finish is long, surprisingly dry and nicely bitter

Large white head, lasting, lots of lace. Beautiful nose, citrus, melon and fruit. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Hazy gold color. Fruity, peppery flavors, yeasty, pineapple and more melon. Nice 9%er! Finish is medium dry, fruity. Think i,ve had this beer in my cellar for a little over a year now, still yummy, nice.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2009 Batch #47 ¬ñ This beer has a sparkling clear golden body with very lively medium bubbles careening to certain death in a nice pillowy white head. The aroma is that of yeast, citrus (orange), spices (clove, a touch of ginger), and banana. The flavor is outstanding; the banana come out more in the flavor then if did in the aroma. All of the other flavors mingle together nicely to provide a wonderful flavor spectrum. The body is medium-full with a thick mouth coating finish, that also manages to be crisp and warming. There is no evidence of alcohol in the flavor and only a tad on the palate. An excellent American brewed Beligan Tripel.

Hazy yellow/gold body. Tremendous creamy white head no matter how gingerly you attempt to pour. Smells of pine cones, apple juice and yeast.  Tastes of malt, clove, apples and pears. Taste is sweet, light and tasty. Everything about this beer seems careful most likely demonstrative of how this beer was made. Very well made beer and most importantly, delicious. Sampled from a 750ml bottle (Batch# 33) with my cousin and good friend Ryan.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 Like juicy fruit gum. Very fruity. Banana, citrus. Like a German hefe that grew up to be Belgian ale. Hint of floral, clove and spice as well. Slightly slick texture. A US Belgian done very right.
(Bottle)  Pours a hazy golden color with a large white head.  Fruit and floral aroma with flavors of banana and honey make for an enjoyable drinking experience.
Very very good. Nice pour with a foggy golden color and a large white head. Hoppy aroma, some fruit hints in the taste. Very enjoyable!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2005 Pours with a nice white head with average lacing. Nice orange and spicy aroma. Very nice. 

Another rating pours with a nice head that falls flat on it¬ís face. More sweet orange.
Not my favorite triple.  I thought it was too hoppy for the style, hops of a bitter pale ale in a triple.  BUT, the one I had was fresh, and I bet this would age wonderfully, so I'll put some aside.
Very nice Tripel. Poured in a Chimay glass it looked like Duvel, but the head didn't last as long. Peppery and fruity, with a dry finish but good body. Thoroughly enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2009 2009-12-05. Lightly hazy golden body, not much head. 3+ Flavour is mildly alcoholic, modest pale malts, toasty touches. Aroma is mild, light citrusy hops? Muted yeast. 6+ Average palate is very lightly carbonated. Okay, but not well served by being on cask in my opinion. 7/3+/6+/3/14 3.4 Cask at Coles, Buffalo
January 2006. Bottle, upwards of 14 months old. Hazy golden yellow body with a big fluffy white head. Sweet palt malt in aroma, mild hops and alcohol. Dry alcohol in flavour, light spicey pepper notes, pale malt, light floral notes. Average to medium palate. (3+) Very nice, but not spectacular. 7/4/6+/3+/14-15 - 3.6
December 2003. Dark yellow gold colour. Floral and bitter. Had a bit of a catch in my throat quality to it. Couldn¬ít wrap my head around it. First time I wanted to tell a beer "It¬ís not you, it¬ís me!" Batch 37. 6/3/6/3/13 - 3.1

Absolutely, without a doubt, the best, most enjoyable tripel I've had...ever!  The only lacking point is a SLIGHTLY weak aroma (which is very nice otherwise!).  Appearance would have benefitted from a larger head, but the color is great!  Flavor is wonderful...dry, spicy, and full...and the finish is nice too!  Really an exceptional example of the style!

750 ml. caged & corked bottle. Batch # 39. No freshness date that I can see. Poured out a hazy, bright orange color, with a humongus head on it. The head slowly faded to a large yeasty island floating on top of the beer. Aromas were of tropical fruit, and a slight lemon aroma as well. I think this bottle has passed it's prime, but I'll drink it all the same. Tasted ok, malty as all hell, and the hops were somewhat subdued by the lemon taste. I never noticed any banana aromas, but maybe this bottle didn't have any.
Finished somewhat dry, had a thinnish body to it as well. Had a decent alcohol kick to it. Fairly good example of the style, I only wish I could have tried it a bit fresher.
Started off like champagne! then slowly it became beer. yeasty nose, light spice in the taste. it finished bitter and herbal. not too complex but tasted fine and easy to drink.

(bottled, batch #41).  Rich gold color, brilliant clarity.  Pleasing ripe fruit, bready aroma.  Big malt body with lots of fruit flavor and an assertive, herbal bitterness. Lacks a bit of the musty complexity I was hoping for. Dry, lingering finish with peppery alcohol.  An excellent beer!
Superb tripel. Soft, hazy gold appearence with filmy head and some lacing. Extremely creamy with mild tropical and citrus fruits and malt. Warming alcohol finish.

Aroma is of ripe fruit and yeast, with a buttery sweetness to it. Body is clear and golden with a fluffy white head. Some ftuit notes in the taste as well as the yeast, and a subtle honey flavor. Finish is long smooth and dry. Good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2003 Another ceiling basher. Deep golden color. Foamy white head. Pleasant, but not overwhelming spicy aroma. Notes of Orange peel. Malty and spice palate, with a light, yet sharp butterness. Orange peel once again noted, but also there was a relatively strong hop presence. Very smooth and satisfying.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: I lucked out and found this brew at my local liquor store on sale for $3.99 (normally $7.50). Wheaty, somewhat off, cookie aroma. Similar to an Austrian bock in the nose. Banana yellow in color, cloudy, with a small, white head. Good, visible carbonation. Wow! Rich wheaty, strong alcohol presence. Plummy fruit flavor with a semblance of hop profile. Wonderful and warming. Not exactly a session brew at 9% ABV, but this beer is exceptional.

This blondy appears foggy with little diminishing head.  I like head, she doesn't cut it.  She's probably not supposed to given her style.  But I find it insulting none the less.  I find her taste interesting and distinctively dry.  Overall her golden puss was somewhat enjoyable...not as enjoyable as all you other snobs that have had her.

Batch 35. very hazy medium golden..slight head. aroma is big on clove with a hint of coriander. banana hits me first in the flavor. lots of spices and a hint of toffee in the finish. the 9% ABV is very well-masked.
Pours a very hazy light golden color, nice head.  Bananas and yeast in the sweet nose.  Bitter in the finish.

Batch 31 - The smell is light, alcoholic, with a hint of spices and a strong ester overtone. The taste is of light corriander, and bananas at the onset, followed by a yeasty and bitter middle in which the flavor seems to dissappear. kinda tounge-numbing.
Aroma is yesaty, citrusy, slightly spicy. Appearance is murky golden yellow. Flavor is good up front with a bland middle and an uninspiring finish.

batch 35, had a light golen color too it with a thin white head.  Very clean and smooth taste was sweet a touch of alcohol, finsihing with a hoppy bite. Flavours were light for the most part with a hint of banana on the nose.

750ml, batch #31.  Cloudy bright yellow appearance underneath a big white head.  The aroma is mellow banana, lemon spice, and is quite nice, subtle but complex.  Only a light hint of alcohol present, which was suprising ans appreciated.  Sharp up front, then going from a tart, spicey banana flavor to a bland, sour cardboard flavor with the mouth feeling anesthetized.

With a careful pour¬óand despite its bottle conditioning¬óthis beer decants as an inviting, golden hued ale with a enormous but quickly dissipating, rocky white head.  There was a thin sediment layer on the bottom of the corked and caged 750 ML bottle, which read ¬ìBatch #39.¬î  I found that the beer left some excellent lacing.  The aroma is inviting and robust, with hints of green apple or pear and spice.  This ale is clean, dry and refreshing from start to finish, but it is sufficiently complex to hold the interest this reviewer.  The initial palate is bright and spicy, but quickly yields to fruit notes of assorted variety.  I recognized the brewery¬ís suggestions of banana and honey.  I also discovered a hint of lemony citrus flavor mid-palate.  The level of carbonation is less prominent than other bottle conditioned ales, and the alcohol flavor is well-balanced with the other flavors.  This is a medium-bodied ale, with a long, dry finish.
Batch 32:  Hazy blond body, white head.  Very light aroma of banana and spice.  Very carbonated, bubblegum flavor with lemon and other fruits.  Excellent.

Clear gold color with a medium creamy white head.  Very aromatic as each sip gives you a different perspective.  It is a subtle sazz hop and a strong yeast, weak bubblegum, straw, and lemongrass.  Taste is spicy( pepper, cloves), sweet yeast.  Carbonated and sweet finish.
Powerful musky and alcoholic aroma. Pale, white head, not too big, cloudy. Spicy and bitter flavor, strong yeast and obvious alcohol presence. Very Duvel-esque.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2003 Batch #28...750ml bottle

Using my Allagash tulip glass to drink this heavenly nectar, it pours a burnished gold that is perfectly clear from a careful pour. A frothy, off-white head starts out thick, then slowly shrinks down to small cap. It's easily brought back up again with a simple swirl. The lace looks a lot like soap suds overlooked on a car window in the middle of a hot, sticky summer.  Wonderfully complex aroma with suggestions of spicy fruits, banana, grape, clove, phenolics, bready yeast, alcohol, and a musty earthy note. Despite this wide array of scents, the aroma comes across as sweet. Stunning...  The flavor is sweet and spicy, with lots of fruitiness and honey on the forefront. After the initial rush of sweetness, the flavor shifts to a slighty phenolic one, along with a small burst of black pepper spiciness. The clove, yeast, and musty flavors are in there too, but play secondary roles and stay mostly in the background. The tail end has a rush of warming alcohol, which is highlighted by a touch of hops. Again, stunning¬Ö  This brew is highly carbonated, but settles to a creamy, soft mouthfeel that is just a bit prickly on the tongue. The body is on the lighter side of medium. Alcohol dries out the finish considerably.  An incredibly well-done domestic tripel!

Batch #37. Hazy Golden color, fluffy white head. I smelled apples upon opening. Further inspection revealed pears, yeast, spice, among others. Complex fruity/spicy flavor. Very smooth, finish was not quite as long as described above. I'll definitely drink again.
Clear golden colour.  A fruity spicy beer, some pear notes, herbal notes.  A nice mix of spiciness and sweetness.
This is one of my favorite all-time beers. Light yellow in color...complex,fruity and smooth. So much to taste in this tripel...
Blond beer with a small head. Fruit and yeast aroma. Sweet, yeasty, fruity alcohol taste. Neutral finish and aftertaste.

Batch #34.The appearance was a large sized white head that consisted of fine-small sized bubbles.There was was carbonation observed with this beer along with a cloudy body.The hue was yellow and the nose consisted of malt, hops, fruit, and cloves.The flavor was sour, tart, and fruity.It had bubbly and smooth mouthfeel along with a medium body.There was virtually no lacing with this beer.

Batch #34: This brew poured a large head of fine to medium sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind very little lacing and a hazy straw yellow colored body behind.  THe aroma is a mild yeasty one and the mouthfeel is smooth with a slight tingly bite to it.  The flavor is a mixture of fruity textures with csome clove banana and a high alcohool content noted.
Batch #36:  As soon as I worked the cork out, I immediately smelled apples.  Very smooth and tasty with a clean finish.  Highly recommended.

Impressive lasting crown of luxurious foam. Rich, pure vanilla sugared floral aroma...By floral I mean strong, crisp and almost masculine--no roses or pansies here. Noticed notes of subtle lime vanilla as well as cork. Creamy, well-blended and perfect sweet-tart blend are other descriptors that came to mind.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2003 Honey cloudiness with subtle nose hints tripel to-die-for, but a surprising peppery undertones is so distracting, I must say the least fav of my triple experiences despite its head ;).
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Pretty golden color with an attractive white head and a subtle spice nose.  Lots of coriander spice with very fruity, almost vinous flavors.  Sharp yeast in the finish.  Nice body and a good beer.

What a nice beer.Great honey golden/copper(hazy,very pretty bubblesSmells fruity/alcoholic(teases of champagne?)slight banana/definite honey(great malt/hop blend).Nice little head that is not in a hurry to leave you(yet not obnoxious like duvel)The lace is sent from heaven.The taste is so smooth for a tripel.Nice hops/great dry finish.A must try for belgian lovers.A masterpiece from Allagash.Batch# 38.On finishing this blessed 750ml the yeast at the bottom brings this one together even better.Super hazy/yeasty/smooth.Get it!(reasonable price)

Golden cloudy color with large head that stays. Sweet fruity flavor that has a nice hoppy spicey taste. Sweeter than other tripel's I have had.Nicely balanced. Finishes dry and long with a little alcohol feel in the mouth. Great american tripel.

Batch 33: Hot damn, Timdanchanta is 21!  He secured this one up in Illinois a couple of weeks ago for his first "legal" beer.  So anyway,  poured a pure golden color with a long-lasting thick white head.  Flavor was fruity, with a little bit of sourness thrown in there - the complexity is admirable.  A terrific beer, and a very happy b-day to my good friend Tim.
Batch 33: Cloudy appearence with just a tad bit of sourness.  I could problably taste more of the flavor if I did not have a Macanudo beforehand.  An honorable 1st beer for my 21st.

Batch #33: Hazy tangerine hue with big fluffy head and outstanding lacing. Aroma hints of large yeast(sourdough bread); big and fruity(passion fruit, apricot, ripe pear, blueberry, banana); spices (clove and corriander), and vanilla. Malty taste at the start followed by a twangy yeast and then a massive spicy finish. Very once in a while I detect a sour fruity undertone, but next gulp, it's gone again. Surprising dry and crisp for a large tripel. Medium to full-bodied, it has a lively mouthfeel and a bit alcoholic feel. Wow, a unique take on the style, doesn't suffer by becoming overly sweet, in fact it's almost overly spicy. One damn nice American version of the classic style. Thanks to BierBauch for the trade.
hazy light orange, white head.  citrus, yeast and sweet vanilla bean aroma.  flavour bursts with honey and black pepper with fruit and a light hoppy bite.  finishes soft and slightly creamy.

Medium honey orange with medium light creamy head. Very faint floral and yeast aroma. Mouth filling medium light body. Soft floral honey and tropical fruity sweet and lighter bitter flavours. I was a bit disappointed in this one as I found it kinda bland for an Abbey tripel

Slightly hazy peach color with a thick whitish head. Aroma of fruity tastiness (light pineapple) and bready malts with a slight twang. Sweet maltiness with fruity flavors. Sugary and lightly hoppy with a subtle spiciness. What I expect from a trippel. Moderate mouthfeel and soft but steady carbonation. Nice dry finish. Alcohol not evident.
Gold colour with small white head.  Aroma of citrus and alcohol.  Flavour is malty, yeasty, with some alcohol heat.  Finishes dry and musty.
(75o ml bottle) Batch 40. Golden body with dissipating white head. Citrus and perfume nose. Strong malt, vanilla and slight hops. Finishes mellow and marshy...

Batch 35. Hazy golden color. Soapy white head that left good lacing. Enticing smells of apricots and peaches, candy sugar, banana and vanilla. Taste is best described as a combination of the smell, apricots,  peaches and bananas drizzled with vanilla and sprinkled with candy sugar. Yet this beer somehow manages not to be overly sweet. The 9% ABV is extraordinarily well hidden. One of the best American Belgian triples. Top Notch.

Wow, why is it that I feel the effects of alcohol much more with lighter beer than with darker beers.  Have only had half a goblet and am already losing focus.  Thin lacey head with great carbonation.  Aroma dominatd by wheat/yeast with a little bit of wine/grapes.  Color is a medium gold with decent clarity.  Flavor is a combnation of wheat and spices with a bubbly effervescence.  Finish is long like the description says and it slightly bitter and leaves a plesant aftertaste in the mouth.  Additionally, there is a nice alcohol warming.  Yeah Baby!  A very good triple.

Batch 34.  Yellowish brown color with a big head.  Rich aroma of alcohol, grapes, bannana, pear, other fruits.  Trace of hops as well.  Lots of pleasant alcohol in the taste with lots of fruit too.  Pear, apple, raisin, it's all in there.  A wonderful beer.  Savor every sip.  When you're finished with the 750 mL bottle, at 9%, you'll really feel it.

Let me start by saying I'm an unabashed Allagash fan... On with the show: This is a Batch 32 bottle. Nice head, pleasing citrus aroma. Color is cloudy golden. Flavor is bright and sweet, with hints of spice. HUGE lacing. Dry finish. One of my all-time favorites.

Sweet and spicy wheat aroma with some nice citrus. Light golden amber cloudy with light head. Silky body with medium-heavy champagne carbonation. Alcoholic with spices and herbs. Wheat, grass. Light hops. Sweet finish and after, with light bitterness. A brandy-like smoothness in the after.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Nice golden color with a tall, white head. Lots of carbonation; more than I expected. The flavor is very sweet & lingers very nicely; like other raters have said, it has an almost candy-like flavor. There is a definite alcohol presence in the finish, but it¬ís still very smooth; not harsh at all. A very impressive beer.

Edit: Just tried a 2-year cellared bottle. It¬ís smoother, with a fuller, more yeasty mouthfeel. The fruit is a little muted - it might¬íve lost a little bit of flavor. 1 year of aging should be just about right for this beer.

Hazy, gold, small but "lacey" head; Earthy aroma of wet stone drying in the sun and dried herbs. Creamy palate with a wide array of fruit flavors, I'll go with tangerine, white peach, nectarine and, YOU GUESSED IT, strawberry. Nice prickle on the tongue from well integrated carbonation with a nice little marshmallow and blueberry interplay on the mildly warming finish...is this secretly contract brewed in Belgium? The highest rated US triple, and with good reason.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2005 Bright golden, a bit cloudy.  Darker color than expected.  Nose is lovely, a bit bready, quite spicy, hints of lemon and orange peel.  Nice yeasty flavor, good roundness.  Has a spicy zippiness, has a slightly pine character to it.  Finishes dry.  Chewy and sweet, bubblegumlike with lots of candy sugars.  Nice palate.  The best tripel in the world, and it comes from Maine?  Who woulda thunk it.

Rocky, slowly diminishing head.  Slightly hazy honey color.  Lots of carbonation.  The cork came out with some decent force.  Yeasty, estery aroma.  Soft mouthfeel.  Yeasty.  Dry finish.  One of Allagash's great offerings.

Batch #33: Cloudy orange color with a nice white head. Aroma and flavor consisted of some nice fruity tones...clove, banana, bubblegum, sweaty body odor, old lady's perfume, grass. Bubbly feel, dry finish.

Batch # 32 750ml bottle - Nice pale gold yellow color, got a tall white head of fluffy smooth stryrofoam that falls apart in sections leaving huge clumbs and ledges of foamy stringy lace. Smell is lots of bright citrus, orange, lemon, and lime, dulled a bit with some nice yeast and spicyness. Taste is subtle and complex in layers with a nice flow of citrusy lemon, orange, a bit of banana, nice leveled yeast, some grainyness squeezed in as well and lightly dancing spicyness of citrus rinds and black pepper with a good sweet malt balance the whole way through. Finishes with a light hop hold and alcohol warming. Full body, pretty rich, bold, creamy even, and a nice hold of bittering fruitness and spice. Nice complexity to this triple and is quite a nice offering in the style

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 Batch #105: Pours a deep golden bronze with a nicely-lacing froth of white head.  Aroma of sweet biscuity pale malt and Belgian yeast and a touch of grassy hops.  Body starts rich and light caramely biscuity sweet with some light fruity esters and authentic doughy yeastiness.  Finishes lightly bitter, full and sweet with some pear and strawberry notes.  Has good complexity and balance, a true to style Abbey Tripel.

Pours a golden apricot color. Nose is banana/oranges/peaches with some herbal and spicy aromas as well. Taste is sweet candied sugar up front followed by some fruitiness as well as a subtle spice kick. A perfect way to celebrate my last Saturday night on the East Coast.
.75 liter bottle Nice presentation, lovely aroma. Taste is reasonably yeasty, but there was too much bitterness this time. Dunno. Still a good beer.

Batch 26.  I've had this baby laying down for a year ever since I picked it up from the brewery.  Popped open with solid oomph.  Gorgeous appearance, a hazy golden color with a nice head, subsiding into a rocky, lasting foam.  Aroma was distinctly of honey drizzled over whole wheat bread.  Explosive taste, filling the mouth with flavors of honey, oak, and hay.  Nice bitterness on the finish, somewhat dry.  The alcohol is warming, and the palate utterly perfect.  A sensational beer.  I bow in awe.

Joy joy joy. I found this in San Antonio at an establishment that I can't divulge. These moments of beer discovery in Texas are most prized. Touch of clove and pear esters. Big foamy off white head. Plenty of yeast character. Crisp cool and maybe peaks at 52¬∞F. Delicious, lightly creamy feel. How does Allagash do this? The yeast tastes very familiar.

Wow.  The belgian styles being brewed domestically are incredible.  I am a big fan of New Belgium and I think this surpases that one.  Pours up a huge fluffy paper white head.  Wonderful flavor with hints of pear and honey.  Long finish.  Very good.

Batch # 38. Initially missed the honey notes as I had a mishap prior to tasting with real local honey. Certainly finding it at the bottom of a 750. Delicious. In a blind taste I can say that I would not have distinguished this as being anything other than a true Belgian. Peppery, spicey, and with the yeastyness that I expect. A finish that just goes on for miles. The label does not lie. Well, I have as of yet not done any cellaring .... 
 As for the visuals - hazy, light gold with a whipped egg white lioke head that dissipates.
From batch #33 - golden and bubbly with a white head.  Enticingly sweet aroma. Exhibits a dry honey flavor with a bit of spice that lingers on the tongue.  At its best at cellar temperature.
Batch #36. Deep golden color, tiny bubbles in the tiny head. Peachy fruity honey nose. Earthy spicy pepper finish. Needs to be drunk at cellar temperature.

Batch 35. Slightly cloudy, soft light golden color. White head diminishes fairly quickly. Very nice aroma of fruit (apples?) and yeast. Flavor is predominantly malt, alcohol, and sweet fruit including bananna and apple. Finish is slightly dry, malty and warm from the alcohol. Also a pleasant lingering chewy bread/yeast aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2003 Another top quality brew from Allagash. Slightly hazy orange-amber color with huge head and every visual characteristic of the Belgian style. Seemed similar to their White except for a few noticable variations. The appearance reminded me of Orval, color and head. Also fruity and a little spicy. Banana comes to mind. Fantastic brew! Best when on the warm side.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Draught.  I guess I am going to be solo on this one.  A friend of mine at a beer fest said "tripel what?"  I would say that 3 times nothing is still nothing.  The prevalent flavor is water.  The beer is way too light.  I can taste hints of yeast and maybe that sugary taste is honey, but ovverall this beer is empty.  I didn't notice many of the aspects of the style.  Very dissapointing.
Big orange and candi sugar nose, with a hint of muscat grapes. The palate is very fruity, with loads of orange, pineapple, and honey. The finish is long and spicy (black pepper).
A smooth golden ale with frothy head. Honey fruitiness in the nose. Malty fruity flavors with touch earthy spiciness. Finishes relatively balanced.
This beer had an explosive cork and an overflowing effervescence.  It poured a cloudy gold with a white head.  The taste was a little dry compared to other tripels, but still very good.

A great hazy golden colour with a perfect head which does not fade at all! A great smell of cloves and bananas, and other complex aromas. The taste is great...pure complexity. Full bodied with a good carbonation and a clean taste - honey, bananas, spice, wheat all dominate the palate. A great beer in a big bottle - suitable for cellaring makes it a great beer. Especially at this price! I picked up the large bottle for $6. This was batch #34. At the store (Beers of the World in Rochester, New York) they had batch #30 & #34, but I figured the latter would be better. I might buy both batches and cellar them for a while, to see what results can happen in a year or two! :-) Definately try this beer, or any by Allagash if you haven't already!
Wow what a great tasting triple. Has a lot of flavors going on, I can taste hints of citrus and bannana in this brew. Alcohol is very well hidden. Excellent !!!

This had a lot of Belgian yeast, a lot of fruity estery malt, and just a lot of Belgianness. In fact, I don't think there was anything really special about this beer, it was just really big and really powerful within the style. Very musky on the back of the palate and just very pervasive, but nothing really special.
Had a typical tripel taste, with a lot of yeast going on. Not very complex, light bodied. A good beer, but not anything amazing.

Cloudy light orange color.  Nose is yeasty and spicey with hints of banana.  The body is heavy on the yeast with a nice spiciness and a decent hop bite towards the end.  Balanced, complex, juicy.  Very nice.
A beautiful golden color, hazy with a sticky white head. Sweet flavors of honey and very light spice. Very mild hops notes at the end. Can't wait to get more.

Bath #34. Sweet honey, herbal, meadow like (flowers), nice and pleasant. Cloudy amber, orangey, white impressive head. Interesting taste. Sweet but soft, light velvety taste with notes of nuts with nice hops. Very nice beer.
Light golden orange color. Very smooth, sweet with vanilla flavor, good spices. Soothing and warm. This is a real treat, almost a dessert. Couldn't wait to finish the bottle.
Hazy blond w/ orange-ish hue & big white head. Lovely aroma of banana, spice, cloves & yeast. Light, spritzy body. Fresh banana flavour w/ bread & spices. Dry, tingly, warm finish.

Wow, this is really good.  Sweet but not cloying.  Very yeasty aroma.  It does taste like passion fruit, but I'd have never pinpointed it without the commercial description.  Unusual spicy flavors.  Complex and intriguing, one of the best beers I've had.
Yeast, citrus aroma, hazy golden, good sized white head. Tastes of kumquat, and bread. Really good mouth feel. A great Tripel.
Dark blond, cloudy.  Aroma of perfume, spice, malt.  Pale malts and flowery notes.  Dryish, yeasty finish.  Quality tripel.

Aroma of malt, plums, yeast, and a little hop spiciness.  Pours a fairly clear orange-straw with a white foamy head.  A lot of Belgian-style ales have impressive aromas, but then the flavor doesn't live up to expectations - not this one.  It has a robust flavor of malt and light fruit, I get slight notes of vanilla, and then a spicy, kind of salty finish.  Soft mouthfeel with an even finish.  Quite a nice tripel, better than some Trappist examples.
A cloudy deep yellow possibly could be considered orange, short bus color.  Gives moderate head.  Bitter white grapefuit flavor. Very yeasty and chalky, a really earth like feel to it. Solid.
