Orange color. Medium head. Aroma is malty and slightly sweet. A medium bodied Abbey Tripel. Slightly yeasty, and somewhat tart. Touch of fruit, lemon and oranges, bananas and peaches. Smooth taste. Slight sweetness. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.

Tonight was a good night. "Why," you ask? Because I discovered this beer and I discovered 2 hours of Kids in the Hall on Comedy Central. While the Allagash Tripel was all spiced cream and fruits (mostly bananas and peaches), Kids in the Hall is Funny. While Allagash is made in Maine, the Kids in the Hall are Canadian. Oakes is Canadian as well but while this beer's beautiful bright golden amber body sparkled with constant effervescence and the thick, creamy white head sheeted and even chunked the side of the glass, Oakes is not funny. At least not in the cross-dressing, irreverent, absurdist humor way that the Kids in the Hall were. Damn this is a fine beer, probably my favorite in the style.

Colour: straw to chromate-yellow, clear. Very thick, white head.
Nose: buttermilk whilst pouring, yes, diacetyl! Overpowers everything else.
Taste: dry-bitterish, quite outspoken at first, merges into a soft-sweetness. Again very lactic touch. Definitely diacetyl but luckily less pronounced than in the nose. I want to taste citrus, spicyness and hops, but keep getting butterscotch.
Mouthfeel: very mellow, yet dry. Slightly sticky. Throat-warming effect.
Aftertaste: as said, creamy-sweetness - keeps relatively long.

Diacetyl is a killer, certainly in blond & dry beers. An esteemable effort - but ruined
Light yellow in color, slightly hazey.  Yeastly, clove aroma.  Complex flavor of fruit tartness, Belguim yeast and clove.  Very balanced.  On the finish I taste mostly spice.

Pale golden with an attractive billowing head.  Aroma is nice and soft, a bit of alcohol, definitely not a "hot" aroma, some hops too.  Bright clean maltiness.  Doesn't show its alcohol at all.  Clean and bright with bits of honey a nice subdued spiciness.  Tripel is a hard category to succeed in with me and this one does a good job.
Batch #22.  Great Triple.  Complex and well balanced.  Fruity, spicy and yeasty flavor.  Recommended.

One of the more interestingly flavored Belgians I have had to date. With the appearance of a peach-orange sunrise and foamy head--the rating experience started auspiciously. The aroma was of wood, yeast, coriander? (and maybe unripe banana peel), and definitely conjured up memories of witbiers, with an initially indiscernable tangy quality present in flavor as well. After some skunky notes aired and a harsh raw estery quality dissipated, the distinct tastes were easier to identify--this is certainly a complex ale. Again, wood and a witbieresque interplay were significant factors. After at least half the tasting spent in bafflement trying to decipher the tangy X quality I realized it was grapefruit--which dominated the experience. I don't care for grapefruit, but still a decent beer. Upon reading the "commercial description," it seems the grapefruit character must be passion fruit--right on...

As a novice beer rater - I do not quite grasp a lot of the subtle notes  that the more experienced raters here do - as a result I may not appreciate some of the qualities that an ale like this posessess. However, of the few strong Belgians that I have had - this one has to be the best.  It did not overwhelm me with alcohol - though it is quite present! The most obvious flavor coming through to me is sweet honey with a strong spice finish. The pour is a show in itself with effervescent bubbles flowing through the entire 750 ml bottle. Aroma - hint of clove and banana.  Storng to the finish - excellent mouthfeel.

A great American tripel in true Belgian style.  Beautiful full translucent cloudy deep golden beer with a huge firm white head.  Nose of yeast, wheaty bread, hops, and fruit.  Taste of yeast, but balanced with sweet bread, lemony fruit, spice, and a finish of bitter hops.  As it warms, pepper and cloves add bite, though I never did get the banana fruit that often comes along with these spice tastes in a wheat beer.    Really nicely balanced, not too yeasty, not too sweet, not too anything.

Batch #34 - whatever that means. Aroma was fruity with sweet caramel or butter toffee bits and an alcoholic tone. Looks great - bottle, label, deep honey-gold beer with a nice raft of head.  Superbly balanced and smooth. Perhaps too smooth for a 9% beer -- so watch out.  Perhaps a little on the dry side initially, but then the sweetness hits you mid-palate. Nice silky palate where the hops kick in.  Outstanding, and hard to beat "round here.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 it poured a cloudy brilliant yellowy orange with a topping of bright white..the aroma was yeasty with bits of apricot and banana, and some orange too..the aroma was very chewy indeed..spicy, dry, apricots, peaches, bananas, some alcohol bite at the end..everything is splendid until the finish where i started to find  a clash of some kind going on with the alcohol the fruitiness and the yeasty spiciness..however..it did subside with time and I am normally not a huge fan of trippels, and this one was one of the best I've had

Batch 28: Wonderful golden hazy yellow color.  By far the best tripel I¬íve had.  Alcohol well incorporated and yeasty/fruity profile is perfectly matched.  Great spice, but subdued enough to prevent overwhelming notes, great dry finish.
Batch #32: Wow! This is some excellent strong ale.  The spices were light and the honey was just right for the palate. Smooth and subtle sweet finish.  ;)

Batch 30.  This is an impressively heavy, full-bodied Tripel.  I agree, notalush, it is very similar to Victory¬ís Golden Monkey -  the alchohol content is similiar, as is the finish.  Dark golden body, white lacing.  Complex flavors that are difficult to distinguish from one another.  Banana?  I¬ím not sure, but definetly wheat and yeasts are strongly present.

Batch 30.  This looks, smells, and tastes almost exactly like Victory Golden Monkey.  Translation: It¬ís a damn good tripel.  The major difference this has is it¬ís somewhat dry finish.  There are less spices in this brew, but I most certainly taste the banana and honey suggested in the commercial description.  I think this is a bit better (heavier, fuller flavored) than the monkey, but not by much.  It¬ís 5.29 price tag is the lowest I¬íve paid for a 750 ml bottle, which is a major plus.
Batch 25. Cloudy yellowish-orange. Great head. A thin layer stays on it as you drink. Yeasty aroma with a slight alcohol nose. Had bits of sweetness to it. Finishes dry. A great beverage.

Batch 31.  I would like this better in a smaller quantity (my wife bailed out on this one and I was left alone to finish).  All of the great tropical fruit and spicy flavors with tremendous hop perfume.  Beautiful lasting head.  Amazed at how well this American brewery replicates the style.  Beats out a number of Belgian-brewed trippels, in my humble opinion.

Batch #28: translucent golden appearence with a thin beading, frothy snow-white head.  Intensely complex fruity aroma; apple, mango, passion fruit, peach.  It¬ís like walking through an orchard.  The flavour is mellow and fruity at first with a candyish/warming middle and a nice dry finish.  It¬ís a toss up between this and New Belgium for the best American trippel.

Batch #28, slightly cloudy golden color, with a nice sized head, nice yeasty aroma with a hint of spice, very smooth and easy drinking with hints of banana, citrus, spice, alcohol is very well hidden, a most enjoyable brew

Batch 28: Hazy lemon color with small bubbles.  First sip tasted like fresh cotton candy melting in the mouth.  Mellows into a warm sugar alcohol sensation.  In the middle there¬ís a dry grass flavor coupled with an acidic banana taste.  Well rounded triple.

Bottle from batch #30.  Golden color with a white head and lots of rising bubbles.  Sweet candy, citrus, orange, honey, and fruits infuse this beer with character and punch.  The creamy and smooth body was a highlight compared to many harsh tripels.  I can¬ít wait to have this one again.
Yellow orange with a beautiful off white head.  Full flavours of wheat, yeast, sweet spices.  A grassy field on a warm summer¬ís day.  A perfectly pleasant farmhouse feel.  Wonderful.
Just what a tripel should be

Spicy, yeasty nose; hazy orange color and a lacy head. Sweet, sugary start with hints of light honey and apples in the middle. Broad, slightly dry peppery finish. Great balance, medium body and all around a quality brew. The alcohol stays rather in the background but provides a warming effect on the mouth and in the swallow.

Batch # 30: Banana, spices, fruit and yest are coming right into my nose. Nice orange color, little frothy head leaving brussels lace on the glas. Peppery but ligth flavor, also yeast, apricots and honey. Smooth, silky warm finish. Our cat liked the aroma - catnip in this brew? Great brew.

Batch 27: Yeasty, very slight soapy aroma before it warmed.  Looked very nice...good head, good retention in it.  strawberry blonde color.  Full-bodied taste was rather smooth, sweet & spicy.  Alcohol was masked ridiculously well.

Batch 25.  Poured a slightly hazy yellow/gold.  Nice head and great lacing top to bottom.  Tangy citrus with light spices in the background.  Yeast, light sugars, some alcohol presence, and long thin sweet/peppery, mild hop finish.  top quality brew.

Batch #30. What a magnificent brew, and to think that it was made right here in the USA. Glowing golden in color with a huge white head. Aroma of tropical fruits and yeast, banana and bread.(like a wheat beer without the earthy tones) Flavor is long and lasts long after the last drop. Complex with the same banana and tropical fruits, yeast and spices that were exibited in the nose. Mellows in the finish with the yeast and malts being evident. TThere is so much more to this beer that I cannot put words to. It is, on the downside, a little bit on the abrupt side.with a little bit of aging however it would be on the top of the list of world class brews.

Batch 24.  Stellar.  Incredibly smooth.  Somewhat less head than I expected.  Very similar to Duvel, one of my favorites.  You aren¬ít really aware of the alcohol in this.  These guys can make a beer.  I think that their Belgians are even better tham Omengang¬ís!
Looks exactly like a Chimay White.  Prominent tangy yeasty flavor.  Fruity aroma that somewhat disappears in the taste.  Hints of grape flavor.
Batch 30.Supurb triple.Mild sweet bready aroma.Fine carbonation.Very smooth fruity herbal dry flavor with balanced peach flavor sweetness.

Cloudy pale yellow color with a medium white head and lasting lace.  The aroma is slightly sweet and lemony with a touch of spice and yeast.  The flavor is spicy, yeasty and malty with a hint of citrus.  Heavy bodied, warm in the throat, tingly on the tongue.

Batch 19:  Hazy golden peach.  Big white foamy head.  Aroma of carambola, honeydew, light fruit.  Yeast is dominant flavor, medium bodied, light footed, alcohol is evident yet not too dominating.  Finishes spicy, white pepper, dry, honey, and terribly pleasant...very enjoyable!

Batch #26.  This beer is excellent.  Tons of fruit throughout, including the above mentioned passion fruit, sour apples, and a touch of citrus.  Also a nice dash of spice (mostly clove and a little cinnamon) adds to this delectable beer.  Enjoy it if you can.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2003 10/24/02 Batch #27: Golden yellow, big white head, nice fruity and yeasty aroma. Bananas and spices dominate the flavor. Very smooth and enjoyable, with just the right amount of carbonation. Long malty sweet finish, great belgian style ale. 
02/24/03 Batch #34: Pours a clear golden yellow with a big white head that lingers. It has a fruity, yeasty aroma with a touch of cloves and banana. Medium body and medium carbonation, the flavor is all spices, malts, banana, and honey-this is a fantastic brew.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2003 750ml bottle, batch #26.
Pours a medium-dark, hazy golden color, with a large frothy white head that doesn't want to go away, clinging to the sides of the glass for dear life all the way down.  Aroma is crisp - citric (lemon), spicy (clove), yeasty (banana), and light malt (doughy) .  Flavor is also crisp, sweet start, making way for some banana and clove to coat the tongue in the middle, ends with some citrus - lemon and grapefruit mostly.  Full body, complex flavors that get more impressive as the bottle gets more empty, only the slightest hint of alcohol at the end.
intesting,  reminded me alot of westy 8 for some reason.  strong belgian flavor
Batch #28. Like their own description, subtle banana & honey flavors. It has a great nose; reminds me a bit of a white beer. It¬ís cloudy yellow w/ a big white frothy head.

Batch #28:  Wow.  Big nose with pepper, cherry, strawberry and yeast all present.  Filled half the kitchen with this wonderful aroma.  Very fruity up front(banana, strawberries, cherries) with coriander showing through towards the middle as the beer leans toward peppery spiciness.  Finish is spicy, nice and dry, and has a pronounced warming alcohol effect.  This beer is a sight to behold - hazy golden with a large, frothy head that wants to stick around for a few minutes before completely dissappearing.  Body and mouthfeel are just right.  Sits nicely on the tongue and doesn¬ít leave a pronounced or long aftertaste. Marvelous.

This beer rocks. I bet Stephen King drinks this stuff before writing each day up in Portland. I¬íve tried a ton of Belgian Strong Ales. I like most of them and love just a few. The Westy¬ís are awesome. Allagash isn¬ít far behind the Westy Blonde. If you agree with my other Belgian beer ratings, you will really love this beer.

Nose is spicey with a touch of orange coming to the fore. Flavor is complex but well-balanced. Quite sweet, but the sweetness balances out a warming dose of alcohol. Hints of oranges, coriander, cinnamon, and apples all compete for a place on the palate.

Very complex,fruity and sweet in the beginning,it has a lively carbonation.  Sweet start then a warming spicy finish. 9% ABV is well hidden,lightly yellow,and quite frothy, Drinkable and Recommended !

Golden, hazy color topped off with a white foamy head.  Noticable hints of honey and banana.  ABV is somewhat hidden, but what does come through adds to the flavor.  Smooth and complex, but didn¬ít make me want to come back for more.
#26. I liked this much better then the dubbel.

Batch#26.Meringue like head on this honey colored brew. Spicy citrus nose with a little hint of alcohol. I¬ím getting a little bit of this banana taste that is previously mentioned. Definately a nice tripel but I¬ím starting to think I like dubbels better.Addendum: As this beer warms up the edges really seem to smooth out and the bite from the alcohol mellows considerably. Really a fine beer.I¬íll add one point to the overall. Thanks to Ringo for this one!
A fine example of a domestic Tripel... more spice than New Belgium and available on the east coast.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2003 Batch #26. Textbook example of a Belgian strong golden ale.  Tastes more Belgian than most Belgians...  Sort of hot, but very creamy and smooth.  Yes, we have bananas!
UPDATE 2/8/02 Cask conditioned - Excellent, wonderful, soift and tasty, even Raven liked it.  The cask-conditioned gets a 4.7 from me.  If you have the chance, you'll want to try it.

At first, I liked the Dubbel better than this, but after having a few bottles since then, this has become my favorite Allagash next to the White. Quite smooth for a 9% beer, with a perfect balance of spice and malt.

Batch #28: Hazy-golden with a lively white head. Must pour slowly. Beautifully abstract lace patterns. Fresh nose. Smooth and silken mouthfeel with a malleable texture in the malts; slips down the throat effortlessly. Very gentle with nothing really to complain about. 9.0% is only slightly evident in the finish, where it seems to round out the malts and tame them from becoming too cloying. Overall, very nice beer. My only (personal) wish would be that it was a little more spicy and hoppy.
I found this beer to be both flowery and hoppy (if that makes any sense).  Golden in color but they somehow manage to get a lot of taste into it.  A bit tart at times with a nice finish.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2009 Batch 20:Hazy,golden app.with world class head.Like Brut RSV only less dense,still dense!Exotic aroma!Fruit,spice,musty yeast,honey,vanilla,wood.Appetizing,sweet,and dry flavors with a fitting-perfect palate.Flavor not as complex as aroma(still not a bad thing in this case). Chewy,sweet,pale malts are followed by a woody,acidic dryness.Dry,spicy,hoppy finish.The yeast pour adds intensified yeast and spice flavors to finish(corriander?).Dangerously,refreshing and quenching.Cold or warm.

What a great Belgian Tripel, Pour with an enormous white head that lasts for days.  Slightly cloudy, golden amber color best describes the beer.  Smell of flowers and spice. Tastes greats and finishes dry and cleans.  If you like Tripels you cant go wrong.
Sweet,fruit esters,great,underlying hop charcater,great head.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2003 750 ml caged and corked bottle, batch #23. Pours hazy bright golden orange in color, decent cream colored lasting head. Fuity and spicy aromas. Fruity butter scotch and spicy, very dry and crisp finish. Full bodied with a full but crisp mouthfeel, man what a good American made tripple.

a very nice Belgian style micro.
hoppy for a trippel style. a little sweet and  has interesting fruity flavors.
the main thing that separates this from a true Beglian is the lack of the tart and zesty  yeast flavors.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2004 Whoa! Very carbonated! Strong scent of apple mix with the alcohol. Also a wood taste. Darker brown blond. I had Batch# 21. Definitely try this with a good brie, as they compliment each other well. Recommended American Belgian(huh?) a la Ommegang. Great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2005 Head is large and in between creamy and bubbly.  Lasted long.  This beer initially had stong citrus notes but also touched upon the sweeter part of my palate.  I found this in itself to be unique.  Finished strong with a full body.   This is a wonderful beer to someone who does not even generally care for Belgian beers.  Rerate.  Upon retrying this, it continually delivers. I buy this beer often.  I love the balance, and the herbal liqueur-like flavor.  Epluche Culotte may be more complex, but this has the balance and spiciness I enjoy most in a tripel.  I find this to be one of the least watery tripels as well.  Rerate  I suppose I should say more.  I think, of all the good beers I have had in the last 3 years, I may have purchased this one the most frequently.  That is, in part, due to its broad availability near where I live, but I think it is more due to how damned good it is.  I could never tell this wasnt made in Belgium, in a blind taste.  Wonderful balance throughout.  Maybe the best example of a beer that dosent have to use sheer force of flavor and body to come across as good.  It¬ís in the balance, the yeast, the spice, the delicate flavors that play about on the palate.  Some of the newer batches have moments of, perhaps, too much sweetness, and the alcohol does show up at times, but as far as aging potential goes, this stuff is superb.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2016 Bottle (750mL, Dec 03, 2015 bottling). Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy light to medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, basement), with notes of dried pineapple, pear, pepper, lemon zest, and alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. Wow...most definitely a 4+ rendition, at least in this format and at this age. I wouldn¬ít age it any further, for the aroma will surely continue to fade, but my god the mouthfeel and flavor balance are exquisite! And the aroma is holding up astoundingly well. Extremely authentic and well-made. I¬ím not a huge fan of Allagash in general, but this is pretty much a benchmark for the style.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2015 Three-dimensional honeyed malts support the subtle peppery, herbal hops¬ÖNot far away, gracious pears are tickled by the spicy hop bitterness and alcohol warmth¬ÖThis fantastically classy Tripel may not have come from an abbey, but it sure knows how to make one feel heavenly...

Aroma has a lot of elements, sweet and fruity maltiness, spices, yeast, and a tinge of alcohol.  Carbonation is very evident, head is average for the style, but I was careful in pouring.  It¬ís an attractive hazy golden-orange color (I ¬írolled¬í the bottle before pouring). Fantastic lacing.  Flavor profile is complex, with the fruity, malty flavors most apparent, along with some herbal tastes, spices, and a bit of yeast.  Finish is long and satisfying, and yeasty.  Warming.  This beer just feels great on the tongue, the carbonation really does something for it.  This is a great Tripel in every aspect, it feels, smells, looks and tastes very nice.  Nice big 750ml bottle, too.  I can¬ít think of a Tripel I¬íd rather have more right now.  Thanks a lot, jca!  Addendum: this bottle was from batch #13.

Golden hue with a touch of amber and an immense white head. Huge aroma of yeast and bread with a hint of alcohol for good measure. Flavors of candied sugar and coriander with a touch of alcohol and hop bitterness on the palate. Solid tripel.
Slight spiciness mixed with citrus in the aroma.  Body is wel balanced for 9%.  A good Belgian Strong, but nothing outstanding to make it stand out.
(Batch #23) My 200th rating! The passion fruit description is dead on. Pours with a medium head, well under control, medium carbonation. Sweet, with mild banana notes, a bit too much alcohol bite.
Not impressed.  Long, dry and bitter finish. Alcohol too strong in this one also.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2003 batch 22. A very nice Belgian strong, nice and smooth and lots of complex flavors mixing well. Its just not my style, a little too sweet, and even though I love the high alcohol in othey styles, its just too much in Belgians. One of my favorite Belgian Strongs, but there are many beers out there I would rather have.

Pours to a hazy golden color with a smallish head.  Aroma of pears and slight corriander.  Flavors of honey, candi, cotton candy, peaches, and passion fruit.  Finishes fairly dry with slight hop acidity.
a very good interpretation of the style.  They capture a lot of the nuances of a classic triple
I just couldn¬ít get into this one and thought it was a tad harsh.  The 9% alcohol really shows through.

Batch 24:  Loose head that disappears quickly.  A clarified gold color in which the bubbles keep on rising, like champagne.  Sugary aroma with spicy undertones.  A rich, sweetly spicy flavor that acts like champagne (tickles your nose!).  This is to beer what basmati rice is to rice -- sweeter, richer, more sophisticated, and slighly exotic (in a tame, manageable way) -- for boorish Americans, at least.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2005 (11/19/05, Batch 67) Soft off-white head, leaves nice lacing,  atop lightly hazed golden body.  Aroma is rich and inviting -- moderately sweet, flowery, honey, passion fruit, cantalope, banana, orange.  Taste is moderately sweet, fruity (cantalope, orange, passion fruit, banana).  Less dryness than expected in the finish for a tripel.  Medium body, alcohol very well hidden.  An excellent beer that should improve with aging. (10/4/8/4/17)

(5/7/02, Batch 24)  Wow!!  Very sweet and fruity aroma.  Light body dances on the tongue.  Sweet flavor, but there¬ís much more -- complex, fruity (banana, among other flavors), spicy, and some yeastiness.  Ever-so-slight astringency in the aftertaste is one of the only drawbacks.  Good white head with nice lacing, atop a beautiful golden liquid. (10/5/9/4/18)

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2004 re-rate5/7:  very complex but alcohol starts the ride,and then flavors burst about in your mouth.  Later in the glass I was tasting peach, or maybe that's the passion fruit it claims in the commercial description. This is really delicious. Mine was batch number 22. (both batch 22)(one more for summer, maybe it'll get better????)
This is great stuff!!   After the shock of alcohol, the fruitness wanders over the tongue.  Nicely hopped, and very flavorful.  A Great Beer!

Outstanding. A true special occasion beer. Batch 20: Set apart by wonderful, balanced handling of the taste and alcohol, perfect rocky head. Snappy, tangy, incredibly crisp. Fruit hangs in, hops are strong. This and the Grand Cru would make a great surprise for someone who has never had hand crafted beer, I think. Jayme done good sending me ths one.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 2/20/03:  Batch #33:  More of a earthy tone in the aroma, and deeper fuller finish.  +0.3 from last time. 3/20/02:750ML bottle, hand numbered batch 16: Hazy golden color, yeasty nose, fruity/dry taste.  After reading the description and getting into it, I do smell the passion fruit and taste the banana, but I'm not getting any honey.  In general I don't prefer Tripel's so I can't rate it any higher, but this is a quality brew.
This stuff is quite possibly the best Belgian Ale I have seen on the market.  The herbal notes come through, followed by a slight fruity finish, albeit smooth.
Every bit as good as the top authentic Belgians.  I did a side by side taste test with Duinen Tripel, and while subtly different; no worse, no better.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 (re-rate, 750ml batch 49) Cloudy, chilled yellow/golden with a thin but steady, fairly creamy looking head. Aromas of mango, candied sugar,yeast, heady pale malts, corriander and more. Very lush, fluffy mouthfeel, somewhat alcoholic and yeasty at first. Malts begin to shine as it warms, fruitness although subtle makes it presence known, corriander, herbal notes and white pepper gives it a dash of zest along with the alcohol presence. Medium bodied at best, drinkability is off the charts for a triple, has a bit of a salt edge that may be off putting for some but the ecletic mix of flavors are very rewarding if you have the patience for them. Damn fine brew.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 An insanely drinkable beer.  Absolutely complex with notes of medicine, hops, salt and herbs.  Head is as big as a beer can possibly have, the whole way down.  Creamy, slightly spritzy mouthfeel and a lingering, salty finish.   I don¬ít know if this is really 9% because the alcohol is hardly noticeable.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: A good choice for someone who wants to break into stronger Belgian-style beers. A bit fruity, not as phenolic as some of true Belgians.  A little more hops than some ¬íreal¬í Belgian Tripels. Gets a lot of credit for the pricepoint.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2003    Light golden cloudy body, thin creamy head. Spicy citrus aroma, yeasty with soft floral notes. Flowery, yeasty malt flavor, notes of spicy coriander/ orange. Soft mouthfeel. Smooth, hoppy, citrusy finish. Crisp, clean peppery finish.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2006 August 2001:  OK, here¬ís one where the description is actually right on target.  I DO smell passion-fruit, actually; the flavor seems to be honey-lemon and wheat, there is little to be disappointed in here except perhaps the aroma could be a bit fuller.  Alcohol seems faint for a beer this strong; the smoothness and balance are remarkable.  Best Belgian from outside Belgium I¬íve ever had. 9/4/10/5/19 4.7

July 2006:  750 ml bottle, batch 72, cellar temperature or a bit below in an Allagash glass.  An immense frothy snow-white head tops the luminous whiskey-gold body and leaves very thick, near opaque lacing as it dies....deep, sweet fruitiness bombs you in the nose, honey and light floral (dogwood)  notes, faint hints of white pepper, subtle yeasts -- an absolutely transcendant, intoxicating combination......a faint sour breadiness begins our journey across the tongue followed quickly by honey-malt sweetness and moderate alcohol apparency.....nice balance, but not nearly as complex on the tongue as the aroma gives hopes for; this is better I think on draught or with a couple of years (I¬ím guessing this batch is about 6 months old), the alcohol is just a bit too much and the palate a touch sticky.  World class still?  Maybe....more samples to come, to confirm...
Cosidering relatively low price, its a great tripel.

As with their white - a dead on interpretation of the style, and one of the best of its style produced in the USA.  Light in body, making it exceptionally drinkable, yet full-flavored, with plenty of spicy yeasty notes.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2003 As this winsome beer sits in the triple glass a slightly hazy golden amber color, the head behemothic, frothy in its texture, brilliant white and as it evanesces leaves behind a glutinous sheet of lace to smother the glass. Malt dominates the nose, citrus crisp, fresh and clean, with just the slightest tinge of yeast, start is malt and somewhat sweet, the top middling in its feel. Stingingly acidic is the finish, hops pronounced in their spiciness, the aftertaste droughty and long lasting, a quite quaffable beer in my humble opinion.

Wow.. another winner by Allagash.. This beer is kind of a well groomed mix of malt and hops.  This is made in the m√©thod champanoise, and boy oh boy.  it has a very clean, mellow flavor.  A fairly malty, yet hoppy aroma. damn this is nice.  I certainly recommend this beer to anybody with taste.
